questions.text: Complement fixation can be done by all of the antibodies except:
questions.solution:
Complement fixation cannot be done by IgG4.

Complement cannot bind to the antigen directly. It binds once the antibody fixes or activates it. The actual binding of the complement on antibody occurs on the Fc portion of the Ig molecule.

Compliment fixation involves IgM, IgG3, IgG1, and IgG2 in this order. IgG4, IgA, IgD, and IgE cannot fix complement.

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: An AIDS patient presented with neurological symptoms like seizures, focal neurological deficits, and diplopia. There is history of headache, nausea, dizziness, irritability, and a low-grade fever for the past 3 months. Brain biopsy showed granulomatous inflammation, trophozoites, and cysts. The trophozoites were large, 20-50 μm in size, and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia. Which of the following organisms is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of granulomatous amebic encephalitis. It is caused by acanthamoeba.

Granulomatous amebic encephalitis: It is a granulomatous infection of the brain and spinal cord that typically occurs in persons with a compromised immune system. 

  • Granulomatous amebic encephalitis is believed to follow the inhalation of the dried cysts. The incubation period is long and the evolution of the illness is slow. 
  • The clinical picture is that of intracranial space-occupying lesions with seizures, pareses and mental deterioration.
  • Diagnosis of GAE is made by demonstration of trophozoites (The trophozoites are large, 20-50 μm in size, and characterized
    by spine-like pseudopodia)     and cysts in brain biopsy, culture and immunofluorescence microscopy using monoclonal antibodies.

Other options:

Naegleria fowleri a pathogenic free-living amoeba which causes the disease primary amoebic meningoencephalitis(PAM)

Naegleria fowleri:

  • Patients are mostly previously healthy young adults or children, the infection comes from water containing free-living amoeba and usually follows swimming or diving in ponds.
  • The amoeba invades the nasal mucosa and passes through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges and brain to initiate acute purulent meningitis and encephalitis (PAM).
  • The incubation period varies from 2 days to 2 weeks.
  • In the incubation period, the patient experiences anosmia, the disease advances rapidly, causing fever, headache, vomiting, stiff neck, ataxia, seizure and coma and ends fatally within a Week. (average 5 days). 

Toxoplasma: Trophozoites are crescent-shaped and are 3-7 μm in size.

Plasmodium falciparum: Runs more acute course. In peripheral blood smear, ring forms and gametocytes are seen.

questions.text: A group of health workers is conducting a perinatal mortality audit at a hospital. Which of the following should they not take into account to calculate the perinatal mortality rate?

choices.text: Number of live births per year
Number of late neonatal deaths per year
Number of stillbirths over 1000 g per year
Number of early neonatal deaths per year

questions.solution:
Number of late neonatal deaths per year is not included in the perinatal mortality rate.

The perinatal mortality rate (PMR) is calculated using the following parameters during a particular time period:

  • Late fetal deaths or stillbirths >1000 g - correlates to 28 weeks of gestation
  • Early neonatal deaths - from birth to 7 days of life
  • Live births >1000 g

The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) refers to the rate of deaths within the first 28 days of life. It is calculated using the following parameters:

  • Early neonatal deaths
  • Late neonatal deaths - after 7th day but before 28th completed day of life

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: The ‘en bloc' removal of organs is a feature of which of the following autopsy techniques?
questions.solution:
The 'en bloc' removal of organs is done in the Ghon technique. In this procedure, the cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and urogenital organs are removed as organ blocks.

The 'en masse' removal of organs is done in the Letulle technique. It is the removal of the cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs as a single organ mass. The mass is then dissected into organ blocks.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

Related Pearl: Autopsy: Types Of Incision

Type of incision Procedure Indication Advantage
I-Shaped Incision Extends from symphysis menti to symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice It is simple and convenient.
Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the acromial process on the shoulder on either side of the chest, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.
Modified Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the angle of mandible on either side, brought forwards, downwards to meet at the suprasternal notch . It is then run downwards as a midline incision up to the pubic symphysis. Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text: A primigravida came to the labor room at 40 weeks + 5 days gestation for the induction of labor. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is 1 cm dilated and 3 cm long. The vertex is at -1 station, and the cervix is soft and posterior. What will be the modified Bishop score for this lady?
questions.solution:
The modified Bishop score in this patient is calculated to be 6.

The Bishop score is a scoring system used to assess labor induction outcomes. It is based on the station of the head, dilation, length, position, and consistency of the cervix noted by doing a vaginal examination.

Note: In the modified Bishop score (1991) system, effacement is replaced by the cervical length in centimeters.

From the data given in the question:

  • The position of the cervix is posterior, hence score = 0
  • Cervical length is 3 cm, hence score = 1
  • Cervical dilatation is 1 cm, hence score = 1
  • Consistency of cervix is soft, hence score = 2
  • The station of the head is -1, hence score = 2

Hence, the modified Bishop score is 0+1+1+2+2 = 6.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text:
All the following are methods of indirect transmission of diseases, except _____.
  1. Contact with soil
  2. Droplet nuclei
  3. Fomite borne
  4. Unclean hands and fingers
  5. Transplacental
questions.solution:
Contact with soil & transplacental route is the direct mode of disease transmission among the given options.

Communicable diseases are classified based on the mode of transmission:

  • Direct:
    • Direct contact (e.g.: sexual intercourse)
    • Contact with soil
    • Droplet infection
    • Skin or mucosal inoculation
    • Transplacental 
  • Indirect: 
    • Vehicle-borne
    • Vector-borne
    • Air-borne
      • Droplet nuclei
      • Dust
    • Fomite-borne
    • Unclean hands and fingers

The traditional 5 F's - flies, fingers, fomites, food, and fluids can be used to remember the modes of indirect transmission. Some infectious agents are able to survive in the external environment while maintaining their basic properties of virulence. This is a requirement for this indirect transmission.

An important distinction has to be drawn between droplet nuclei infection and droplet infection. The main difference between airborne droplet nuclei and droplet transmission is in the size of infected/ contagious particles and whether proximity is required for transmission.

Droplet nuclei/ residue from evaporated droplets containing infective microorganisms can result in airborne transmission. The size of these droplet nuclei is <5 μm in diameter, and they can remain suspended in the air for significant periods of time, allowing them to be transmitted over distances >1 m. There's no need for close proximity or contact. Diseases like chickenpox, measles, tuberculosis, and influenza can spread through airborne transmission.

Droplet transmission occurs when one cough or sneezes, and contagious droplets from the infected person travel shortly in the air and directly comes in contact with another person's conjunctiva, mouth, or nasal mucosa. The particle size here is >5 μm in diameter. Transmission here requires close proximity and direct contact. Examples of diseases spread via this route include the common cold, diphtheria, and whooping cough.

Related Pearl: Modes of Transmission of Communicable Diseases

Direct

Indirect

Direct contact

Droplet infection

Contact with soil

Inoculation into skin or mucosa

Vertical (transplacental)

Vehicle-borne

Vector borne – mechanical or biological

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is approved for prophylaxis against respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection?
questions.solution:
Nirsevimab is a monoclonal antibody recently approved by the FDA to be used as a prophylaxis against respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection.

RSV is responsible for more than half of the cases of bronchiolitis in infants less than 1 year of age. It generally presents as a fever with cough and wheezing. It has a very high infectivity and transmission is by close contact and droplet transmission. Nasopharyngeal swabs and nasal washings are collected as samples. They are inoculated in cell culture (HeLa or Hep-2) immediately after collection. In cultured cells, RSV shows characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation.

The image given below shows giant cells and syncytial formation seen in RSV infection:

Nirsevimab is a monoclonal antibody with activity against RSV. One dose of Nirsevimab, administered as a single intramuscular injection prior to or during RSV season, may provide protection during the RSV season. Possible adverse effects include rash and injection site reactions.

Other options: Ribavirin is used for treating RSV infections but is not approved for use as a prophylactic agent.

Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IgE indicated in asthma.

Oseltamivir is used for the treatment of avian influenza and is not recommended to be used for RSV.

questions.text: The dose-response curve for the effects of three drugs on the same tissue is shown in the image below. Which of the following represents drug A and drug C, respectively, at μ receptor?
questions.solution:
In the given image, drugs A and drug C are agonists and partial agonists, which can be a combination of fentanyl and buprenorphine, respectively.

Drugs that are only partially as effective as agonists are partial agonists. Drug C does not produce a full response at any concentration, making it a partial agonist. In the given graph, fentanyl is an agonist at the μ receptor producing a response of drug A and buprenorphine is a partial agonist at μ receptor producing sub-maximal response.

Drugs that bind to physiological receptors and mimic the regulatory effects of endogenous signaling compounds are agonists. When two drugs produce equivalent responses, the drug whose dose-response curve lies to the left is said to be the more potent since it requires a lower dose to produce the same effect. Drug A and drug B produce the same action and level of response in the tissue. The curve of drug A on the left indicates that it produces the same response at a lower concentration, making it more potent than drug B. Fentanyl and methadone(option A), morphine and hydromorphone(option B), methadone and morphine(option D) are examples of the same.

questions.text: What is the condition seen in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows conjoined twins with fusion in the pelvic region, which is known as ischiopagus.

In monochorionic monoamniotic twinning, incomplete duplication of the embryonic disc can occur. Incomplete separation of the monozygotic twins results in the birth of two infants that are joined or fused together at some part of the body. These twins are known as conjoined twins or Siamese twins.

Depending on the degree of incomplete separation, different types of conjoined twins can form:

  • Craniopagus: United at the head
  • Thoracopagus: United at the thorax 
  • Cephalothoracopagus: Fusion of both head and thorax
  • Omphalopagous or Xiphipagous: United anteriorly from the xiphoid to the umbilicus
  • Parapagus: Lateral fusion with two heads, sharing a single thorax, abdomen, and pelvis (most common)
  • Ischiopagus: United at the pelvis 
  • Pygopagus: United in the sacral region
  • Heteropagous: Asymmetric forms

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman complains of recurrent episodes of diarrhea and abdominal pain for the last 5 months. The pain is relieved after defecation. After investigations, a diagnosis of diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome is considered. Which of the following opioid drugs has been approved for treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
The opioid drug approved for diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome(IBS) is eluxadoline.

Eluxadoline is an opioid agonist that acts on μ-receptors. On oral administration, it acts on gut opioid receptor and causes slow colonic movement and increased fecal fluid absorption. FDA has approved eluxadoline in patients with diarrhea-predominant IBS. The adverse effects include constipation, sphincter of Oddi spasm leading to abdominal pain, pancreatitis, and elevated pancreatic enzymes or liver enzymes. Therefore eluxadoline should not be used in patients with a history of pancreatitis, alcoholism, or sphincter of Oddi disease.

Other drugs used in the treatment of diarrhea-predominant IBS are:

  • Alosetron
  • Rifaximin
  • Loperamide

Other options:

Option B- Methylnaltrexone is a peripheral mu-opioid receptor (MOR) antagonist and has been approved for opioid-induced constipation. 

Option C- Naloxegol is a peripheral MOR antagonist. It does not cross the blood-brain barrier. It is approved in the treatment of opioid-induced constipation.

Option D- Alvimopan like methylnaltrexone and naloxegol is a peripheral MOR antagonist. It decreases intestinal transit time and improves defecation. It has been approved to shorten the time of postoperative ileus. 

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presented with short stature.His upper segment to lower segment ratio is 1. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
The upper segment to lower segment (U/L) ratio in this child is 1. The U/L ratio is low for his age which makes spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia most likely among the given options.

The lower segment is defined as the length from the symphysis pubis to the floor. The upper segment is measured by subtracting the lower segment from the height.

The U/L ratio is

  • 1.7 at birth
  • 1.3 at 3 years
  • 1 after 7 years
  • 0.9 in adults

High U/L ratio:

  • Rickets
  • Achondroplasia
  • Untreated congenital hypothyroidism 

Low U/L ratio:

  • Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia
  • Vertebral anomalies

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is brought to the ER after he complained of chest tightness and then collapsed after running a half marathon. His father and grandfather also have a history of similar episodes. On echocardiography, mitral regurgitation and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a young patient with a history of chest tightness and sudden collapse following strenuous physical activity, with a similar history in first-degree relatives and echocardiography showing mitral regurgitation with systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet, a diagnosis of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HCM) is likely. 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by the thickening of the septal myocardium below the aortic valve. This leads to obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract and the most common presenting symptoms. Systolic obstruction is initiated by drag forces, which push an anterior displaced anterior mitral valve leaflet into contact with the hypertrophied septum. This causes mitral regurgitation, and decreased cardiac output due to the obstruction. Stroke volume is maintained by increasing the pressure generated by the ventricles, and can thus lead to myocardial ischemia. Conditions of low preload such as dehydration and low afterload such as arterial vasodilation can cause hypotension and syncope. 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with variable penetrance. The most frequent symptoms are dyspnea and chest pain. Syncope can occur following exertion as diastolic filling diminished due to fluid loss and tachycardia increases LV outflow tract obstruction. Ventricular arrhythmias can cause sudden cardiac death. On examination, pulsus bisferiens, triple apical impulse and loud S4 may be heard. Auscultation may reveal a systolic murmur that increases with upright posture or Valsalva maneuver and decreases with squatting.

Echocardiography is diagnostic, showing left ventricular hypertrophy with asymmetrical hypertrophy of the interventricular septum, systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve and mitral regurgitation. Beta-blockers are the initial medication in symptomatic individuals. Calcium channel blockers, specially Verapamil have also been shown to be effective in symptomatic patients. Preventive intra-cardiac defibrillator is indicated for patients with HCM and documented cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular tachycardia.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

questions.text: You were posted for an autopsy of a 34-year-old man who was under police custody for interrogation. On external examination, signs of third-degree torture were present. Which of the following incisions is preferred to detect and evaluate the hidden subcutaneous hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of custodial death. The incision that is preferred to detect and evaluate the hidden subcutaneous hemorrhage is the elongated X- shaped incision.

An elongated X-shaped incision is used to dissect subcutaneous structures in the back of the body. It helps identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries when superficial imprints are faint. This type of incision is helpful in the reconstruction of events before death and is practiced in custodial death.

The image below shows the 'elongated X- shaped' incision:


Option A: I-shaped incision is a simple, convenient, and most commonly practiced incision. It extends from the symphysis mentii to the symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left or right around the umbilicus. The umbilicus has dense fibrous tissue and is difficult to penetrate with the needle for suturing after autopsy.

The image below shows the 'I- shaped' incision:


Option C: Y-shaped incision commences at anterior axillary fold on the chest on either side, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum in the midline and then run downwards to the symphysis pubis, as in the I-shaped incision. It is preferred in females. It is more cosmetically accepted as the incision, and the stitches are minimally seen after the autopsy. 

The image below shows the 'Y-shaped' incision:


Option D: In the modified Y-shaped incision, an incision is made in the midline from the suprasternal notch to the symphysis pubis. The incision extends from the suprasternal notch over the clavicle to its center on both sides and then passes upwards over the neck behind the ear. It is indicated in cases of strangulation or death due to compression of the neck.

The image below shows the 'modified Y-shaped' incision:

Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the acromial process on the shoulder on either side of the chest, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.
Modified Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the angle of mandible on either side, brought forwards, downwards to meet at the suprasternal notch . It is then run downwards as a midline incision up to the pubic symphysis. Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text: A young boy was hit by a cricket ball on his left eye. There was no restriction in ocular movements nor any visual disturbances. However, the ophthalmologist wanted to check for a foreign body. He used the instrument shown below. What is the false statement regarding this?

choices.text: It provides a mirror image of the opposite angle
It is used for the demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae
It is used for the measurement of the angle of the posterior chamber
It is used for the localization of a foreign body

questions.solution:
The given instrument is an indirect gonioscope of four-mirror type, which is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber and not the posterior chamber. 

Types:

  • Indirect gonioprism: provides a mirror image of the opposite angle.
  • Direct goniolens: provides a direct view of the angle

Application:

  • To view the angle of the anterior chamber
  • Localization of the foreign body, abnormal blood vessels, or tumours in the angle
  • Demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae
  • Direct goniolens can be used during goniotomy

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with an untreated illness caused by a virus whose replication cycle is given below. Which of the following oral lesions is unlikely to develop in this patient?

choices.text: White, plaque-like lesions with cheesy exudate, on an erythematous mucosa
Discrete red lesions with central bluish-white spots seen on the buccal mucosa at the level of premolars
White, frond-like lesions with hair-like growths from folds in the patches
Well-circumscribed painful ulcers with a white necrotic base surrounded by a red halo.

questions.solution:
The replication cycle above shows an RNA virus using the reverse transcriptase enzyme to synthesize complementary DNA which is then integrated into the host DNA. The most probable virus, thus, is the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). 

Koplik spots (discrete red lesions with central bluish-white spots seen on the buccal mucosa at the level of premolars) are pathognomic lesions seen in measles are are not associated with HIV. 

Oral lesions commonly seen in patients with untreated HIV infection CD4+ T cell counts of <300/μL, include:

  • Oral Thrush/ Oral candidiasis associated with Candida albicans - presents as white plaque-like lesions with cheesy exudate on an erythematous mucosa. They are typically painful and can be easily brushed off. Diagnosis by KOH preparation demonstrates budding yeasts, hyphae, or pseudohyphae.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia associated with Epstein-Barr virus presents as white, frond-like lesions with hair-like growths from folds in the patches, generally along the lateral borders of the tongue. they are typically painless and cannot be brushed. Despite its name, it is not considered premalignant. 
  • Aphthous ulcers- Well-circumscribed ulcerative lesions with a white necrotic base surrounded by a red halo. These lesions are of unknown etiology and can be quite painful and interfere with swallowing. Topical anaesthetics provide immediate symptomatic relief of short duration.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient suffered a diaphyseal tibial fracture sustained in a road traffic accident and he was managed conservatively with casts. The follow-up radiograph after a few months is as shown below. What could be the probable cause of this finding?

choices.text: Due to loss of a fragment of bone

questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows hypertrophic nonunion of the Tibia. It is mostly due to inadequate stabilization.

Based on increasing biologic potential for fracture healing, non-union can be of the following types:

  • Atrophic nonunion: Poor healing response with no callus formation due to little or no active bone-forming cells at the fracture site. The blood supply is typically poor. On radiography, there is an absence of bone reaction. 
  • Oligotrophic nonunion: There is minimal callus formation, often due to inadequate approximation of fracture surfaces. On radiography, there is minimal bone healing reaction.
  • Hypertrophic nonunion: These fractures have adequate healing response and good vascularity. There is a lack of adequate stability for the union to occur. On radiography, there is usually abundant callus formation with an intervening dark area of fibrocartilage-lacking mineral. It can occur after initial nonoperative management or in some cases after initial operative management where there was inadequate stabilization.

questions.text: A child presents to you with an abdominal mass, hypertension, and hematuria. Which of the following statement is false about the syndromes associated with this condition?

choices.text: Trisomy 18 can result in cognitive impairment
Aniridia is associated with WAGR syndrome
Male abnormal genitalia is commonly seen in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome
Early-onset renal failure is characteristic of Denys-Drash syndrome

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of Wilms tumor. Male abnormal genitalia is associated with Denys-Drash syndrome and not with Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome. Both of these are syndromes associated with Wilm's tumor. 

Wilms tumor is the most common primary malignant renal tumor in children. After neuroblastoma, it is the second most common malignant abdominal tumor in childhood. The clinical presentation of Wilms tumor is an incidental discovery of asymptomatic abdominal mass, hypertension, abdominal pain, and gross painless hematuria. Pulmonary embolism can be a fatal complication. 

Wilm's tumor arises due to loss of function mutation of the WT1 (Wilm's tumor 1) gene. The syndromes associated with Wilms tumor are WAGR syndrome, Denys-Drash syndrome, Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome, Fraiser syndrome, Fanconi anemia, trisomy 18, and Perlman syndrome.

Noteworthy syndromes and their features are:

  • WAGR syndrome: Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities, mental retardation
  • Denys-Drash syndrome: Early-onset renal failure, gonadal dysgenesis / male pseudohermaphroditism
  • Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome: Hemihypertrophy, organomegaly, macroglossia
  • Trisomy 18: Prominent occiput, cognitive impairment, hypertonia

Histologically, Wilms tumor is made of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cells. 

Wilms tumor is an example of small, round, blue-cell tumors that are malignant neoplasms that have a characteristic appearance under the microscope. Other examples include: 

  • Medulloblastoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

The diagnosis can be confirmed by radiological investigations like CT, abdominal ultrasound, and biopsy.

Surgery, and chemotherapy, with or without radiotherapy can be used for the management.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male from a rural district presents to the clinic with severe pain during and after defecation. The pain has been present for the past 6 months but has increased in severity recently and reached maximal intensity 3 days back. Inspection of the rectum shows a bulging purple mass as shown below. Rectal examination was difficult to perform because of pain, but no other masses could be palpated. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the image are suggestive of thrombosed external hemorrhoids. If the patient presents to the hospital after 72 hours, then it is treated conservatively with analgesics and a Sitz bath. Once the symptoms come down, definitive surgery is performed. 

Patients who present within 72 hours of thrombosis are treated with excision(option D). This procedure involves the removal of the clot with an elliptical incision on the skin.

Four degrees of hemorrhoids:

First degree – bleed only, no prolapse

Second degree – prolapse but reduce spontaneously

Third-degree – prolapse and have to be manually reduced

Fourth degree – permanently prolapsed

Treatment of Hemorrhoids:

  • Grade1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treated with simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation, and cryotherapy.
  • Surgery is indicated in: 
    • Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids
    • Hemorrhoids with a significant external component
    • Early grade piles not responding to office procedures
  • Surgical procedures used in the removal of hemorrhoids are:
    • Open (Milligan–Morgan) hemorrhoidectomy: resection of hemorrhoidal tissue and wounds are left open and allowed to heal by secondary intention.
    • Closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy: involves resection of hemorrhoidal tissue and closure of the wounds with absorbable suture
    • Stapled hemorrhoidopexy
    • Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation
    • Other options:

Sitz bath - involves sitting in a bath of water that contains salt or sodium bicarbonate. Image is shown below

Option A and C - Hemorrhoidectomy - it is indicated for hemorrhoids complicated by fissures, fistulae, ulceration and strangulation. Also for symptomatic external hemorrhoids.

Incision is not recommended as it may lead to complications such as rethrombosis.

Below is an image showing the two types of hemorrhoids.

questions.text: You are posted in pediatrics OPD as an intern. A 7-year-old child presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent fractures and poorly-developed teeth. Examination reveals joint laxity and blue sclera. Both parents are phenotypically normal. Your senior asks you to interpret the mode of inheritance in this case from the pedigree chart given below.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of recurrent fractures, poorly developed teeth with blue sclera, and joint laxity is suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta. Osteogenesis imperfecta is an example of gonadal mosaicism where phenotypically normal parents can have more than one affected child.

It is a type of autosomal dominant disorder where some patients do not have phenotypically affected parents. The disorder can result from a new mutation in the egg or the sperm from which the zygote was formed. The siblings may or may not be affected. In some cases, mosaicism can result from a mutation that occurs after the formation of the zygote, during early (embryonic) development.

A phenotypically normal parent who has gonadal mosaicism can transmit the disease-causing mutation to the offspring through their mutated ova/sperm. Therefore, there is a possibility that more than one child of such a parent can be affected.

Other options:

Option A- In X-linked recessive conditions, an affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons but all daughters will be carriers of the disease. Sons of heterozygous women have a chance of inheriting the mutant gene.

Option B- In mitochondrial inheritance, if the mother is affected and the father is normal, then all their children (both male and female) will be affected. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother will not be affected.

Option C- Genomic imprinting is the transcriptional silencing of either maternal or paternal allele. Prader-Willi syndrome is paternal imprinting (deletion of paternal chromosome15 in 65-75% of individuals), maternal uniparental disomy 15 (20-30%), or an imprinting defect; and Angelman syndrome is due to maternal imprinting (deletion of maternal chromosome 15).

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient who works at a smelter presented with headache, fever, sweating, muscle pain, joint pains, and chest tightness and discomfort. He had returned to work only that morning after taking a long weekend off for Holi. He was symptomatically managed, and his condition improved remarkably within a couple of days. Which of the following substances is most likely to be implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Monday morning fever (Smelter shakes/ Brass chills/ Metal fume fever), which is used to describe the symptoms associated with zinc poisoning.

Symptoms of metal fume fever occur 4–24 hours after exposure to zinc oxide fumes. It presents as an influenza-like illness with headache, fever, sweating, chest tightness and discomfort, and joint pains. Typically, symptoms appear after the weekend, thereby giving rise to the term ‘Monday morning fever’. Zinc toxicity resembles malarial chills. Exposure to zinc chloride ammunition bombs (hexite) has led to the development of fatal adult respiratory distress syndrome.

It has been shown that inhalation of zinc oxide fumes is associated with a dose-dependent marked inflammatory response in the lung even if clinical symptoms do not occur. The illness usually has a good prognosis, and the symptoms often improve towards the end of the working week as some short-term immunity from previous symptoms usually develops. The pathogenesis is not known but is thought to result from endogenous pyrogen release due to cell lysis.

Other metals that produce this condition may include copper, magnesium, iron, chromium, cadmium, nickel, manganese, mercury, cobalt, lead, antimony, silver and aluminum, etc.

Other options:

In acute poisoning with phosphorus, the vomitus and stools will be luminous in the dark. The stools may give rise to faint fumes, constituting the smoky stool syndrome.

    • Raindrop pigmentation is seen on temples, eyelids, and neck

    • Hyperkeratosis of palms and soles
    • Painful paresthesia of hands and feet
    • Red velvety appearance of the stomach
    • Blackfoot disease - a gangrenous condition affecting the extremities

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman with abdominal pain and hematochezia was diagnosed with stage II colon carcinoma located in the hepatic flexure. An extended right hemicolectomy was performed. Which of the following images represents the mentioned procedure?

(the white area indicates the parts resected)
questions.solution:
Image 2 represents extended right hemicolectomy, which is the surgical procedure of choice for colorectal carcinoma in the hepatic flexure.

This procedure involves the division of the ileocolic, right colic, and middle colic vessels, and the removal of the specimen with its mesentery. The parts resected include the cecum, approximately 10 cm of the terminal ileum with ileocecal junction, ascending colon, hepatic flexure, and proximal transverse colon (distal transverse colon and splenic flexure are also sometimes removed).

Procedures performed for tumors of the colon are summarized below:

Tumor location Procedure of choice
Cecum/Ascending colon 

Right hemicolectomy 

  • Ligation and division of the ileocolic, right colic, and right branch of the middle colic vessels 
  • Resection of cecum + approx 10 cm of the terminal ileum with ileocecal junction + ascending colon + hepatic flexure 
Hepatic flexure/Transverse colon

Extended right hemicolectomy

  • Ligation and division of the ileocolic, right colic, and middle colic vessels 
  • Resection of the cecum + approx 10 cm of the terminal ileum with ileocecal junction + ascending colon + hepatic flexure + proximal transverse colon (distal transverse colon and splenic flexure are also sometimes removed)
Splenic flexure/ Descending colon

Left hemicolectomy 

  • Ligation and division of the left branch of the middle colic vessels, the left colic vessel, and the first branches of the sigmoid vessels 
  • Resection of the transverse colon (left MCA territory) + Splenic flexure + Descending colon up to the sigmoid colon
Sigmoid colon Sigmoid colectomy, or LAR (Low anterior resection)
  • Ligation and division of the sigmoid branches of the inferior mesenteric artery.
  • Removal of the entire sigmoid colon and rectum

 

Other options:

Image 1 represents a right hemicolectomy, which is done for tumors of the cecum/ascending colon.

Image 3 represents a total proctocolectomy. Here, the entire colon, rectum, and anus are removed, and the ileum is brought to the skin with ileostomy.

Image 4 represents a total or subtotal colectomy. The entire colon is removed except for the sigmoid colon to create an ileosigmoidal anastomosis. It is done for fulminant colitis, attenuated familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), or synchronous colon carcinomas.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the infertility clinic with complaints of chronic pelvic pain and irregular menstruation. An endometrial biopsy was taken and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing caseating granulomas suggest a diagnosis of endometrial tuberculosis. 

The endometrium is involved in 50–60% of all cases of genital tuberculosis. It can appear grossly normal due to cyclical shedding. The diagnosis is made by histopathological examination, which shows the above findings. 

It occurs as a descending infection from the fallopian tubes due to anatomical proximity and continuity. Hematogenous spread is thought to be the process by which the tubercle bacilli implant into the mucosa of the fallopian tubes and subsequently affect the endometrium by direct extension. There is a reinfection every month due to shedding off of the endometrium during menstruation 

Findings:

  • Ulcerative, granular, or fungating lesions may be seen occasionally
  • Shrunken cavity due to fibrosis
  • Golf-ball ostia of fallopian tubes 
  • Extensive fibrosis can also close the internal os causing pyometra 
  • Intrauterine adhesions - Asherman syndrome 

Genital tract tuberculosis is among the commonest causes of infertility. They often present with a history of infertility, irregular menstruation, and vaginal discharge.

Treatment includes standard anti-tubercular therapy based on drug sensitivity patterns.

The below histology image of endometrial tuberculosis shows Langhans cells, caseating granulomas, and epithelioid cells in the background of endometrial glands and an image of hysterosalpingogram showing endometrial tuberculosis.

All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.

questions.text: A patient develops hemolytic anemia following the consumption of fava beans. After a detailed workup, she is found to have a condition that is due to a defect in a metabolic pathway. In which of the following sites does this pathway occur?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of the deficiency of the G6PD (glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) enzyme. It is an enzyme in the pentose phosphate pathway or the hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt pathway which occurs in the cytosol.

G6PD is an enzyme that plays a critical role in redox reactions that occur in all aerobic cells. It is the only source of NADPH in erythrocytes that helps in the formation of reduced glutathione. This reduced form protects erythrocytes against oxidative stress.

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked inheritance disorder. Most patients with this condition are asymptomatic. But when exposed to oxidative agents, they are prone to develop acute hemolytic anemia. The various oxidative triggers include:

  • Fava beans
  • Infections
  • Drugs such as primaquine, dapsone, and nitrofurantoin

A hemolytic attack can present with weakness and abdominal/ lumbar pain. Later, the patient can develop jaundice, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria. Investigations will show elevated levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and low levels of plasma haptoglobin. Acute renal failure is a complication seen in adults.

questions.text:
A male child presents with poor growth. Examination reveals bowing of legs, frontal bossing, and pectus carinatum. The X-ray is shown below. Laboratory investigations reveal that the disease is due to decreased dietary intake. Which of the following would not be seen in this patient?

PTH - Parathyroid Hormone

ALP - Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of rickets and decreased serum PTH would not be seen in this patient. PTH is elevated in rickets.

The clinical vignette describing a child with bowing of legs, frontal bossing, poor growth, pectus carinatum, and x-ray findings showing cupping and fraying of the bilateral distal metaphysis of radius and ulna with growth plate widening are suggestive of rickets. The laboratory findings on rickets would be:

  • Normal/decreased serum calcium
  • Decreased phosphorous
  • Elevated PTH, and
  • Increased ALP levels

Rickets occurs due to a nutritional deficiency in vitamin D. Decreased vitamin D leads to decreased calcium and phosphate due to reduced absorption. The decreased calcium stimulates increased PTH production. ALP level is increased as it is involved in bone mineralization.

Clinical features of rickets include general features such as malnourishment, abdominal distension, proximal muscle weakness, etc.

Head-

  • Softening of the skull bones, called craniotabes. 
  • Delayed closure of fontanells.

Chest-

  • Typical rachitic rosary i.e. widening of the costochondral junctions that give the feeling of rosary beads on palpation.
  • Harrison's groove, a horizontal groove in the lower chest, may appear from the inward pull of the softened ribs by the diaphragm during respiration.

Other bony abnormalities-

  • Vertebral column abnormalities like scoliosis, kyphosis, and lordosis can also appear
  • In the distal extremities- widening of the wrists and ankles, varus/ valgus deformities, windswept deformity (valgus on the side and varus on the contralateral side), anterior tibial bowing, etc

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: A primigravida in her 1st trimester presents with genital prolapse. On examination, the cervix visible outside the introitus is replaced into the vagina and held in place by a ring pessary. What is the ideal time to remove the pessary?

choices.text: At the end of her 1st trimester

questions.solution:
Genital prolapse in pregnancy is treated with the application of a ring pessary which should be kept in place until the 18th–20th week of pregnancy, when the body of the uterus is sufficiently enlarged to sit on the brim of the pelvis.

Patients may present with copious vaginal discharge and a decubitus ulcer may develop if the cervix remains outside the introitus. If the uterus does not rise above the pelvis by the 16th week of pregnancy, there is a chance of incarceration of the uterus.

The symptoms are mostly pronounced in early pregnancy.

There is an increased chance of miscarriage, premature rupture of membranes and chorioamnionitis during pregnancy.

Treatment involves the application of a ring pessary to keep the cervix in place. A ring pessary is also used to treat prolapse in very elderly women who cannot be surgically managed. It is used as an adjunct to pelvic floor physiotherapy. It is also used in puerperium to facilitate involution.

The image below shows a ring pessary.

If the pelvic floor is too lax, the patient is advised to lie in bed with the foot end elevated, and the prolapsed mass is covered with a gauze soaked in glycerine and acriflavine. This is continued until the 18th–20th week of pregnancy till the prolapsed mass is reduced in size and replaced inside the vagina.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of her hands with stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient’s hands is given below. What is the preferred management in limiting joint destruction and disability for her?
questions.solution:
The history and image are typical of rheumatoid arthritis. Methotrexate with anti-TNF is preferred in limiting joint destruction and disability.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown etiology characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. A variation in the HLA-DRB1 gene is known to cause RA. Cigarette smoking is known to increase the risk.

Histopathological features include synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation with inflammatory infiltrates and rheumatoid nodules. These are necrotizing granulomas surrounded by fibrinoid necrosis. 

Clinically, patients present with early morning joint pain and stiffness that is relieved with activity. It mainly involves the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Other hallmark features include flexor tendon tenosynovitis, swan neck deformity, boutonniere deformity, Z-line deformity, and trigger finger. RA is a systemic disease and leads to a variety of extra-articular manifestations, including fatigue, subcutaneous nodules, interstitial lung disease, etc. 

Patients may have elevated ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibodies are helpful in prognosis.

Management comprises non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for pain relief, along with disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs (DMARD). Methotrexate is the DMARD of choice. Hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) is given as an adjuvant in combination with other DMARDs. Biological agents such as TNF-α inhibitors, anakinra, and rituximab are known to reduce the signs and symptoms of RA, slow the radiographic progression of joint damage, and improve physical function and quality of life.

Combination therapy:

  • Methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine (Oral triple therapy).
  • Methotrexate and leflunomide.
  • Methotrexate and a biological such as anti-TNF

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought with loud, raspy, and noisy breathing. His mother also says that his voice has become hoarse over the past 3-4 months. He was born at term through an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The fiberoptic laryngoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of laryngeal papilloma or recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.

It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children. It is caused by human papilloma DNA virus (HPV) types 6 and 11. Squamous papillomas can be seen in children, juvenile papillomatosis (as in this case), and in adults, adult-onset papilloma. 

It is thought that the patients acquire this condition from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus infection during birth. It is usually seen in the supraglottic and glottic regions. Less commonly, the subglottis, trachea, and bronchi may be involved.

Clinically, the patient is typically a young child 3-5 years of age. They may present with hoarseness of voice, stridor, and breathing difficulty. The disease recurs requiring repeated surgical and medical management throughout childhood. Rarely, they may undergo malignant change. 

It is diagnosed using flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and may later be confirmed by direct laryngoscopy or rigid bronchoscopy and biopsy.

Treatment of recurrent respiratory papillomatosis:

  • Surgical management with excision using a CO2 laser
  • Medical management using interferon-alpha has been tried as an adjuvant, but it is associated with significant side effects 

The adult-onset version is usually less severe and does not recur after surgical removal. It affects males more than females and presents between the ages of 30-50 years. 

Other options: 

Option A - Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition of the larynx that manifests at birth and disappears by the age of 2 years. Babies present with stridor on crying that relieves in the prone position. 

The following image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis of laryngomalacia:

 

Option B - Reinke's edema is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. 

The following image shows Reinke's edema:

 

Option C - Vocal cord nodules occur at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cords. This occurs due to vocal trauma that happens when the patient speaks in low tones or high intensities for prolonged periods. 

The following image shows a unilateral vocal nodule:

questions.text: A retired 65-year-old man was found to have a mass in the right lower lobe of the lung on chest x-ray. A  biopsy sample was taken from the mass. The image below shows the findings of histopathological examination and Immunohistochemical staining with calretinin. Which of the following was the most likely profession of the patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing malignant epithelioid mesothelioma (a neoplasm most commonly associated with asbestos exposure) is most likely suggestive of asbestosis. Hence, the most likely profession of this patient would be an asbestos factory worker.

The histopathological image shows cuboidal and flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma. These are strongly positive for calretinin. These features point toward the diagnosis of malignant epithelioid mesothelioma. The most common cancer associated with asbestosis is lung adenocarcinoma; however, mesothelioma is the most specific malignancy.

Malignant mesothelioma is a rare and aggressive malignant tumor of the pleura, associated with heavy asbestos exposure. It arises from either the visceral or parietal pleura. Less common sites include the peritoneum, pericardium, tunica vaginalis, and genital tract. 

Clinical features include chest pain, dyspnea, and recurrent pleural effusions. The lung is invaded directly, and metastatic spread may involve the hilar lymph nodes, the liver, and other distant organs. 

Grossly, it appears as a diffuse lesion arising either from the visceral or parietal pleura. The affected lung is ensheathed by a thick layer of soft, gelatinous, greyish-pink tumor tissue.

The image given below shows the gross pathology of mesothelioma:

Microscopically, they are of three types:

  • Epithelial - shows cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma
  • Sarcomatous/mesenchymal- has a histological appearance resembling fibrosarcoma
  • Biphasic/mixed

The image given below shows an epithelioid type of mesothelioma showing cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma.

The image given below shows malignant mesothelioma under immunohistochemical staining with calretinin.

Other options :

Option B: Sandblasters are at increased risk of developing silicosis. Silicosis is associated with the calcification of hilar lymph nodes, which leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. Histopathology in silicosis shows whorled collagen fibers. HRCT in patients with silicosis shows a characteristic crazy paving pattern.

The image below shows whorled collagen in a silicosis nodule:

 

Option C: Welders are at increased risk of exposure to iron oxide, leading to siderosis.

 

Option D: Coal miners are at increased risk of developing coal workers' pneumoconiosis.  

The image below shows histopathological appearance of coal worker's pneumoconiosis:

questions.text: The muscle marked as X in the image gets its nerve supply from____.
questions.solution:
The short triangular muscle marked in the posterior part of the elbow joint is the anconeus, it receives its nerve supply from the radial nerve.

It arises from the posterior surface of the lateral epicondyle of the humerus and inserts to the lateral aspect of the olecranon and the proximal quarter of the posterior surface of the shaft of the ulna. The anconeus is an extensor of the elbow.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the structure marked with a red arrow?

choices.text: Posterior superior nasal nerves pass through this foramen
It is situated  posterior to the superior turbinate
It is the common site for the origin of an angiofibroma
It serves as a gateway between the pterygopalatine fossa and the nasal cavity

questions.solution:
The structure marked with a red arrow is the sphenopalatine foramen. It is situated at the posterior end of the middle turbinate.

The sphenopalatine foramen serves as a gateway between the pterygopalatine fossa and the nasal cavity. It transmits the following structures from the pterygopalatine fossa to the nasal cavity

  • Sphenopalatine artery
  • Nasopalatine nerve
  • Posterior superior nasal nerves (lateral and medial)

As it transmits the sphenopalatine artery, it is the common site of the origin of the nasal angiofibroma.

  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Identify the image shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shown is Charleston bending brace used for scoliosis.

Charleston bending brace is a commonly prescribed nighttime brace. It is custom-fitted based and is intended to be worn while lying down. It applies lateral force to the spine, pushing the curve closer to the midline and holds it in an overcorrected position. 

Milwaukee brace is used in scoliosis. It is also known as a cervico-thoraco-lumbo-sacral orthosis or CTLSO. It is a back brace used in the treatment of spinal curvatures (such as scoliosis or kyphosis) in children. 

The image shown below is the Milwaukee brace:

 

Reisser's cast is also used in the management of scoliosis. The given image shows Risser's cast.

 

Wilmington Brace is another common TLSO brace custom-fitted based on a cast taken of the patient in the supine position. The brace fits onto the body like a tight jacket, known as a full-contact TLSO. The Boston brace is a snug-fitting underarm brace that provides lumbar or low thoracolumbar support. The difference between the two is that the Wilmington brace is custom-made for each wearer.

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing features of precocious puberty in the presence of an ovarian tumor and elevated levels of inhibin is suggestive of granulosa cell tumor, an estrogen-secreting ovarian tumor. Histopathological image is showing characteristic Call-Exner bodies.

Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The majority of the time it is seen in post-menopausal women. 

These tumors are usually unilateral. In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. The presence of this tumor in prepubertal girls may lead to precocious puberty. The serum and tissue inhibin levels are elevated.

The cut section is soft and has a yellowish reticular or trabecular appearance with interstitial hemorrhage. On microscopy, Call- Exner bodies are seen which are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material recall immature follicles. 

Other options:

Option B: Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor is the second most common malignant ovarian tumor. Schiller -Duval bodies are pathognomonic on histopathology. This structure consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells.

The below image shows Schiller- Duval bodies.

Option C: Psammoma bodies are concentrically calcified structures seen in serous tumors of the ovary but are not specific for neoplasia. 

Option D: Signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. It is the carcinoma of the stomach metastasized to the ovary.

questions.text: The following hysterosalpingogram indicates
questions.solution:
The given image is of a hysterosalpingogram showing the contrast dye filling an irregulary shaped edometrial cavity often described as "moth-eaten" appearance. Hence, it is Asherman syndrome.

The presence of intrauterine adhesions is called Asherman syndrome. Destruction of the basal endometrium prevents endometrial thickening, thus no tissue is produced. Endometrial damage may follow vigorous curettage in association with PPH, miscarriage, or elective abortion.

If intrauterine adhesions are suspected:

  • Radiological evaluation of the uterine cavity is performed.
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) offers information regarding both uterine cavity and fallopian tube patency.
  • Saline infusion sonography can be performed alternative to HSG.
  • Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy as polyps, leiomyomas, air bubbles and blood clots may masquerade as adhesions.

The above image is a hysteroscopic image of intrauterine adhesions found with Asherman syndrome.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy was brought by his parents to screen for thalassemia since both his parents are carriers of the disease. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was performed, and the result is given below. What is the diagnosis?

X-axis: Time (in min)

Y-axis: Analyte concentration (in %)
questions.solution:
The HPLC results show increased HbA2 and normal HbF values, pointing to a diagnosis of thalassemia trait.

β-thalassemia occurs due to mutations causing an impaired synthesis of β-globin chains of hemoglobin (Hb), leading to anemia, hypoxia, and hemolysis. The mutations can be of two types:

  1. Absent β chain synthesis (β0)
  2. Reduced β chain synthesis (β+)

Clinical syndromes of β-thalassemia depending on the genetic defect:

Major: 

  • Severe microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells (typical Hb: 3 to 6 g/dL), requiring regular blood transfusions
  • Crewcut appearance of facial bones and skull (due to cortical bone erosion by expanding marrow and new bone formation)
  • Speen, liver, and lymph node enlargement (due to extramedullary hematopoiesis)

Minor: 

  • More common
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Mild microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells and basophilic stippling (important to rule out iron deficiency anemia by serum iron studies)
  • Mild erythroid hyperplasia in bone marrow
  Major Minor (also called trait)
Genotype

A third clinical syndrome of moderate severity is called β-thalassemia intermedia. The genotype in this type includes milder variants of β+/β+ or β0/β+ and does not require regular transfusions.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of recurrent nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and declining scholastic performance. An X-ray is done which is shown below. Which of the following would not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray showing enlarged adenoids are suggestive of adenoid hypertrophy. Rhinolalia aperta(Hypernasality) would not be seen in this condition, but rhinolalia clausa(Hyponasality) would be seen instead.

Adenoids also known as nasopharyngeal tonsils are prone to physiological enlargement during childhood. Affected children typically present with symptoms of nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, sinusitis, and rhinolalia clausa (loss of nasal tone of voice). They may also experience aprosexia (inability to concentrate) leading to declining scholastic performance. These children have characteristic adenoid facies marked by a dull expression, open mouth, pinched in nose, high arched palate, and crowded upper teeth. 

When symptoms are bothersome, it is removed by adenoidectomy. Otherwise, decongestant nasal drops and antihistamines can be used.

Indications for adenoidectomy:

  • Symptoms like snoring, mouth breathing, and rhinolalia clausa due to adenoid hypertrophy
  • Recurrent ear discharge
  • Dental malocclusion
  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion secondary to adenoid hyperplasia

Contraindications for adenoidectomy:

  • Cleft/ submucous palate: Adenoidectomy leads to velopharyngeal insufficiency in these cases and may cause rhinolalia aperta.
  • Bleeding disorders
  • Active local infection

questions.text: The given image shows the renal handling of glucose. What is the cause of the phenomenon indicated by the parts labeled with question marks in the curves below?

choices.text: All nephrons have the same renal threshold
All nephrons have different transport maximum

questions.solution:
The marked phenomenon in the image is called renal splay. It occurs because all nephrons have different transport maximums (Tm).

For most solutes secreted or reabsorbed, there is a maximum limit to the rate at which the solutes can be transported. This is called the transport maximum (Tm).

In a normal healthy adult, the Tm of glucose is about 375 mg/min. When the filtered load exceeds this value, the tubules will no longer be able to reabsorb glucose. 

The filtered glucose load beyond which glucose starts to appear in the urine is called the renal threshold for glucose. Ideally, Tm and the threshold must have equal values. All the glucose will be reabsorbed by the tubules until the filtration rate reaches 375 mg/min. But glucose appears in the urine before reaching Tm. 

This difference between the threshold and transport maximum is called the splay phenomenon. The physiology behind this phenomenon is that not all nephrons have the same Tm. This leads to the excretion of glucose by nephrons with a lower Tm.

The overall Tm of glucose in kidneys (375 mg/min) is reached only when all the nephrons have reached their respective Tm.

For example, when the plasma glucose concentration is 100 mg/dl and the filtered load (red curve) is around 125 mg/min (normal), no glucose appears in the urine (green curve). But, in patients with diabetes mellitus, the plasma glucose concentration is above 200 mg/min. This leads to a subsequent increase in the filtered load to around 250 mg/min and a small amount of glucose begins to present in the urine.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset severe pain in the abdomen. His mother gives a history of several such repeated episodes of pain in the abdomen, bones, and distal ends of the digits in the past 2 years. He suffered an autosplenectomy the previous year during a similar painful episode. Laboratory findings show unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and significant reticulocytosis. Which of the following is correct regarding his disease?

choices.text: Caused by a point mutation in the alpha globin gene
Heterozygous trait can protect against dengue
Howell Jolly bodies seen on peripheral smear

questions.solution:
The child presents with a history of multiple pain crises, splenectomy, and laboratory findings of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and normocytic anemia. These features point to a diagnosis of sickle cell anemia. Howell Jolly bodies are seen in the peripheral smear of a patient with sickle cell disease.

The below image shows Howell-Jolly bodies:

Sickle cell anemia is an inherited (autosomal recessive) disorder of hemoglobin molecules in which deoxygenated molecules undergo distortion, leading to the classic occlusive crises, hemolytic anemia, and tissue damage. This disease is the result of a point mutation in the beta-globin gene which results in a glutamate residue being replaced by a valine residue. The patients who are homozygous for this mutation present with the above-mentioned features. Those who are heterozygous, are said to have sickle cell trait. This trait can provide a degree of protection against falciparum malaria. This could be because of increases in oxidant stress which can damage the membranes of cells infected by the organism.

Sickle cell disease results in hemolytic anemia with reticulocytosis, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and irreversible sickled red blood cells. These sickle cells can obstruct vessels and cause classic pain crises. These episodes can occur in any part of the body, commonly seen in the abdomen, bones, and chest. Repeated episodes of splenic artery vaso-occlusion can result in a splenic sequestration crises. At this stage it becomes necessary to remove the spleen. This leaves the child even more vulnerable to infections. Appropriate post-splenectomy antibiotic prophylaxis and vaccination should be carried out. In patients who have undergone splenectomy, the peripheral smear can show Howell Jolly bodies, which are basophilic nuclear remnants that would normally be removed by the spleen.

The diagnosis can be confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis and sickling tests.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old G2P1 presents at 30 weeks of gestation with her USG scan, showing a single deepest vertical pocket of 10cm. On examination, her fundal height was greater than the period of gestation. The uterus felt tense, and there was difficulty palpating fetal parts. Fetal heart sounds were normal but auscultated with difficulty. Which among the following could be likely etiologies for this presentation?
  1. Red cell alloimmunization
  2. Maternal pre-eclampsia
  3. Posterior urethral valve
  4. Micrognathia
  5. Esophageal atresia
questions.solution:
An ultrasonography report showing a single vertical pocket of >8cm, with a fundal height greater than the period of gestation indicates polyhydramnios, causes of which may be red cell alloimmunization, micrognathia, and esophageal atresia. (1, 4, and 5)

Polyhydramnios or hydramnios refers to abnormally increased amniotic fluid volume. It is diagnosed when :

  • Amniotic fluid index (AFI) is greater than 24cm
  • The single deepest vertical pocket  (DVP) is greater than 8 cm
  • Amniotic fluid volume is greater than 2L

Other options: Maternal preeclampsia and posterior urethral valve are causes of oligohydramnios. Oligohydramnios is diagnosed when AFI is less than 5 cm or a single deepest pocket of amniotic fluid is less than 2 cm.

questions.text: The image below shows the histology of a normal lymph node. Which of the following sites marked in the image, allows affinity maturation of B lymphocytes?
questions.solution:
B-Lymphocytes undergo affinity maturation in the germinal center (marked as 3) of lymph nodes and produce antibodies.

The structures marked in the above histological section of the lymph node are as follows:

1 - Capsule;

2 - Subcapsular sinus;

3 - Germinal center;

4 - Lymphoid nodule;

5 - Trabeculae 

Histology of lymph node:

Lymph nodes are surrounded by a capsule with a subcapsular sinus below the capsule. Each lymph node consists of a connective tissue framework and numerous lymphocytes of all types which are arranged in a stroma of reticulin fibers and cells to form 3 major regions within each Lymph node:

  • Cortex - It contains subcapsular sinuses, lymphoid nodules, and densely packed lymphocytes. It stains darkly. Each nodule has a paler staining germinal center surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. It contains B lymphocytes and follicular dendritic cells.
  • Paracortex (deeper cortex) - It lacks nodules and has fewer lymphocytes. It is, therefore, lighter homogenously staining. It contains T-lymphocytes and interdigitating dendritic cells.
  • Medulla -  with prominent draining sinusoids adjacent to the hilum. It has less densely packed lymphocytes arranged in medullary cords and macrophages.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the steps involved in the progression of the action potential in a nerve cell.
  1. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus.
  2. Sodium conductance decreases.
  3. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. 
  4. Rapid depolarization occurs.
  5. Repolarization occurs.
  6. The membrane reaches threshold potential.
  7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.
questions.solution:
The sequence of events during the action potential occurs in the following sequence.

1. Resting-state: Both channels are closed

2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.

3. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs.

4. Sodium conductance decreases.

5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.

6. Sodium channels are reset and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the K+ channels remain open and slowly return to the closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.

7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.
