questions.text: A mother brings her 2-week-old neonate with lesions over the body and arms. On examination, thin-walled superficial vesicles are noted as shown in the image below. A disorder of the eccrine sweat gland is suspected. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows clear, thin‐walled, superficial vesicles 1–2 mm in diameter resembling drops of water, without any associated erythema. It is suggestive of miliaria, a disorder of eccrine sweat glands. 

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions, resulting in a leakage of sweat into the epidermis (miliaria crystallina and miliaria rubra) or dermis (miliaria profunda).

Other options: 

Option A: Fox-Fordyce disease or apocrine miliaria is the obliteration of the apocrine duct at the infundibulum.

Option B: Bromhidrosis is characterized by foul-smelling sweat usually due to infection of apocrine glands.

Option C: Milia, also known as “milk spots” are pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts, located over the face usually. They resolve spontaneously without scarring and require no treatment.

Milia and miliaria may sound similar but are actually different from one another. Milia are epidermal inclusion cysts usually located on the face whereas miliaria is a disorder of the eccrine sweat gland and is usually located on the body and arms. The clue given in the question is that the condition is a disorder of the eccrine sweat gland. Hence, the answer is miliaria.

Related Pearl: Different types of miliaria

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions.

Based on the level of blockade it is differentiated into

  • Miliaria Crystallina- Stratum corneum
  • Miliaria Rubra - Malpighian Layer
  • Miliaria profunda - Dermoepidermal junction

Pathophysiology:

  • The first event may be an increase in the skin flora, perhaps with Staphylococcus epidermidis being responsible for producing an extracellular polysaccharide substance or slime that blocks the lumen of the sweat duct.
  • The parakeratotic plugs, a notable feature of the later stages of the disease, are not the primary cause of the obstruction but arise in the repair process, and further aggravate the obstruction.
  • Leakage of sweat into the epidermis is responsible for the final production of the lesions, and for their further aggravation.
  • Miliaria crystallina occurs commonly in infants due to a delay in the development of patency in the sweat ducts.

Clinical features:

  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, thin‐walled vesicles, 1–2 mm in diameter without an inflammatory areola, are usually symptomless and develop in crops, mainly on the trunk. In persistent febrile illnesses, recurrent crops may occur. The vesicles soon rupture and are followed by superficial, branny desquamation.

 

  • Miliaria rubra: Typical lesions develop on the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. The lesions are uniformly minute erythematous papules, which may be present in very large numbers. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation. Relief is often instantaneous when the stimulus to sweating is abolished by a cool shower. In infants, lesions commonly appear on the occluded skin of the neck, groins and axillae, but also occur elsewhere.

 

 

  • Miliaria profunda: This nearly always follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra, and is common only in the tropics. The lesions are easily missed. The affected skin is covered with pale, firm papules 1–3 mm across, especially on the body, but sometimes also on the limbs. There is no itching or discomfort from the lesions.

 

Treatment:

  • First line
    • Control local environment (remove excess bedding, fans, air
    conditioning)
    • Cool the skin (damp compresses, cool showers)
    • Avoid tight or excessive clothing
  • Second line
    • Menthol (e.g. 0.5% menthol in aqueous cream)
    • Topical antibiotics if there is secondary infection
    • Mild topical steroids
  • Third line
    • Removal to cooler climate
    • Prophylactic oral vitamin C

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient who is a known case of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome comes with complaints of severe headache for the past 2 days. She has also had an episode of seizure. Her BP and temperature were higher than normal. What of the following investigation can be used to diagnose her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation likely suggests cortical vein thrombosis, which can be diagnosed by magnetic resonance venography.

It is more common in patients with inherited thrombophilias or antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. Headache is the most frequent presenting symptom associated with or without vomiting, papilledema, or focal deficits. Up to a third of patients have convulsions.

Thrombosis of the lateral or superior sagittal venous sinus usually occurs in the puerperium and is often associated with preeclampsia, sepsis, or thrombophilia.

Often, CT imaging is normal unless an intracranial venous hemorrhage has occurred, but the venous sinus occlusion is readily visualized using magnetic resonance (MR) or CT venography.

questions.text: A researcher was planning to go to a malaria-endemic place for a period of 8 weeks. Which of the following drugs can be taken as prophylaxis before visiting the malaria-endemic place?
questions.solution:
Mefloquine can be taken as prophylaxis by the researcher before going to malaria-endemic places for > 6 weeks.

Chemoprophylaxis against malaria for travelers:

  • If the duration of travel is less than 6 weeks then doxycycline 100mg once a day is to be started 2 days before travel and continued at least 4 weeks after travel.
  • If the duration of travel is more than 6 weeks then mefloquine 250mg once a week is to be started 2 weeks before travel and continued at least 4 weeks after travel.

questions.solution:
The above image shows corneal ulceration (keratomalacia) - a late-stage feature of xerophthalmia. According to the WHO grading, it is graded as X3A.

Xerophthalmia(epithelial xerosis) refers to all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

  • XF – Xerophthalmic fundus – white spots uniformly on the fundus at the level of the optic disc 

The earliest clinical manifestation of xerophthalmia is night blindness or nyctalopia.

Management includes treatment of the corneal ulcer, oral vitamin A, and topical treatment with artificial tears. Topical antibiotics should be given if a secondary infection is present.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of pain and swelling in the penis. He provides a history that there was a popping sound during sexual intercourse. On examination, the penis has the appearance given in the image below. What is the management of this condition?

choices.text: Exploration of penis & repair of tunica albuginea

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of a sudden pooping sound during sexual intercourse with the image showing eggplant deformity of the penis, which is bruised and bent out of shape is suggestive of a penile fracture. The management of this condition is the surgical repair of the tunica albuginea 

Penile fractures occur when the erect penis is bent suddenly. It leads to the rupture of the tunica albuginea. There is extravasation of blood from within the penis. The patient feels a cracking or popping sound followed by pain and detumescence. On examination, there is bruising and penile hematoma. Investigations include ultrasound and MRI. Management includes early exploration of the penis with surgical repair of the tunica albuginea.

Penile fractures are occasionally associated with urethral injuries. Blood at the urethral meatus may indicate coexisting urethral injury. This should be evaluated with either a retrograde urethrogram or cystoscopy at the time of repair.

Other options

Option B: Nesbitt's procedure is performed for Peyronie's disease.

Option C: Orthoplasty is the procedure performed to correct chordee

Option D: Partial penectomy is done in a case of carcinoma of the penis

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes degrade the triglycerides present in the chylomicrons coming from the intestine?
questions.solution:
Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) degrades the triglycerides (TGs) present in the chylomicrons.

LPL is an extracellular enzyme, present in the walls of the capillaries. Although it is present in most tissues, it is predominantly seen in adipose tissue, skeletal and cardiac muscles. It is activated by the apo CII present on the chylomicrons, hydrolyzing the TGs into free fatty acids and glycerol. The fatty acids are either stored in adipose tissues, or used for energy requirements of the muscles. 

LPL synthesis in various tissues is dependent on the nutritional status. In fed state, the insulin levels are high and LPL synthesis is favored in the adipose tissues. In fasting state, LPL synthesis is increased in the muscles. 

When most of the TGs in the chylomicron are metabolized, what remains is the chylomicron remnant. The remnants are removed from the circulation by the liver. Hepatic uptake is mediated by apo E present on the chylomicron remnant. 

Other options:

Option A: Pancreatic lipase degrades the dietary TGs in the small intestine.

Option C: Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) is responsible for degrading TGs in the adipose tissues. When glucagon levels are high, there is an increased release of free fatty acids from the adipose tissues, and the glycerol released along with them is used for gluconeogenesis.

Option D: Hepatic lipase breaks down TGs present in HDL2, converting it to HDL3. It is also involved in degrading TGs in VLDL and chylomicron remnant.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a breast lump for which she has undergone a tru-cut biopsy which revealed a mixed neoplasm with both epithelial and mesenchymal components and leaflike architecture with a low mitotic index. What is the preferred next step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image is suggestive of Phyllodes tumor of the breast, for which the preferred treatment is wide local excision with a 2cm margin, along with overlying skin and underlying pectoralis major muscle, which are excised due to high recurrence rate.

Phyllodes tumor is a type of breast neoplasm commonly seen in women above the age of 30 years. They present as large, freely mobile tumors with an unevenly bosselated surface. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and may undergo pressure necrosis. 

Histology of the tumor is characterised by mixed neoplasm with both epithelial and mesenchymal components with a typical leaflike architecture as shown below. Most of these tumors have a low malignant potential but based on the the mitotic rate, they may be histologically classified as benign, borderline and malignant.  

Treatment of phyllodes tumor is by wide local excision.

Mastectomy is indicated for massive or recurrent tumors, and for malignant tumors (high mitotic index on histology) for which postoperative radiotherapy or chemotherapy may also be offered. Sentinel lymph node biopsy or axillary nodal clearance are not done as they do not spread via lymphatics, but may show hematogenous spread in malignant cases.

questions.text:
Which of the following enzymes catalyze a reversible reaction in the pentose phosphate pathway?
  1. Ribose-5-phosphate ketoisomerase
  2. 6-Phosphogluconate dehydrogenase
  3. Ribulose-5-phosphate 3-epimerase
  4. Transketolase
  5. Transaldolase
questions.solution:
6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase is involved in the irreversible oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway. Transketolase, Transaldolase, Ribose-5-phosphate ketoisomerase, and Ribulose-5-phosphate 3-epimerase are involved in the reversible non-oxidative phase.

The pentose phosphate pathway, also known as the HMP shunt pathway, is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose. It contributes in two major ways:

  • Formation of NADPH for the synthesis of fatty acids and steroids and maintenance of reduced glutathione for antioxidant activity
  • Formation of ribose for the synthesis of nucleic acid and nucleotides

The enzymes for this pathway are found in the cytosol. There are two phases:

  1. Irreversible oxidative phase: Glucose-6-phosphate is dehydrogenated and decarboxylated to form ribulose-5-phosphate.
  2. Reversible nonoxidative phase: Ribulose-5-phosphate is converted back to glucose-6-phosphate.

Clinical significance:

  • Protection against hemolysis: NADPH is utilized for the reduction of oxidized glutathione. Reduced glutathione removes H2O2, thereby preventing oxidative damage to RBCs and hemolysis. Thus, deficiency of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase results in hemolytic anemia.
  • Formation of glucuronate: Glucose-6-phosphate gives rise to glucoronate via the uronic acid pathway. Glucoronate is important as a precursor for proteoglycans and as a conjugate for substances like steroid hormones and drugs for their excretion in bile or urine. A deficiency in the uronic acid pathway results in essential pentosuria.
  • Fructose and galactose metabolism: Fructose bypasses the regulatory step in the HMP pathway and undergoes rapid glycolysis in the liver. This results in the increased fatty acid synthesis and VLDL secretion. Galactose formed from glucose is an essential constituent of lactose, glycolipids, proteoglycans, and glycoproteins. Deficiencies of enzymes in these reactions lead to metabolic diseases like essential fructosuria, hereditary fructose intolerance, and galactosemia.
  • Formation of amino sugars: Amino sugars are formed from glucose and are important components of glycoproteins, glycosphingolipids, and glycosaminoglycans.

questions.text: A young boy presented with sudden-onset painless, rice-water diarrhea with flecks of mucus. He was treated with intravenous fluids and antibiotics, after which, he recovered. However, his stool sample still contains the causative agent, 2 weeks after this episode. Such a carrier is known as:
questions.solution:
A carrier who continues to excrete the causative agent for 2-3 weeks after they have recovered from the illness is known as a convalescent carrier. The clinical scenario of sudden-onset, painless, rice-water diarrhea is characteristic of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae.

An apparently healthy individual excreting V.cholerae in stools is a cholera carrier. The V. cholerae antibody titer is increased and is positive as long as the indivudal harbors the organism.

There are 4 types of cholera carriers:

  • Incubatory/pre-clinical carriers: They are potential patients. They shed the infectious agent during the incubation period of the disease. The duration of their carrier state is 1-5 days (incubation period).
  • Convalescent carriers: Those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence, i.e the patient has recovered from an attack of cholera, continues to excrete vibrios for 2-3 weeks, usually due to ineffective antibiotic treatment.
  • Contact/healthy carrier: Those who had a subclinical infection and developed a carrier state without suffering from an overt disease. Duration is usually less than 10 days.
  • Chronic carrier state is not a frequent phenomenon in cholera but has been documented.

Note: Paradoxical carrier is a carrier who acquired a pathogen from another carrier.

questions.text: The following image shows the sequence of propulsion of a bolus in the gut by means of peristalsis. Which of the following substances is responsible for the configuration of the segment of the gut marked as '2'?
questions.solution:
The given configuration of the segment marked by '2' is due to the vasoactive intestinal peptide being responsible for a state of relaxation of this part of the gut. 

The above image shows peristalsis. It is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen. The given segment of relaxation is an anterograde segment that moves from an oral to a caudal direction. 

Stretching of the gut wall releases serotonin and activates the cholinergic neurons present in the myenteric plexus. Cholinergic neurons passing in an anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus. Cholinergic neurons passing in a retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

The following image shows the events as described.

Note:

In achalasia cardia, there is a defective release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: A mother brings her 9-year-old child with complaints of polyuria. On examination, he has growth failure and bitemporal hemianopia. Laboratory evaluation reveals low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality. Findings on the MRI brain are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with MRI showing intracranial mass with foci of calcification at sella turcica and the laboratory findings suggestive of diabetes insipidus point to a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are tumors that arise from the remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is an intracranial space-occupying lesion. It has bimodal age of presentation. Children usually present with frequent headaches, short stature, bitemporal hemianopsia (due to optic chiasm compression), and polyuria.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid and are compared to machine oil. They also show radiologically demonstrable calcification.

Treatment of central diabetes insipidus caused by craniopharyngioma includes supplementation with vasopressin analogs desmopressin (DDAVP) and resection of the tumor.

Other options:

Option B: Germinomas of the pituitary stalk also cause central diabetes insipidus. However, they are often missed in routine neuroimaging. 

Option C: Pituitary microadenomas usually present incidentally or with endocrine effects. They are <10mm in size and the tumor is confined to the sella. Visual field deficits are usually caused by pituitary macroadenomas. 

Option D: Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare cause of central diabetes insipidus. Symptoms include dermatological manifestations such as red, scaly papules, pain, and swelling in the limbs, characteristic bony lesions, and disseminated lymph node enlargement.

questions.text: A patient with hepatomegaly and polyarthritis involving the joints of the hands underwent a liver biopsy. The results are shown below. Which of the following tests will be the most appropriate for screening other family members?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the slide stained with prussian blue stain point to a diagnosis of hemochromatosis. The most appropriate test for screening the patient's family members would be transferrin saturation.

Asymptomatic and symptomatic family members of the patients should be screened with serum ferritin and percentage transferrin saturation. In the early phase of hemochromatosis, these values will be found to be elevated even before the iron stores are significantly increased in the liver. If serum ferritin and/or transferrin saturation are found to be elevated, the next step is to test the individual for HFE genotype to decide the further management.

In patients with acute inflammatory conditions and hepatocellular necrosis, serum ferritin will be elevated — since ferritin is a positive acute phase reactant. These conditions will not affect transferrin saturation, so it can be considered a more accurate screening method.

Hereditary hemochromatosis is caused by a mutation in the HFE gene, present on chromosome 6p. This mutation causes a decreased synthesis of hepcidin. This in turn causes unchecked iron absorption from the intestinal mucosa, leading to iron overload. The liver is the organ that is affected first and most severely.

Patients present with hepatomegaly and characteristic bronze skin pigmentation due to excess melanin and iron deposition in the skin. Diabetes mellitus and arthropathy involving the joints of the hand, especially the metacarpal joints, are also seen.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman underwent a Pap test, which showed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance, as per the Bethesda system of classification. This is the first Pap test she has undergone. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In a 26-year-old woman with a pap test showing atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance, the next step is reflex HPV testing.

Reflex HPV testing refers to HPV testing that is done in response to a specific result (such as abnormal cytology in this case). It is not performed if cytology is negative.

Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASC-US) is the most common cervical cytologic abnormality. They represent cells that suggest squamous intraepithelial lesions but do not fulfill all the criteria for them. The risk of progression to CIN 2 or 3 is low, but it may occur.

Management of ASC-US:

  • Women aged 21 to 24 years: Repeat cytology in 1 year. If the repeat Pap test result is abnormal, colposcopy should be done. Reflex HPV can be done in this age group. If the result is negative, they are followed up with cytology.
  • Women 25 years and older: Reflex HPV testing.
    • Reflex HPV test result is positive: Further evaluation with colposcopy.
    • Reflex HPV test result is negative: Follow up with a cotest (HPV test+ cytology) in 3 years.

Bethesda system of cytology reporting for squamous cell abnormalities:

    • ASC-US - atypical cells of undetermined significance
    • ASC-H - cannot rule out a high-grade lesion
  • Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL)- includes CIN I
  • High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL)- includes CIN II, III

questions.text:
Identify the imaging modality and the most probable diagnosis for the given image.

DWI- Diffusion weighted imaging

SWI- Susceptibility weighted imaging
questions.solution:
The given image is a susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) and the most probable diagnosis based on it is diffuse axonal injury (DAI).

SWI is a form of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) sequence that is very sensitive to substances that distort the local magnetic field. Compounds with diamagnetic, paramagnetic, and ferromagnetic properties will interact with the local magnetic field and produce distraction. This would lead to a loss of signal in these areas.

Deoxyhemoglobin, hemosiderin, and ferritin are paramagnetic. Bone minerals and dystrophic calcifications are diamagnetic.

The main clinical use is the identification of microhemorrhages/ blood products or calcium that are not detected in other MRI sequences. In diffuse axonal injury(DAI) there are microhemorrhages at the grey-white matter junction which are easily picked by SWI.

Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) is an MRI technique in which contrast within the image is based on the microscopic motion of water. Thus, it is more sensitive to early changes of cytotoxic or vasogenic damage at the cellular level than traditional MRI.

Diffusion gradients sensitize the MR image to the motion of water molecules. Thus, a loss of motion results in restricted diffusion and appears bright on DWI and greater motion produces a darker image. Structures with increased diffusion such as cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) will appear dark on DWI and bright on ADC (apparent diffusion coefficient) maps.

Restricted diffusion on DWI will be seen in the following conditions:

  • acute infarct
  • brain abscess
  • haemorrhage
  • lymphoma
  • epidermoid cyst

DWI is the earliest modality to diagnose acute infarction (as early as 30 min). The image given below shows DWI in acute infarct of the brain:

questions.text: During a psychiatric assessment, patient was asked to explain the sentence, “A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush”. To which he replied, “It’s better to have a bird in the hand than to have two birds in the bush”. This is known as ______________
questions.solution:
Type of thinking was being tested in the above patient. The patient was asked meaning of the proverb, and he could only answer in the literal sense, and not what the proverb actually meant metaphorically. Hence the patient has concrete thinking.

In the given example, if the patient had explained the proverb as, “Things we already have are more valuable than what we hope to get”, then it would be abstract thinking.

Types of thinking:

  • Concrete thinking: It is literal thinking that is focused on the physical world. People engaged in concrete thinking are focused on facts in the here and now, physical objects, and literal definitions.
  • Abstract thinking is the ability to think beyond a single aspect of a situation, showing that they can think of various meanings of a situation, simultaneously. 

Type of thinking is tested by asking the patient:

  1. The meaning of a proverb
  2. The similarities between objects like a table and a chair or between a dog and a lion.

Note: Abstract thinking maybe impaired in schizophrenia.

questions.text:
A primigravida is diagnosed with pre-eclampsia. She presents with a BP of 168/110 mmHg. She is planned to be administered magnesium sulfate following the Pritchard regime. You are an intern in the labor room. How will you prepare the IV MgSO4 for a loading dose?

One vial of MgSO4 has a 2 ml solution containing 1 gram drug.

choices.text: Add 10 vials of MgSO4 in a syringe with no saline.
Add 4 vials of MgSO4 in a syringe with 8 ml saline.
Add 4 vials of MgSO4 in a syringe with 12 ml saline.
Add 10 vials of MgSO4 in a syringe with 8 ml saline.

questions.solution:
A loading dose of IV MgSO4 is prepared by adding 4 vials of MgSO4 in a syringe with 12 ml saline (option C).

In the Pritchard regime, we have to administer 4 grams of 20% IV MgSO4 as a loading dose.

Now, one vial has a 2 ml solution containing 1 gram drug hence concentration is 50%. To take 4 grams of MgSO4, we need 4 vials, but this 8 ml (4 vials × 2 ml) solution has 50% MgSO4.

So, to make the concentration of 20%, we have to add 12 ml saline to the final solution. So we have a total of 20 ml solution with 4 grams of MgSO4 making a concentration of 4/20 = 0.2 = 20%.

Magnesium sulfate is used to treat eclampsia and also prevent it in the following conditions:

  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • Acute rise in blood pressure to a systolic BP > 160 mm Hg or a diastolic BP > 110 mm Hg or both

questions.text: A 6-month-old male child with a cough and cold for the last 7 days is taken to an ASHA worker by his mother. On examination, the child had a respiratory rate of 42 breaths/min and no chest indrawing or grunting.  What would be the next step followed by the ASHA worker?

choices.text: ASHA herself advices for home-based care
ASHA  refers the child to the nearby PHC
ASHA gives the first dose of oral Amoxicillin
ASHA gives the first dose of injectable Amoxicillin and refers to District hospital

questions.solution:
The next best step for the ASHA worker is to herself give advice for home-based care.

The 6-month-old child with a cough and cold for 7 days, having a respiratory rate of 42 breaths per minute and no chest indrawings or grunting is classified as "No pneumonia". According to the latest SAANS guidelines (Social Awareness and Actions to Neutralize Pneumonia Successfully), for a child with No Pneumonia, an ASHA worker on her own will advise Home-based care for the child. 

Home-based care includes:

  • Exclusive breastfeeding for <6 months old child as much as possible.
  • For older children give plenty of oral fluids
  • Home-made soothing cough remedies can be given to children more than 6 months old.
  • Mothers should be taught about the danger signs and report to the ASHA worker or ANM if any danger signs develop.

For classifying Pneumonia, SAANS guidelines of India are similar to the IMNCI protocols of WHO, except it allows ASHA to take the decision for advising Home based treatment as she has been trained for classifying Pneumonia. Also in the SAANS guidelines Chest indrawing is a feature of severe pneumonia, while it comes under Pneumonia in the IMNCI guidelines.

questions.text: A 3-weeks-old infant diagnosed with primary adrenal insufficiency presented with failure to thrive, recurrent vomiting, and hepatosplenomegaly. Radiological imaging shows bilateral adrenal calcification. Enzyme studies revealed a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase. What is the most likely disease in this case?
questions.solution:
An infant with primary adrenal insufficiency with hepatosplenomegaly, recurrent emesis, and bilateral adrenal calcification is suggestive of Wolman's disease. It is due to the deficiency of the enzyme acid lipase.

It is a lipid disorder caused by a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase (chromosome 10) which leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in the most visceral organs. It is an Autosomal recessive disease.

The child presents in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.No specific therapy is available and death usually occurs within 6 months of life.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the pediatrician as shown below. On examination, the mass is painless, soft, and fluctuating. The slip sign is negative.  Which of the following will not form the treatment option for this child?
questions.solution:
A soft, painless, brilliantly trans-illuminant, fluctuating mass found in the posterior part of the neck in a child, is most likely to be a cystic hygroma. Sistrunk operation is not done in cystic hygroma. It is a surgery done for a thyroglossal cyst. 

Cystic hygroma is a lymph-filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development. It is most commonly present in the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. Since the sac is filled with lymph, it is soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly trans-illuminant.

Initially, the treatment includes aspiration of the contents. Later once the sac or capsule gets thickened by fibrous tissue, it is excised.

Single cysts are treated with sclerosing therapy. Commonly used sclerosants include OK–432, which is an inactive strain of group A Streptococcus pyogenes, pure ethanol, interferon alfa-2a, and doxycycline.

Complete excision is done in case of multiple cysts.

  • Meningocele

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with confusion and dyspnea; he was diagnosed with pneumonia. His blood pressure is 128/76 mmHg, and his respiratory rate is 32 breaths/min. His blood urea level is 10 mmol/L. What would be the best management plan for him?

choices.text: Treat as an outpatient with supportive therapy.
Treat as an outpatient with antibiotics.
Admit to the intensive care unit.

questions.solution:
This patient with pneumonia should be admitted to ICU as his CURB-65 score is 4.

CURB-65 criteria are used to assess the severity of illness in a case of pneumonia, especially community-acquired pneumonia.

It includes 5 variables:

  1. C - Confusion 
  2. U - Urea >7mmol/L
  3. R - Respiratory rate ≥30/min
  4. B - Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg
  5. 65 - Age ≥65 years
  • Patients with scores of 0 are considered as low risk and home treatment can be considered.
  • Patients with a score of 1- 2 will require short inpatient hospitalization or closely supervised outpatient treatment
  • Patients with scores of 3-5 have severe pneumonia. It will require hospitalization and admission to the intensive care unit.

The Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI) is another index to assess the severity of illness and the risk of mortality in the case of pneumonia.
It includes 20 variables and depending on the score, patients are assigned to one of the 5 classes:

  • Class, I, II, III - at low risk of death and can be treated on an outpatient basis
  • Class IV & V - require hospitalization

Related Pearl: CURB-65 Criteria

This is a score to determine the severity of pneumonia.

The CURB-65 criteria include five variables(1 point for each variable):

  • Confusion 
  • Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min 
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 
  • Age ≥65 years.

Management:

0 point: Treat as an outpatient

1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital

≥3 points: ICU admission

Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia 

Score - 0: The drug of choice is macrolides.

                     Azithromycin 500mg OD

                                  or

                   Clarithromycin  500mg BD

                                  or

                   Doxycycline  100mg BD.

Score - 1: Treated with azithromycin  500mg OD + ceftriaxone 2gm OD.

               Respiratory quinolones (Levofloxacin) are not preferred.

Score - >2: Azithromycin 500mg OD + Ceftriaxone 2gm IV OD and specific management.

NOTE:- In a modified version of the CURB-65, the criteria of blood urea nitrogen has been removed.

           This elimination removes the need for lab testing.

questions.text: A patient is posted for an ambulatory surgery and the following agent is used for intravenous induction of anesthesia. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the agent shown in the image below?

choices.text: It causes pain on intravenous injection
Increases the risk of post-operative nausea and vomiting
Used as sedation for mechanically ventilated patients

questions.solution:
The anesthetic agent used in this patient for induction is propofol which appears as a milky white liquid as shown in the image. Propofol has antiemetic properties which help reduce post-operative nausea and vomiting.

Its constituents are:

  • 1% propofol
  • 1.2% egg phospholipid (emulsifier)
  • 2.25% glycerol (Tonicity adjusting agent)
  • 10% soya bean oil 
  • NaOH (to change pH)
  • EDTA (bacteriostatic)

Propofol is formulated as a lipid emulsion, which causes pain on injection. A new aqueous prodrug, fospropofol is associated with less pain on injection. Propofol should be handled with sterile techniques as it has a risk of growth of bacteria.

Propofol facilitates the inhibitory neurotransmission by action on GABA-A receptors. It has a rapid onset of action (within 15 sec). Induction dose is usually 1-2 mg/ kg and maintenance dose is 100-200 µg/ kg/ min.

Effects on CNS:

  • It is cerebro-protective. Reduces intracranial pressure and cerebral blood flow.
  • Anticonvulsant properties
  • Has anti-emetic properties at a dose of 10-20mg.

Other effects:

  • Produce hypotension and bradycardia; hence dose reduction is needed in elderly and hypovolemic patients.
  • Produce apnea since it is a profound respiratory depressant. 
  • Anti-pruritic property
  • Propofol infusion syndrome: It is a rare syndrome that can happen when propofol is used for long-term sedation in young patients who are critically ill or underwent neurosurgery. Symptoms include metabolic acidosis, lipemia, and death.

It is the IV agent of choice for

  • Induction of anesthesia for neuro anesthesia and other surgeries
  • Maintenance of anesthesia in patients undergoing cardiac surgery.
  • Sedation for mechanical ventilation and minor procedures in the ICU.
  • Total iv anesthesia (TIVA) and short-term anesthesia for ambulatory surgeries 
  • Malignant hyperthermia

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man was brought to the casualty with the following findings. On examination, about 25% of the body surface showed sloughing. What is the most probable diagnosis?

SJS-Stevens-Johnson syndrome 

TEN-Toxic epidermal necrolysis
questions.solution:
The given image showing hemorrhagic crust and bloody peeling of the lips along with sloughing of 25% of the body surface area is suggestive of overlap SJS-TEN.

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are severe mucocutaneous reactions, usually to drugs, characterized by blistering and epithelial sloughing. The two terms describe phenotypes within a severity spectrum, where SJS is the less extensive form and TEN is the more extensive.

Based on the type of cutaneous lesion and extent of maximal epidermal detachment, the disease is classified as follows:

SJS  <10% Present
Overlap SJS-TEN  10–30% Present
TEN with spots >30% Present

Common drugs that can cause SJS/TEN:

  • Allopurinol
  • NSAIDs - oxicam group
  • Antiepileptics - phenobarbital, phenytoin, carbamazepine, lamotrigine
  • Antibiotics - penicillins, cephalosporins, sulfamethoxazole, sulfasalazine, nevirapine

In 15% of the cases, where the drug cannot be identified, especially in children, lesions appear to be triggered by infections, most notably Mycoplasma pneumonia infection.

The image below shows SJS in the early stages with mucosal involvement.

Other options:

Option B: Erythema multiforme (EM) major is a severe illness associated with extensive target lesions and involvement of the mucous membrane. It usually has a sudden onset. Compared to SJS/TEN, EM major occurs in younger men, has lower grade of fever, and gives rise to milder mucosal lesions. There is no association with collagen vascular diseases, HIV, or cancer.

questions.text: Which among the following options does not depict the type of inhibition shown in the graph?

choices.text: BAL as an antidote for heavy metal poisoning

questions.solution:
The given image shows a Lineweaver-Burk plot of non-competitive inhibition. Among the given options, all are examples of non-competitive inhibition, except methotrexate on folate reductase enzyme, which is an example of competitive inhibition.

Noncompetitive inhibitors bind to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. So, the degree of inhibition is based upon the concentration of the inhibitor, and increasing the substrate concentrations does not compete with or change the inhibition. Therefore, in noncompetitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km usually remains the same. Noncompetitive inhibition is usually irreversible.

Competitive inhibition is when the active site or catalytic site of an enzyme is occupied by a substance other than the substrate of that enzyme, and its activity is inhibited. Competitive inhibition is reversible, and the inhibition is abolished by increasing the substrate concentration. In Competitive inhibition, Vmax remains constant but Km increases.

The Graph showing the changes in Vmax and Km in competitive and noncompetitive inhibition is given below.

  9. Adequately treated

The rule of halves depicts that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries were aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

questions.text: A nephrectomy specimen of a 40-year-old man showed the following histological picture. The tumor cells are positive for CK7. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this type of renal carcinoma?

choices.text: Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct

questions.solution:
The given image is of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (RCC), which is most commonly associated with Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome and not von Hippel–Lindau (VHL) syndrome. VHL syndrome is associated with clear cell RCC.

Chromophobe carcinoma is composed of cells with prominent cell membranes and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, usually with a halo around the nucleus. It shows large cells having a plant-cell-like appearance with a perinuclear halo. They are arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels.

Chromophobe RCC cannot be histologically graded because of its innate nuclear atypia.

Cytogenetic examination of the tumor shows multiple chromosome losses and extreme hypodiploidy. The tumor is thought to grow from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts. It has an excellent prognosis compared to clear cell and papillary cancers.

Close differential diagnoses are as follows:

  • Oncocytoma: Perinuclear halo is not seen.
  • Clear cell RCC: CK7 is diffusely positive in chromophobe RCC which distinguishes it from clear-cell RCC.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male patient came with complaints of wheezing, shortness of breath, and cough for the past 3 weeks. The cough is productive, with brown mucus plugs. He is a known case of bronchial asthma since childhood. Auscultation reveals widespread expiratory wheeze. Chest x-ray of the patient had the characteristic finding shown in the image given below. Which of the following drugs can be given in this condition?

Laboratory findings:

  • IgE >1000 ng/mL
  • Peripheral blood eosinophilia
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of cough, shortness of breath, x-ray showing the finger-in-glove appearance with peripheral eosinophilia, and IgE more than 1000 ng/mL is suggestive of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). Among the given options omalizumab can be used for ABPA.

Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IgE.

Low-dose glucocorticoids (prednisolone 7.5–10 mg) is considered for the prevention of progressive lung damage in ABPA and suppression of the immunopathological responses. Itraconazole 400 mg/day can be used to facilitate a reduction in oral glucocorticoid.  

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is a hypersensitivity reaction involving the major airways. It is most commonly seen in patients with long-standing asthma. It can also be associated with cystic fibrosis. The condition is diagnosed in younger patients usually before 40 years of age. The patient typically presents with atopic symptoms. Sometimes, an expectorant cough with orange mucus plugs may be seen.

Radiographic findings in ABPA:

  • Lobar collapse
  • Non-segmental areas of opacities commonly in the upper lobe
  • Branching thick tubular opacities due to distended bronchi filled with fungus and mucus termed as finger-in-glove appearance 
  • Pulmonary cavitation is seen occasionally

ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of

  • Serum IgE >1000 ng/mL
  • Positive skin prick test in response to Aspergillus fumigatus extract
  • Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies
  • Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL

With the development of ABPA, asthma or cystic fibrosis typically worsens and may manifest with a new or worsening cough or an increase in sputum production or wheezing. Many patients report coughing up thick sputum casts.

The presence of hyperattenuating mucus in the airways is highly specific. While central bronchiectasis is characteristic, some patients can develop chronic cavitary lesions.

questions.text: All of the following conditions may present with the given immunofluorescence pattern in the skin sample except?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a linear pattern of immunofluorescence and can be seen in Bullous Pemphigoid, Cicatricial Pemphigoid, Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita. Dermatitis herpetiformis shows a pattern of focal granular deposits.

Linear fluorescence pattern as shown below occurs due to deposits along the dermo-epidermal junctions (DEJ). This is seen in the following conditions:

  • Due to linear IgG and C3 deposits in Bullous Pemphigoid, Cicatricial Pemphigoid (10% of the cases show this pattern), and Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita
  • Due to linear deposits of IgA at DEJ in Linear IgA dermatosis

Focal granular deposits of IgA at papillary tips seen in Dermatitis herpetiformis.

Fish-net appearance on immunofluorescence is seen in pemphigus vulgaris. It is due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes (Dsg3 > Dsg1), which are present inter-cellularly.

questions.text:
In a patient diagnosed with breast carcinoma, the surgeon decides to do Auchincloss modification of modified radical mastectomy. Which of the following steps are included in this surgery?
  1. Removal of breast
  2. Removal of Pectoralis major
  3. Removal of level 1,2, and 3 axillary lymph nodes
  4. Retraction of Pectoralis minor
  5. Incision of Pectoralis minor
questions.solution:
The steps included in Auchincloss modification of modified radical mastectomy are removal of the breast, removal of level 1,2, and 3 axillary lymph nodes, and retraction of Pectoralis minor. 

Radical mastectomy involves the removal of the pectoralis major along with the pectoralis minor. However, the removal of both these muscles led to a lot of functional impairment with no improved cancer outcome.

Structures removed in modified radical mastectomy:

  1. Whole breast tissue
  2. The skin over the breast tissue
  3. Nipple-areola complex
  4. Pectoral fascia
  5. Levels I, II, ± III axillary lymph nodes

The pectoralis minor muscle is either cut (Patey's, Scanlon's modification) or retracted (Auchincloss). The incision used is an elliptical Stewart incision. 

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

questions.text: A research fellow in biochemistry is studying the lac operon concept of gene regulation. He cultures E. coli. in a glucose deficient and lactose present medium. Which of the following genes expressed in this condition helps lactose gain access into the cells?
questions.solution:
The gene marked as 3 is the lac Y gene which helps lactose gain access into the cells. It does so by encoding for the enzyme, lactose permease.

Lac operon concept

Jacob and Monod studied the Lac operon model which is the regulation of lactose metabolism by the intestinal bacterium E. coli. It is switched on when the bacteria have to utilize lactose for utilization. Otherwise, it is switched off. The genetic arrangement of the lac operon helps coordinate the expression of the three main enzymes (5, 6, 7 below) involved in lactose metabolism. The genes include:

  1. lac I- it codes for the repressor protein that prevents transcription of the distal structural genes, lac Z, lac Y, and lac A by interfering with the binding of RNA polymerase to the promoter.
  2. CRE (cAMP response element)- It is activated by binding the cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP). When activated, it increases the binding of RNA polymerase and increases gene expression.
  3. Promoter site- It is the site where RNA polymerase binds the gene for transcription. 
  4. Operator site- It is the site where repressor protein binds.
  5. lac Z gene- It codes for β-Galactosidase that hydrolyzes lactose to galactose and glucose. 
  6. lac Y- encodes for lactose permease which increases the permeability of lactose into the cells
  7. lac A- encodes for thiogalactoside transacetylase

questions.text: Which of the following tests is a type of ring precipitation test?
questions.solution:
Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test is an example of a ring precipitation test.

The formation of an insoluble antigen-antibody complex when a soluble antigen combines with its antibody is known as precipitation. This occurs in the presence of electrolytes at a suitable temperature and pH. When the precipitate remains suspended instead of sedimenting it is known as flocculation. They may be of different types as follows:

  • Ring test: Antigen solution is layered over a column of antisera. A ring of precipitate is formed at the junction of the two liquids. Examples are 
    • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test used for the diagnosis of anthrax
    • The Lancefield technique of grouping Streptococci
  • Slide test: Flocculation occurs when drops of the antigen and antiserum are placed on a slide and mixed. The VDRL test (Option A) used to diagnose syphilis is an example.
  • Tube test: Serial dilutions of the toxin are added to fixed quantities of antitoxin for quantitative standardization. Kahn test (Option B) is used to diagnose syphilis is an example.
  • Immunodiffusion or Precipitation in gel: Precipitation occurs in a gel such as soft agar by diffusion of the substances through it. It may be divided based on single or double diffusion in one or two dimensions. Elek's gel precipitation test (Option D) used to determine the toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria is an example of double diffusion in two dimensions.

questions.text: How are magnitude of stimulus felt and intensity of stimulus applied related according to the Weber-Fechner law?
questions.solution:
According to the Weber-Fechner law, the magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the logarithm of the applied stimulus intensity.

Other important laws in neurophysiology:

  • Bell Magendie law- The anterior or ventral roots of the spinal nerves are motor and the posterior or dorsal nerve roots are sensory.
  • Law of projection- Stimulation of a sensory system at any point central to sensory organs produces a sensation that is projected at the periphery and not at the point of stimulation.

questions.text: In the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop, which of the following corresponds to the 'c' wave of JVP?
questions.solution:
In the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop, the event that occurs between Points B and C is iso-volumetric contraction, which corresponds to the ‘c’ wave of JVP.

In iso-volumetric contraction, the ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction (systole) and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents iso-volumetric contraction occurring in ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening, during which both the right atrium and right ventricle are in diastole. 

Related Pearl: Cardiac pressure - volume loop

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure(Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

Phase I: Period of filling (between A and B)

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction (between B and C)

Phase III: Period of ejection (between C and D)

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation (between D and A)

where,

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

questions.text: Identify the knot given in the image below.
questions.solution:
The knot given in the image is a reef/square knot.

An image showing standard knotting formations is given below.

The surgeon's knot is a square knot that contains a double turn in the first throw. A "throw" is a complete twist of two strands in the square knot. The double turn makes the first throw of the surgeon's knot less likely to slip while the second throw is being tied. It is used when added security is required. A two-throw technique prevents slippage.

A granny knot is a slip knot which is two throws of the same type. It is used to achieve the right tension and is followed by the reef knot for security. An Aberdeen knot is used for the final knot during continuous sutures.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulliparous woman presented with mild dyspareunia. Examination revealed a non-tender, mobile, fluctuant swelling on the vaginal wall. Ultrasound examination revealed a single cyst of size approximately 2 cm, independent from the bowel and bladder. The cyst arises from the part in the image labeled as A. Structure A is a remnant of what?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of a Gartner's duct cyst, which develops from the Gartner's duct (marked as A), a remnant of the mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct). 

The remnants of Wolffian ducts (Gartner's duct) in females are located in the broad ligament and vagina. It is an imperfect duct that runs below and parallel to the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus until the internal os, after which it passes into the cervix. It then runs forwards, reaching the anterolateral part of the vaginal wall.

Gartner's duct cysts are located in the vagina or broad ligament. They are usually asymptomatic and found within the lateral vaginal wall during a routine examination. Symptoms if present, might include dyspareunia, pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination reveals a tense cyst, seen bulging from beneath the vaginal wall.

Differentials include epidermoid cysts, Bartholin's gland cyst, uterine prolapse, cystocele, rectocele, urethral diverticula.

Treatment is observation in most cases. Marsupialization or excision may be done if large and symptomatic.

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV-positive lady with a CD4+ count of 35/μL presented with decreased visual acuity and floaters. On fundus examination, the following findings were seen. Which of the following is true regarding this patient's condition?

choices.text: Screening is done yearly if CD4 counts <100/μl
Anti retroviral therapy is the mainstay of treatment
Valganciclovir is used as intravitreal implant

questions.solution:
The clinical description of an AIDS patient with low CD4 counts with vision abnormalities and the fundus image demonstrating a pizza pie appearance suggests a diagnosis of cytomegalovirus retinitis. Anti-retroviral therapy is the mainstay of treatment.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis most commonly occurs in immunocompromised states like AIDS, transplant patients, and cancer patients.

Ocular features include reduced vision due to macular involvement, which carries a poor prognosis (Option A). Floaters signify vitritis. One eye is usually affected initially. 

CMV retinitis shows “pizza pie” or “scrambled eggs and ketchup appearance” or “cottage cheese” on fundus examination. It appears as an arcuate zone of retinitis with hemorrhages and optic disc swelling. Often CMV is confined to the retinal periphery, beyond the view of the direct ophthalmoscope. Frosted branch angiitis (FBA) shows marked vascular sheathing. Cataract is a finding in the late stage of the disease.

Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is the mainstay of management, restoring the patient’s innate ability to suppress CMV activity. Valganciclovir is taken orally and Ganciclovir is used as a slow-release intravitreal implant. (Option D)

Screening is done in patients with low CD4 counts once in 3 months if <50/μL, once in 6 months if 50–100/μL, and once a year, if >100/μL. (Option B)

    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)

    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)

    • Salmonella infections, disseminated

    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is bought to the emergency department after being found in a confused state at a bus station in Kerala. He is unable to recall his name, address, spouse's name, or any other personal information. His driving license from his wallet revealed that he is from Bangalore. Further investigation revealed that he got laid off from his job two days ago. He has no history of substance abuse. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of dissociative amnesia with a dissociative fugue. 

Dissociative amnesia is characterized by extensive and severe amnesia with an inability to recall important autobiographical information. The amnesia is predominantly retrograde with minimal anterograde amnesia. It usually follows severe emotional trauma, interpersonal conflicts, and other stressful events, such as sexual abuse, loss of a loved one, loss of livelihood, etcetera. Clinically, the presentation is quite dramatic with significant impairment in social, personal, and occupational functioning. In order for a diagnosis of dissociative amnesia to be made, it is imperative to rule out substance use, and other neurological and psychological conditions that may lead to a presentation similar to dissociative amnesia. 

It is further categorized into the following types:

  • Selective amnesia: Ability to remember some of the events occurring during a circumscribed period of time.
  • Localized amnesia: Inability to recall all events in a circumscribed period of time.
  • Generalized amnesia: Failure to recall one’s entire life.
  • Continuous amnesia: Failure to recall successive events as they occur.
  • Systematized amnesia: Amnesia for certain categories of memory, such as all memories relating to one’s family or to a particular person.

Dissociative fugue is characterized by a sudden, unintended, and unexpected travel to a place away from home, or workplace, or another place involved in one's daily repertoire. It is usually brief, lasting few hours to days, and is generally reversible. It is commonly associated with dissociative amnesia. In addition to amnesia, these patients may also experience confusion, trance-like behaviors, depersonalization, derealization, and conversion symptoms. It may recur in some patients.

It is important to note that dissociative fugue was deleted as a major diagnostic category in DSM-5. It is instead declared as a subtype or specifier of disso­ciative amnesia.

Treatment of dissociative amnesia and dissociative fugue is mainly with psychotherapy. 

Other options-

Option B: Confabulation refers to the unconscious filling of gaps in memory with inaccurate, fabricated, and often implausible information.

Option C: Depersonalization is defined as the persistent or recurrent feeling of detachment from one's self. The patient may report feeling like an automation or like they are watching themselves in a movie.

Option D: Dissociative identity disorder is characterized by the presence of two or more distinct identities or personality states that assume control of an individual's behavior. It was previously called multiple personality disorder. 

Related Pearl: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)
 

ICD-11 classifies Dissociative Disorders as:

  • Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Partial Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Depersonalization-Derealization disorder
  • Dissociative Amnesia
  • Trance Disorder
  • Possession Trance Disorder
  • Dissociative Neurological symptom disorder
  • Secondary Dissociative syndrome

questions.text: You are a new intern posted in the department of ophthalmology. In the case file of a patient who had undergone a total penetrating keratoplasty, you see the ophthalmic examination findings saying that  'Khodadoust lines' are seen. In which of the conditions would you notice this finding?
questions.solution:
Khodadoust lines following penetrating keratoplasty are seen in a case of endothelial graft rejection. Khodadoust lines refer to a linear pattern of keratic precipitates associated with an area of inflammation at the graft margin.

Corneal graft rejection

The corneal graft is immunologically privileged, with an absence of blood vessels and lymphatics and the presence of relatively few antigen-presenting cells. Thus, they seldom are subject to graft failure or rejection. Predisposing factors for rejection include larger grafts >8 mm, infection, glaucoma, and previous keratoplasty.

Patients may have blurred vision, redness, photophobia, and pain. However, many patients remain asymptomatic until rejection is established. Corneal graft rejection can be of four types:

  • Epithelial rejection - elevated level of epithelium is noticed. 
  • Sub-epithelial rejection - usually due to residual adenoviral infection. These form infiltrative opacities called Krachmer spots. 
  • Stromal rejection - these present with deeper haziness.
  • Endothelial rejection - These are characterized by Khodadoust lines. It is the most common form of graft rejection leading to failure.

Stromal edema is indicative of graft failure and the presentation is almost always akin to anterior uveitis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female patient complains of episodic pain on the left side of her face. The pain is triggered when she is chewing or washing her face and lasts for about a minute. There is no sensory loss or autonomic dysfunction. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a middle-aged female with paroxysmal pain in the face, which is triggered by movements and washing of the face, is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. 

Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by excruciating paroxysmal pain in the lips, gums, cheek, or chin. It is commonly seen in middle-aged and elderly women. The pain may occur spontaneously or after movements like chewing, speaking, and smiling. Certain trigger zones are present on the face which provoke these attacks. Tactile stimuli such as washing the face and brushing teeth may trigger the pain. The pain usually lasts for a few seconds to 1-2 minutes.

The large myelinated fibers of the trigeminal nerve carry tactile stimuli from the face but do not carry the pain sensation. In trigeminal neuralgia, compression of the large fibers leads to their demyelination. These demyelinated large fibers become hyperexcitable and electrically coupled with the surrounding smaller unmyelinated pain fibers of the trigeminal nerve. This explains why tactile stimulation of trigger zones leads to pain paroxysms.

Carbamazepine is the first-line drug in the management of patients with trigeminal neuralgia. Lamotrigine, phenytoin, topiramate, or gabapentin are other options that may be tried if carbamazepine is ineffective. Microvascular decompression of the trigeminal nerve can be done if medical therapies fail.

Other options:

Options A, B: Cluster headache and SUNCT are examples of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias. Both of them are characterized by a stabbing type of pain in the periorbital region, along with autonomic features such as lacrimation and conjunctival tearing on the ipsilateral side and nasal stuffiness. Since this patient has no autonomic features, both of these options can be ruled out.

Option D: Temporal arteritis is usually accompanied by manifestations in other systems (such as myalgias) and signs of inflammation (such as raised ESR and CRP). The patient might also have visual disturbances which can lead to permanent blindness. Furthermore, the pain is usually constant and does not have triggers as in the case of trigeminal neuralgia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient who is under the support of a mechanical ventilator in ICU is found to be improving and is planned to be weaned off from ventilatory support. As an anesthetist, you plan to give spontaneous breathing trials using a T-piece. All of the following is a pre-requisite for weaning off except

choices.text: Vital capacity >10 ml/ kg body weight

questions.solution:
Rapid shallow breathing index should be < 105 to wean off a patient from a mechanical ventilator.

Tidal volume is kept ideally at 4-6 ml/kg body weight. A value more than this will cause lung injury.

A patient on mechanical ventilation should be tried to wean off when he can breathe spontaneously and is hemodynamically stable with adequate arterial oxygen saturation.

Additional criteria include,

  • Inspiratory pressure: -20-30cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: 4-6ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: <10 L/min
  • Rapid shallow breathing index(RSBI): <105

Note: Patients with an RSBI of less than 105 can be successfully extubated. Those with an RSBI greater than 120 should retain mechanical ventilator support.

Related Pearl: Mechanical Criteria for Weaning or Extubation

  • Inspiratory pressure: -20 to -30cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: 4-6ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: 10L/min
  • Rapid shallow breathing index: <100

questions.text: A patient came to the ENT outpatient clinic with complaints of hearing loss and sensation of spinning while coughing, lifting heavy weights, and on exposure to loud sounds. He also describes that he is able to hear his eye movements and footsteps. There is a history of trauma a few weeks back. Pure-tone audiometry shows an air-bone gap. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome.

Here, the patients present with autophony (Hearing eye movements and footsteps), vertigo induced by loud sounds (Tullio's phenomenon), and Valsalva maneuvers, or by changes in pressure in the external auditory canal (Hennebert's sign). An air-bone gap in the audiometry represents conductive hearing loss.

Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome occurs due to the third window effect created by the thin/ dehiscent wall of the superior semicircular canal. This causes endolymph in the labyrinthine system to move with sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system. It is usually diagnosed in middle-aged individuals. Etiology may be congenital or acquired from cranial trauma.

Patients present with noise or pressure-induced dizziness. Some may complain of chronic imbalance. As a result, the patient adopts avoidance of noisy environments. Also, some may have gaze-evoked tinnitus or hyperacusis. Nystagmus triggered by sound or pressure, where the eye movements align in the same direction as the exposed semicircular canal, is a characteristic sign.

PTA shows a low-frequency conductive hearing loss. Noncontrast HRCT of the temporal bone can demonstrate the defect, and the condition is usually treated by surgery if there are severe disabling symptoms. Otherwise, conservative medical management is done.

Other options:

Option A: Vestibular neuritis presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sweating, and pallor. There should be no associated cochlear symptoms like hearing loss and tinnitus, neurological symptoms, or signs of brainstem lesions. 

Option B: Meniere's disease (MD) or endolymphatic hydrops is a disorder of the inner ear caused by impaired endolymph resorption. It is characterized by an episodic sudden onset of vertigo, low-frequency hearing loss (in the early stages of the disorder), low-frequency roaring tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the affected ear. Pure tone audiometry (PTA) will reveal sensorineural hearing loss. Hennebert’s sign and Tullio's phenomenon are also seen in cases of Meniere's disease.

Option D: Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which a normal dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause. Patients present with a bilateral conductive type of hearing loss, tinnitus (commonly in cochlear type and active stage), paracusis willisii (better hearing in noisy surroundings than in a quiet place), vertigo, and a monotonous, well-modulated soft speech. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve known as the Carhart's notch.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with gall bladder carcinoma was posted for radical cholecystectomy. Which of the following segments of the liver would be removed in him?
questions.solution:
Segments IVb and V of the liver are removed during radical cholecystectomy.

Cantlie’s line or main portal fissure extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava. It divides the liver into the right and left hemiliver. It contains the middle hepatic vein. The liver has 3 major fissures and 3 minor fissures.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage.

The left lobe is composed of the left lateral segment (Couinaud’s segments II and III) and the left medial segment (segment IV). The right lobe is composed of segments V, VI, VII, and VIII, with segments V and VIII making up the right anterior lobe and segments VI and VII making up the right posterior lobe.

Segment I corresponds to the caudate lobe of the liver and segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe of the liver. Segment IV is divided into segments IVa and IVb. The gallbladder fossa is related to segments V and IVb and is hence removed in radical cholecystectomy.

Gallbladder carcinoma is a rare malignancy that is seen in the elderly. 

Gallbladder carcinoma is indistinguishable from cholecystitis or cholelithiasis. It is usually diagnosed when patients undergo cholecystectomy for gallstones. Its clinical features include right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Jaundice, palpable mass, and anorexia are late features. CA 19-9 is elevated in the carcinoma gallbladder and is used for monitoring.

The preoperative diagnosis is often made on ultrasonography and followed up by a CT scan or MRI/ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography. A percutaneous biopsy under radiological guidance is done for pathological examination. PET scanning helps in detecting metastatic disease. In select cases, a laparoscopic examination is useful in staging the disease. Laparoscopy can also detect peritoneal or liver metastases. The most important prognostic factor is the depth of invasion (T-stage)

Radical en bloc resection is done which includes the gallbladder, wedge hepatectomy (2 cm of the liver in the gallbladder bed or segments IVb and V if there is concomitant liver infiltration), or extended hepatectomy and bile duct resection if the bile duct is involved or the cystic duct margin is positive on intraoperative frozen section.
