questions.text:
Arrange right lung hilar structures from superior to inferior.
  1. Superior lobar bronchus
  2. Pulmonary artery
  3. Principal bronchus
  4. Inferior pulmonary vein
questions.solution:
The right lung hilar structures from superior to inferior:

  • Superior lobar bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

The medial surface of the lung is connected to the heart and trachea by a group of structures that enter or leave the hilum. It is called the pulmonary root. It is anteriorly related to the phrenic nerve, pericardiacophrenic vessels, and anterior pulmonary plexus. The vagus nerve and posterior pulmonary plexus form the posterior relation and the pulmonary ligament the inferior relation. 

The superior vena cava and right atrium are seen in front of the right root and terminal part of the azygos vein superiorly.

The aortic arch is seen superiorly and descending thoracic aorta posteriorly of the left root. The left hilar structures are vertically arranged as:

  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents with dementia and gait difficulties along with episodes of urinary incontinence. Physical examination is notable for magnetic gait. There is no papilledema. An MRI brain demonstrates ventricular enlargement. After a serial lumbar puncture, his gait significantly improves. Which of the following is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The triad of dementia, ataxia, and urinary incontinence, along with the other clinical features and MRI showing enlarged ventricles, is highly suggestive of normal-pressure hydrocephalus. Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting is preferred in this condition.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a reversible cause of dementia. It is caused by obstruction to the normal CSF flow in the cerebral convexity and delayed absorption into the venous system.

Clinical features of NPH triad:

  • ataxia (magnetic gait is described as slow and unsteady turns that are slow, broad-based, and short-stepped)
  • dementia
  • urinary incontinence

Papilloedema is not seen.

Diagnosis: 

  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the sylvian fissures can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy due to the propped open (so-called “boxcarring”) appearance.
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure.
  • Another confirmatory test performed is the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) tap test which shows marked improvement of symptoms with spinal fluid removal.

Treatment: Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting- It is done to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Complications of the shunting procedure include shunt obstruction, infection, intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage, malposition or breakage of the shunt, etc.

Other options: 

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension presents with transient vision loss, headache, and papilledema. Medical therapy includes acetazolamide and furosemide. Topiramate is also used due to carbonic anhydrase inhibitor activity. Surgical therapy includes optic nerve sheath decompression (or optic nerve sheath fenestration) and CSF shunting procedures.

questions.text: Disclosure of which of the following information, without the consent of the patient would be considered a breach of professional confidentiality?

choices.text: Informing the nature of illness of an under-trial prisoner to prison authorities
Informing the school board about diagnosis of tuberculosis in a school teacher
Informing the nature of illness of a convicted prisoner to prison authorities
Informing the warden about a hosteler's venereal disease

questions.solution:
Informing the nature of illness of an under-trial prisoner to prison authorities without the explicit consent of the patient would be considered a breach of professional secrecy or confidentiality.

An undertrial prisoner has the right not to permit the doctor to disclose the nature of his illness to any person. If a person is convicted, he has no such right and the doctor can disclose the result to the authorities.

Professional secrecy is an implied term of contract that a doctor will keep all professional details of his patient as a secret. A doctor must not disclose any details regarding the patient without his/ her consent.

Privileged communication includes the exceptions to the general rule of professional secrecy. According to this, a doctor has a duty to disclose information about a patient, to protect the interests of the community or state. 

Examples of privileged communication include:

  • Infectious diseases to the people in contact
  • Venereal diseases to the sexual partners/authorities in charge of residential areas (hostel wardens etc.)
  • Notifiable diseases, births, deaths to the public health authorities
  • Suspected crime, like murder, assault, or rape to the police
  • Patient's own interest like suicidal tendencies, melancholia
  • Inquiry in a court of law

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of multiple sclerosis comes to the hospital. She complains of blurring of vision in one of the eyes soon after she comes home after her zumba classes. What is the name of this sign?
questions.solution:
The blurring of vision after a physical exercise in multiple sclerosis is Uhthoff's Phenomenon. 

Uhthoff ’s phenomenon refers to the unilateral visual blurring that may occur during a hot shower or with physical exercise. It is an exacerbation of the symptoms of multiple sclerosis due to heat.

Other options:

Option A: Lhermitte's sign is an electric shock-like sensation radiating down the back into the legs. It is induced typically by flexion or other movements of the neck. Lhermitte’s sign can also occur simultaneously with other disorders of the cervical spinal cord like cervical spondylosis.

Option C: Facial myokymia is a persistent, rapid flickering contraction of the facial musculature or a contraction that slowly spreads across the face. It results from lesions of the corticobulbar tracts or in the course of the facial nerve in the brainstem.

Option D: Tic douloureux is the other name for trigeminal neuralgia. It can occur when the demyelinating lesion involves the root entry (or exit) of the fifth cranial nerve.

questions.text:
A diabetic woman who is on metformin presented with abdominal pain and diarrhea. On evaluation, her blood sugar levels are within normal limits. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis report is given below. What is the most likely cause for her ABG findings?
  • pH - 7.24
  • HCO3 - 16 mEq/L
  • PaCO2- 35 mmHg
  • Sodium levels - 130 mEq/L
  • Chloride levels - 94 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The most likely cause for the above ABG findings is lactic acidosis.

This patient has high anion gap metabolic acidosis. This is most probably due to lactic acidosis due to the history of metformin treatment.

Inference from the given question stem:

Step 1: pH in this patient is 7.24, which indicates acidosis. (normal range: 7.35-7.45)

Step 2: Bicarbonate level in this patient is 16 mEq/L, which is decreased. This signifies the deficiency of the base. Hence, this is metabolic acidosis. (normal range: 22-26 mmHg)

Step 3: PaCO2 level in this patient is 35 mmHg, which is normal. (normal range 35-45 mmHg)

Step 4: Anion gap calculation:

Anion gap = Na+ - (Cl-+HCO3-)

=130 - (94+16)

=20, which is a high anion gap

Other causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis:

  • Lactic acidosis
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Ethanol poisoning
  • Salicylate poisoning
  • Methanol poisoning 
  • Renal failure
  • Propylene glycol poisoning

Other options:

Option A- Diabetic ketoacidosis results in high anion gap metabolic acidosis associated with elevated levels of ketone bodies and hyperglycemia (serum glucose level >17 mmol/L or 300 mg/dL). This cannot be the cause in this patient as the serum glucose levels are within normal limits.

Options C and D- Diarrhea and renal tubular acidosis type 1 results in normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents with a fever and right-sided swelling behind the angle of jaw. He also complains of odynophagia and difficulty moving his jaw.  He underwent a molar tooth extraction about three days ago. On examination, the ipsilateral faucial tonsil is displaced medially with mild collapse of the tonsillar fossa. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of a parapharyngeal abscess (anterior compartment type), an infection of the parapharyngeal space.

This space can get infected following infections of the tonsils, adenoids, and parotid glands. It can also occur following dental extractions and penetrating trauma. 

Clinically, patients may present with the following features-

  • Fever
  • Odynophagia or dysphagia
  • Trismus due to irritation of the medial pterygoid muscle
  • The collapse of the tonsillar fossa and tonsil
  • Swelling- Behind the angle of the mandible (in anterior compartment infection), parotid region or area behind the posterior pillar (in posterior compartment infection)
  • Paralysis of IX, X, XI, and XII cranial nerves is commonly seen in infections of the posterior compartment.
  • Features of internal jugular vein thrombosis and carotid artery thrombosis.

Diagnosis can be established using a CECT.

Patients require intravenous antibiotic therapy with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, carbapenem antibiotics plus drugs that target anaerobic organisms, such as clindamycin or metronidazole. A parapharyngeal abscess is drained by an external horizontal incision made on the skin a few centimeters below the angle of the mandible, followed by blunt dissection. 

Other options:

Option B: Retropharyngeal abscess presents predominantly with features of dysphagia and difficulty breathing. Patients may also develop stridor and croupy cough. It is seen as a bulge on the posterior pharyngeal wall, most typically, on one side of the midline, unlike parapharyngeal abscesses. 

Option C: Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy presents with severe pain in the throat, fever (up to 104 °F), chills and rigors, and a “hot potato voice". On examination, a bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil can be seen. Uvula can be pushed to the opposite side.

Option D: Lemierre’s syndrome is thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein and devastating anaerobic bacteremia that follows oropharyngeal infection. It typically presents in children and young healthy adults as severe lateral neck pain and sepsis following prolonged pharyngitis.

The image attached below shows the compartments and components of the parapharyngeal space.

questions.text: A child with an accommodative squint develops strabismic amblyopia and is treated as shown in the image. Identify the affected eye and by what age should it be corrected?
questions.solution:
Occlusion of the normal (left) eye is the treatment of choice for amblyopia. Thus in the given case, the right eye has strabismic amblyopia and it should be corrected before 8 years of age.

Amblyopia is a decrease in vision in one or both eyes with no identifiable abnormality in the eye or the visual pathway to explain it. It may be of the following types:

  • Strabismic - monocular suppression of the deviating eye in case of abnormal binocular interaction and may develop in children with accommodative squint
  • Anisometropic - due to a difference in refractive error between the two eyes
  • Stimulus deprivation - in the case of vision deprivation
  • Bilateral ametropic - high but symmetrical refractive errors
  • Meridional - blurring of vision in one meridian
Treatment of choice:
  • Occlusion of the normal eye (4 to 6 hours/day) using patches.
  • Penalization: Blurring of vision using atropine.

The acuity of an amblyopic eye can be improved in the sensitive period which is usually up to 7–8 years in strabismic amblyopia and maybe longer (into the teens) for anisometropic amblyopia when a good binocular function is present.

questions.text: You are asked to plan a combination therapy for a 60-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is being treated for congestive heart failure. His liver and renal functions are normal and his BMI is within normal limits. Which of the following class of drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Thiazolidinediones should be avoided in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF).

Thiazolidinediones are drugs that act by binding to the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPAR-γ), thereby reducing insulin resistance. These drugs are associated with an increase in plasma volume, weight gain, and hepatotoxicity. They commonly result in peripheral edema and are contraindicated in patients with CHF and hepatic disease. Metformin (biguanides) is also avoided in unstable CHF. 

Oral glucose-lowering agents include:

  • Biguanides: metformin
  • Insulin secretagogues: glimepiride, repaglinide
  • α-glucosidase inhibitors: acarbose
  • Dipeptidyl peptidase inhibitors: sitagliptin
  • Thiazolidinediones: rosiglitazone, pioglitazone

The management of type 2 diabetes mellitus should be initiated with medical nutrition therapy. According to the American diabetes association, vegetables, fruits, low glycemic index foods, and high fiber content is recommended. 

Other options:

Option B: α-glucosidase inhibitors reduce glucose absorption from the GI tract by inhibiting the enzyme that breaks down oligosaccharides. They should be avoided in patients with inflammatory bowel disease. The common side effects include diarrhea, flatulence, and abdominal distention. 

Option C: Dipeptidyl peptidase IV inhibitor, increases insulin levels and decreases glucagon levels. This class of drugs generally warrants a reduced dose with renal insufficiency. Serious side effects include allergy and hypersensitivity reactions like anaphylaxis, angioedema, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

Option D: Sulfonylureas act by increasing insulin secretion. These are recommended in individuals with recent onset of type 2 diabetes mellitus. These drugs are avoided in patients with hepatic and renal dysfunction. Common side effects include hypoglycemia and weight gain.

Other classes of hypoglycemic drugs:

SGLT2 inhibitors: Lead to increased loss of glucose and sodium in the urine. This leads to an increased incidence of urinary and genital mycotic infections and fall in systolic blood pressure.

GLP-1 receptor agonists: They are associated with an increased risk of acute pancreatitis and are avoided in patients with pancreatic disease.

Biguanides: They are associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text:
A plastic surgeon is planning a split-skin grafting procedure. Arrange the following phases in the correct order during the take of the graft?
  1. Neovascularization
  2. Imbibition
  3. Adherence
  4. Inosculation
questions.solution:
The correct order of phases during the take of a split skin graft at a recipient site is: imbibition → inosculation → neovascularization → adherence.

During the first 48 hours following the placement of the graft on the recipient site, the graft survives by getting nourishment from the plasma exudate from the capillaries of the recipient bed. This is known as imbibition or plasmatic circulation. After 48 hours, the cut-ends of the blood vessels of both the graft and the recipient bed align together to form anastomoses. This phase is called inosculation. Neovascularization refers to the in-growth of the blood vessels from the recipient site into the graft. The organization of the graft begins immediately following the placement of the graft due to the formation of a fibrin layer. The graft becomes adherent to the bed by days 10-14.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: You are assessing the drinking water quality in your locality. According to WHO, the safe limit of radioactivity in drinking water is:
questions.solution:
The safe limit of radioactivity in drinking water is alpha activity 0.5 Bq/L and beta activity 1Bq/L.

Radioactivity is the number of nuclear disintegration per unit of time. Its unit of measurement is the becquerel (Bq). 1 Bq = 1 disintegration per second.

These guideline values include both naturally occurring and man-made radioactivity. When it is below the guideline values, the drinking water is considered safe and it does not need any radiological examination.

The variables that are assessed in the drinking water are physical parameters, chemical parameters, biological parameters and radiological parameters. 

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

It describes the cloudiness of water.

  • <4 NTU – measured only by instruments.

TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators:

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci: Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens: They are spore-forming organisms that are resistant to many disinfection methods. They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination. Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts measure a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidence of fecal contamination of water. 

IV) Radiological aspects:

  • The proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity, it is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text: A deficiency of the enzyme which catalyzes the given step will lead to which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
The step marked in the given image, conversion of GM2 ganglioside to GM3 ganglioside, is catalyzed by hexosaminidase A. Deficiency of hexosaminidase A enzyme leads to Tay-Sachs disease.

Tay-Sachs disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder. It is characterized by the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. Clinical features include progressive neurodegeneration, developmental delay, and a cherry red spot on the macula. There is no hepatosplenomegaly, as is seen in Niemann-Pick disease.

questions.text: A man presented with severe pain over his foot after an RTA. Examination revealed tenderness and swelling over the dorsum of his mid-foot. The fracture line is as shown in the picture. Identify the fracture.
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing a fracture of the neck of the talus point to a diagnosis of aviator's fracture.

These fractures most commonly occur following a high-energy injury causing forced dorsiflexion with axial load. They typically occur in aircraft injuries, where the rudder bar is driven forcibly against the foot causing dorsiflexion, and the neck being very weak gives away, leading to fracture.

They can be further classified using Hawkins classification:

  • Type I - Undisplaced
  • Type II - Subtalar dislocation
  • Type III - Subtalar and tibiotalar dislocation
  • Type IV - Subtalar, tibiotalar, and talonavicular dislocation

Undisplaced fractures are managed conservatively in a short leg cast for 8–12 weeks and a non-weight-bearing cast for 6 weeks. Fractures of Hawkins types II-IV are managed by open reduction with internal fixation (ORIF).

Complications include avascular necrosis of the body of talus due to aberrant blood supply and, ultimately, osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills 1 hour after initiating the transfusion. Direct antiglobulin test and plasma-free hemoglobin levels are negative. Antibodies against donor white blood cells and human leukocyte antigens are primarily implicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever and chills during transfusion with no evidence of hemolysis as suggested by the negative direct antiglobulin test/Coombs test and negative plasma free hemoglobin is suggestive of a febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR).

FNHTR is the most commonly occurring transfusion reaction that occurs between 1-6 hours after transfusion. During blood storage, leukocytes release cytokines, which when transfused can cause transient fevers, chills, and malaise without hemolysis.

The image below shows a leukoreduction filter which is used for filtering out donor WBCs.

This helps in reducing the incidence of febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). They also remove microaggregates. 

Selective leukoreduction filters have been developed capable of at least a 3-log reduction of WBCs in blood components. These synthetic fiber filters remove WBCs by a combination of mesh density, chemical attraction, and active adhesion. To meet FDA criteria for leukocyte reduction, all RBC units must have less than 5 × 106 WBCs/U and at least 85% of the original red cell content.

Leukocyte reduction of RBC components is most often performed by blood collection centers within the first few days after collection using an integral or sterilely connected filtration system. Filtration before storage reduces WBC breakdown products in the blood component. The optimum time for performing leukoreduction is before storage, although, a less effective option is to perform leukoreduction after storage, just before transfusion. 

Reduction in leukocytes either by filtration or irradiation equally effective in reducing the incidence of alloantibody-mediated refractoriness, and leukoreduction significantly decreases the rate of alloimmunization compared to those receiving non-leukoreduced products

Potential benefits include reduced risk of: 

  • Sensitization to HLA antigens (important for transplant patients & preventing platelet refractoriness)
  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR)
  • CMV transmission

Management of FNHTR:

  • Stop further transfusion
  • antipyretics like paracetamol
  • Use leukoreduced blood products

questions.text: A 29-week pregnant woman, who was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia, was prescribed oral iron tablets. However, she is unable to comply as she develops epigastric pain, increased vomiting, and constipation on taking this tablet. Which of the following iron preparations can be given in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Iron sucrose is the iron preparation to be given to a pregnant woman with intolerance to oral iron therapy. 

Iron sucrose is the parenteral iron formulation. Other parenteral iron preparations are iron dextran, sodium ferric gluconate, ferumoxytol, and ferric carboxymaltose. Indications of parenteral iron therapy are:

  • Iron malabsorption (sprue, short bowel syndrome)
  • Severe oral iron intolerance
  • Unresponsive to oral iron therapy
  • In patients who are receiving erythropoietin

Iron sucrose is given intravenously and gets split into iron and sucrose by macrophages. The increase in hemoglobin is equivalent to that of the oral iron formulations. The main adverse events of parenteral formulations include hypersensitivity reactions, headache, arthralgia, and urticaria. The patients should be monitored to avoid iron overload.

Other options:

All the other options are examples of oral iron preparations. Common adverse effects include nausea, epigastric discomfort, diarrhea, or constipation.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old male patient presented with acute renal failure. A dynamic radionuclide renography was ordered to assess the renal perfusion. Which of the following radionuclides are preferred?

99mTc-MAG3 - mercaptoacetyltriglycine 

99m-Tc-MDP - methylene diphosphonate
questions.solution:
99mTc-MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) is used for performing dynamic radionuclide renography, to assess renal perfusion.

99mTc-MAG3 dynamic radionuclide renography is the simplest and safest way to assess renal perfusion in patients with renal failure. It helps in differentiating the reversible causes of acute renal failure such as acute tubular necrosis, from conditions like intrinsic parenchymal disease where it is severely impaired or absent.

Dynamic renography:

  • Used to assess split renal function and drainage from the renal collecting systems in suspected obstruction
  • 99mTc-MAG3 is the most commonly used isotope in dynamic renography. Its uptake reflects the tubular function
  • 99mTc-DTPA may also be used. Its uptake reflects the glomerular function and hence, it is commonly used to assess GFR

Indications for 99mTc-MAG3 Dynamic Renography:

  • To find divided renal function and urinary drainage where the collecting system is significantly dilated
  • To find differential renal function following surgery or procedure. Examples: post pyeloplasty or post removal of a double J stent
  • To assess for a urinary leak or possible obstruction following renal transplantation

Other options:

Option A- 99mTc-pertechnetate is used in the imaging of the thyroid, salivary glands, and Meckel's diverticulum imaging.

Option B- 99mTc-sulphur colloid is used in liver/spleen imaging, and prosthetic infection.

Option D- 99m-Tc-MDP (methylene diphosphonate) is used for bone scintigraphy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in Ziehl-Neelsen staining of a sputum sample for diagnosis of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection?
questions.solution:
Decolourising with iodine is not a step involved in Ziehl-Neelsen staining. 

Steps involved in Ziehl-Neelsen stain are:

  1. Place sample on slide evenly spread it with rotational movement
  2. Air-dry the slide and fix it by passing it over a flame
  3. Apply carbol fuchsin stain
  4. Wash with water to remove excess stain
  5. Decolourise with alcohol 
  6. Apply methylene blue stain 
  7. Wash with water to remove excess stain
  8. View under microscope

Kinyoun modified it so that heat fixing is not required, it is called the cold method. It involves increasing the concentration of phenol acid and the duration of staining. It is then washed with water and decolourised with acid alcohol. Counterstaining with Loeffler's methylene blue or malachite green is done for a minute and viewed under a microscope.

The image below shows the steps of Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

The best diagnostic procedure of M. tuberculosis is sputum culture.

  • Sputum microscopy is the most dependable and conventional method for demonstration of AFB(Acid-fast bacteria) by ZN staining method.
  • The smears are made from thick purulent part of the sputum and then are air dried, fixed by heating, and finally stained by ZN technique.
  • The stained smear is examined under oil immersion lens (100). Acid-fast bacteria in a stained smear appear bright red against a blue background.
  • At least 10,000 bacilli should be present per mL of sputum in order to be demonstrable in direct smears.
  • Atleast 300 fields should be examined taking about 10 minutes before giving a negative report.
  • The presence of at least two or more typical bacilli in the smear is reported as positive for AFB (Acid-fast bacteria).

The smears are graded depending on the number of tubercle bacilli present in a stained smear on examination by oil immersion lens.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida with a history of gestational diabetes mellitus is in active labor. After delivery of the head, a positive turtle sign was noticed. Which of the following maneuvres cannot be used for the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The case of gestational diabetes with a positive turtle sign is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. Pinard's maneuver is not used in the management of shoulder dystocia.

Pinard's maneuver is done for frank breech extraction. The middle and the index fingers are placed in the popliteal fossa to abduct and flex the fetal leg. The fetal ankle is then grasped and breech extraction is accomplished as shown below.

Mc Robert's maneuver, Gaskin's maneuver, Rubin's maneuver are all used in the management of shoulder dystocia. 

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or rarely the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively, following the delivery of the head. A positive turtle sign may be seen which refers to a definite recoil of the head back against the perineum. The incidence of shoulder dystocia increases with increasing birth weight, which can be due to maternal obesity, gestational diabetes, post-term pregnancy, and multiparity. Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia:

  • Gentle downward traction of the fetal head with suprapubic pressure 
  • Mc.Roberts maneuver: Flexing the legs on the abdomen with concurrent suprapubic pressure. This causes straightening of the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebrae, rotation of the symphysis pubis toward the maternal head, and a decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination. This tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

Woods corkscrew maneuver: Pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a cork­ screw fashion releases the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

  • Rubin's maneuver: The fetal shoulders are rocked from side to side by applying force to the maternal abdomen. If this is not successful, the pelvic hand pushes the most easily accessible fetal shoulder toward the anterior surface of the chest, producing a smaller bisacromial diameter. This permits displacement of the anterior shoulder from behind the symphysis.
  • Gaskin maneuver: (All fours maneuver): The parturient rolls onto her knees and hands and downward traction against the head and neck is applied, with the attempt to free the posterior shoulder.
  • Zavanelli maneuver: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery.
  • Symphysiotomy: The intervening symphyseal carti­lage and ligamentous supports are cut to widen the symphysis pubis.
  • Cleidotomy: Fracture of the clavicle using an instrument to free the anterior shoulder. Usually done for a dead fetus. (shown below)

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: Under McNaughten's rule, which of the following criteria is not valid to clear a mentally unsound person of all responsibility?

choices.text: Psychiatric illness while committing the crime
Inability to understand that the act is wrong

questions.solution:
The criterion of the presence of uncontrollable impulse is not included in McNaughten's rule. Therefore, it is not a valid criterion to clear a mentally unsound person of all criminal responsibility.

McNaughten's rule is followed by the British Courts of law to examine the liability of a mentally unsound person who has committed a crime. BNS 22 is the Indian adaptation of this rule. 

McNaughten's rule forms the basis of the legal test of insanity/the 'right or wrong' test. It states that a mentally unsound person is cleared of all criminal responsibility for the crime committed if the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of evidence of psychiatric illness.
  • Existence of psychiatric illness at the time of the commission of the crime.
  • Psychiatric illness is of such a degree that the person does not have the ability to understand the wrongness of the act, i.e., impaired intellectual ability. 

McNaughten's rule decide a person's soundness of mind based on the presence or absence of intellectual ability. However, it fails to consider any impairments in the person's emotional state or the presence of any uncontrollable/ irresistible impulses while committing the act.

questions.text: An electron microscopic image showing the skeletal muscle sarcomere is given below. The area marked by the arrow is known as the _____ band and its length _______ during muscle contraction.
questions.solution:
The area marked by the arrow in the electron microscopic image of the sarcomere is the A band or anisotropic band and its length doesn't change during muscle contraction. I (Isotropic) band reduces in length. 

The portion of myofibril that lies between two Z lines is known as the sarcomere. One sarcomere comprises one entire A band and two half-I bands. The various bands of sarcomere are as follows: 

  • A band consists of myosin surrounded by actin filaments
  • I band contains only actin filaments
  • H zone is the middlemost part of the A band which comprises only myosin heads. 

During skeletal muscle contraction, the A band remains constant, Z lines come closer to each other, and the H and I bands reduce in their lengths. 

Related Pearl: Sarcomere

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male patient presented with arthralgia and skin pigmentation. On examination, he was found to have hepatomegaly, arthropathy involving small joints, excessive skin pigmentation with characteristic slate-grey hue, and hypogonadism. What will be the best treatment for this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to hemochromatosis, and the best treatment for this iron-overload state is phlebotomy. One 500-mL unit of blood contains 200–250 mg of iron. Iron removal can be accomplished by weekly or twice-weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL.

With repeated phlebotomy, the following changes occur:

  • Liver decreases in size
  • Liver function improves
  • Hepatic fibrosis may decrease, but established cirrhosis is irreversible
  • Pigmentation of skin decreases
  • Cardiac failure may be reversed
  • Diabetes also improves in about 40% of patients
  • There is little or no effect of arthropathy and hypogonadism. In some cases, arthropathy may even progress, despite therapy.

The goal is to reduce the serum ferritin levels to 50–100 ng/mL. Once the goal is reached, the phlebotomies may be done at appropriate intervals (usually, 3-4 times a year), required to maintain the serum ferritin levels at that level. 

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disease caused due to mutation in the HFE gene on chromosome 6. It is tightly linked to the HLA-A locus on chromosome 6p.

Clinical manifestations are initially non-specific like lethargy, arthralgia, skin pigmentation, and features of diabetes mellitus. The liver is the first organ to be affected, resulting in hepatomegaly, ascites, and spider angiomas. Other systems are also affected, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, congestive cardiac failure, and testicular atrophy. 

Pathogenesis:

The mutated HFE gene on chromosome 6p causes abnormally low levels of hepcidin, which is a principal iron regulatory hormone. This, in turn, leads to increased iron absorption from the duodenum. The excessively absorbed iron is primarily deposited in the parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas; heart; joints; and endocrine organs.

Other features:

  • Hemochromatosis can also be acquired from iron overload due to hemolytic anemia and transfusions.
  • It is associated with an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is the most common manifestation of hemochromatosis. Hemochromatosis can also produce restrictive cardiomyopathy but it is less common as compared to DCM.

Diagnosis: Clinical features, family history, and laboratory investigations directed at diagnosing an increase in total body iron stores using serum iron, transferrin saturation, and serum ferritin levels. Liver biopsy with measurement of the iron concentration and calculation of the hepatic iron index. MRI of the liver is also indicated.

Other options:

Option B- Deferoxamine is a chelating agent, which removes 10–20 mg of iron per day when given parenterally. It is used in cases of severe iron load or when phlebotomy is not well-tolerated.

Options A and D- Trientine and D-penicillamine are chelating agents that bind to copper and are used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child is brought to the dermatology clinic with complaints of reddish-pink nodules on her thighs. The mother is worried about it being a tumor. A sample is sent for histopathological examination and the findings are shown below. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child with reddish-pink nodules and histopathological findings showing large fusiform plump naevomelanocytes(spindled and/or epitheloid naevomelanocytes) is highly suggestive of the spitz nevus (spindle and epithelioid cell nevus), a variant of melanocytic nevus.

A spitz nevus is a melanocytic lesion characterized by spindled and/or epitheloid naevomelanocytes. It is Commonly seen in children as a red-pink nodule, often confused with hemangioma clinically. The classic Spitz naevus usually appears as a solitary, firm, symmetrical, sharply demarcated, round or dome‐shaped nodule of around 5–6 mm in diameter. The color of the lesion is pink to red to reddish brown.

Histologically it can be hard to distinguish spitz nevus from melanoma, they are benign lesions with favorable prognosis. Naevomelanocytic(spindled and/or epitheloid cells) nests are neatly located between keratinocytes, unlike their disorderly arrangement in melanoma.

Melanocytic nevi (moles) are common benign neoplasms caused by acquired activating mutations in components of the Ras signaling pathway.

Based on the location, it may be junctional nevi, intradermal nevi, or compound nevi. 

Other Options:

Option B: Infantile hemangioma is a common benign vascular tumor in childhood. It presents anywhere on the body and is usually not present at birth. They appear red or maroon if superficial, and bluish if deep. They regress by 4 years of age usually. It is shown in the image below.

Option C: Becker’s nevus presents as a hyperpigmented, hypertrichosis patch on the upper trunk and usually begins just before puberty. It is shown below.

Option D- Nevus of Ota is a blue-black macule usually present since birth. Conjunctiva, sclera, and skin supplied by the trigeminal nerve are the most common site involved. They are present throughout life.

The below image shows the nevus of Ota.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with gastroparesis and was prescribed prucalopride. The receptor on which the drug acts is_____
questions.solution:
Prucalopride is a prokinetic agent that is used in the treatment of gastroparesis. Its prokinetic action is exerted mainly through 5-HT4 agonism.

Prucalopride exerts its action across the entire intestinal tract, enhancing the movement of contents from the mouth to the cecum and promoting the passage of material through the colon. It does not impact the rate at which the stomach empties. Prucalopride is prescribed for women dealing with persistent constipation that does not respond sufficiently to laxatives. Typical side effects include nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and headaches.

Other options:

Option A: Chlorpheniramine, loratadine, and cetirizine are H1 receptor antagonists used in the treatment of allergic rhinitis and urticaria.

Option B: Drugs like ranitidine are H2 receptor blockers that are primarily used in peptic ulcers, gastroesophageal reflux, and other gastric hypersecretory states

Option D: Sumatriptan is a 5HT 1B/1D agonist used in the treatment of acute attacks of moderate to severe migraine.

questions.text: A 16 week pregnant female with a known history of seizures is found to have renal angiomyolipoma. On physical examination, white depigmented patches were seen on the back. Prenatal testing was done for the fetus that came positive for the TSC1 gene. The child is at risk of developing all of the complications except.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tuberous sclerosis and the child is not at risk of developing cerebellar hemangioblastoma. 

Cerebellar hemangioblastoma is found in Von-Hippel Lindau syndrome.

Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder that has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

  • Hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules 
  • Facial angiofibromas
  • Periungual fibromas are small fibromas or nodules of skin around fingernails or toenails
  • Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region
  • Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

Other system involvement:

  • Epilepsy, intellectual disability, autism spectrum, subependymal giant cell astrocytomas
  • Cardiac rhabdomyoma
  • Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis
  • Renal angiomyolipomas, renal cysts

questions.text: What is the attached structure in the marked area on the upper-end of the Femur?
questions.solution:
The image shows the femur, and the structure marked is the intertrochanteric crest, to which the Quadratus femoris muscle is attached.

Quadratus femoris: It is a flat, quadrilateral muscle lying between gemellus inferior and the upper margin of adductor magnus, from which it is separated by the transverse branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery. It arises from the upper part of the external aspect of the ischial tuberosity and inserts onto a small tubercle a little above the middle of the trochanteric crest of the femur and into the bone for a short distance below. It may be absent.

Relations: The muscle passes behind the hip joint and the neck of the femur, separated from them by the tendon of the obturator externus and the ascending branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery (which may cause troublesome bleeding if injured during the posterior approach to the hip). The sciatic nerve crosses the muscle posteriorly. A bursa is often present between the muscle and the lesser trochanter.

Vascular supply: Branches from the inferior gluteal artery and from the medial circumflex femoral artery.

Innervation: It is innervated by the nerve to quadratus femoris, L5 and S1.

Actions: It produces lateral rotation of the thigh. Lateral rotation is produced by gluteus maximus, obturator internus, superior and inferior gemelli, quadratus femoris and piriformis, and it is assisted by obturator externus and sartorius. Adduction is produced by adductors longus, brevis and Magnus and by gracilis assisted by pectineus, quadratus femoris and the inferior fibres of gluteus maximus. 

Testing: The short rotators cannot be tested individually, but the lateral rotation of the extended hip and abduction of the flexed hip against resistance test them as a group.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was prescribed a diuretic by a doctor for the management of hypertension. The drug acts on the site 'A' in the given image. All the following are adverse effects of the drug, except ______.
questions.solution:
The site 'A' in the given image represents a distal convoluted tubule. Thiazides act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). The adverse effects are hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypercalcemia.

They block the Na+/Cl- co-transporter in the DCT leading to an increase in Na+ and Cl- excretion. Thiazides are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension. They are also used for the treatment of edema associated with congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome, chronic renal failure, and acute glomerulonephritis.

The advantages of thiazide as an antihypertensive are:

  • It can be given as once a day dose and has a flat dose-response curve
  • Decreased incidence of postural hypotension and relative freedom from CNS side effects
  • No tolerance
  • No fluid retention
  • Decreased risk of osteoporotic fractures due to its hypocalciuric action
  • Low cost

The adverse effects include extracellular volume depletion, hypotension, hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis, hypomagnesemia, hypercalcemia, and hyperuricemia.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (PM POSHAN)?
  1. It is a centrally sponsored scheme that provides one hot cooked meal in Government and Government-aided Schools
  2. It was previously known as Mid-Day Meal Scheme
  3. Provision of hot cooked meals only to preschool children
  4. Targets to reduce stunting, underweight, and low birth weight in children by 4% per annum.
  5. Targets to reduce anemia among young children by7% per annum
questions.solution:
Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (PM POSHAN) previously known as Mid-Day Meal Scheme (Statement 2), is a centrally sponsored scheme that provides one hot cooked meal in Government and Government-aided Schools (Statement 1).

Under the Scheme, there is a provision of hot cooked meal to all preschool children and also to children of classes I to VIII (Statement 3). The scheme is implemented across the country covering all the eligible children without any discrimination of gender and social class. The main objective is to improve hunger and education by:

  • Providing hot-cooked meals in government and government-aided schools.
  • Attend school more regularly and concentrate on school activities.

Statements 4 and 5 are related targets under POSHAN Abhiyaan /National Nutrition Mission( NNM) which is different from Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (PM POSHAN). 

Prime Minister’s Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment (POSHAN) Abhiyaan is a flagship program of the Ministry of Women and Child Development (MWCD), with a goal to achieve an improvement in the nutritional status of children in the first 1000 days of life, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. It targets to reduce stunting, underweight, and low birth weight by 2% per annum (Statement 4). The target for the reduction in anemia among young children (Statement 5), and adolescent girls is 3% per annum.

questions.text: Perl's Prussian blue staining of the bone marrow aspirate of a patient reveals the following. Which of the following is used in the treatment of his anemia?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a ringed sideroblast. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is used in the treatment of sideroblastic anaemia.

Pyridoxine 100 - 200 mg per day for 2-3 months is administered routinely to all cases of sideroblastic anaemia. Blood transfusion and other supportive therapy are also indicated. In cases of secondary sideroblastic anaemia, the primary focus is the removal of the offending agent. However, no definitive treatment is available for hereditary and idiopathic types of sideroblastic anaemia.

Sideroblasts are nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing siderotic granules which stain positively with Prussian blue stain. Based on aetiology, sideroblastic anaemia is classified into hereditary and acquired types.

Hereditary sideroblastic anaemia is an X-linked disorder caused due to a defect in the activity of aminolevulinic acid (ALA) synthetase required for heme synthesis. Affected females act as carriers while males have moderate to marked anaemia and manifest in childhood or during early adulthood

Acquired sideroblastic anaemia:

I) Primary acquired:

  • Also called idiopathic or refractory acquired sideroblastic anaemia
  • Occurs in middle-aged and older individuals of both sexes
  • Due to the reduced activity of the enzyme ALA synthetase, there is disturbed growth and maturation of the erythroid precursors at the level of hematopoietic stem cell
  • Moderate to severe anaemia, which appears insidiously
  • Neutropenia and thrombocytopenia may also be seen
  • Regarded as a myelodysplastic disorder in the FAB classification and thus considered preleukaemic

II) Secondary acquired:

May appear secondary to 

  • Drugs, chemicals and toxins: Isoniazid, Cycloserine, Chloramphenicol, Cyclophosphamide, Alcohol, Lead, etc.,
  • Haematological disorders: myelofibrosis, polycythemia vera, acute leukaemia, myeloma, lymphoma and hemolytic anaemia.
  • Miscellaneous: Carcinoma, myxoedema, rheumatoid arthritis and SLE.

Laboratory findings:

  • Peripheral smear: Hypochromic, microcytic (sometimes normocytic) anaemia
  • Absolute values: MCV, MCH and MCHC are reduced except in acquired type, where MCV is raised.
  • Bone marrow: Erythroid hyperplasia with macronormoblastic erythropoiesis. Marrow iron stores are raised. Pathognomonic ring sideroblasts are present.
  • Serum ferritin: Raised
  • Serum iron: Raised
  • TIBC: Normal
  • Haemoglobin electrophoresis: Normal

questions.text: A manufacturer imports a drug under a name that belongs to another drug. What is this type of drug called?
questions.solution:
This type of drug is called a spurious drug.

As per the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, a drug shall be deemed to be spurious if:

  • It is imported under a name that belongs to another drug
  • It imitates or resembles another drug in a manner likely to deceive
  • The manufacturer name is bogus (labeling a knock-off as a product of an established brand or manufacturing under a fake/ non-existent identity)
  • It has been substituted by another drug or substance wholly or in part

Other options:

Option A: As per the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, a drug shall be deemed to be misbranded if - 

  • It is made to appear of better or greater therapeutic value than it really is
  • It is not labeled in the prescribed manner
  • Its label or container or anything accompanying the drug bears any false claim for the drug

Option B: An adulterated drug is a drug that contains filthy or decomposed substances, substances that are injurious to health, or if the drug contains harmful substances to reduce the quality or strength of the drug. It also includes drugs that are prepared in unsanitary conditions.

Option C: The term unethical drug is not standard terminology in pharmacology. However, the term ethical drug is sometimes used to describe those drugs that are available only by prescription of a medical practitioner.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department with multiple fractures of the face and skull, following a road traffic accident. CT scan showed an intact eyeball with normal intraocular pressure. When light is shone into the right eye, both pupils constrict, but neither pupil constricts when light is shone into the left eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the presence of constriction in both pupils on shining light in the right eye, and the absence of constriction in both pupils on shining light in the left eye is highly suggestive of left optic nerve transection.

In the pupillary light reflex pathway, the afferent is the optic nerve (CN II) and the efferent is the oculomotor nerve (CN III). The afferent limb consists of the retina, the optic nerve, and the pretectal nucleus of the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus. The pretectal nucleus projects crossed and non-crossed fibres to the ipsilateral and contralateral Edinger-Westphal nuclei. This connection forms the basis of the consensual light reflex.

Each Edinger-Westphal nucleus gives rise to preganglionic parasympathetic fibres that emerge with CN III to synapse with postganglionic parasympathetic neurons of the ciliary ganglion to innervate the ciliary sphincter.

In left optic nerve injury (e.g., left optic nerve CN II cut somewhere between the retina and the optic chiasm, thus damaging the left afferent limb, leaving the rest of the bilateral pupillary light reflex pathway intact) the following features are seen:

  • Left direct and right consensual reflexes are lost as afferent signals from the left eye cannot pass through the severed left optic nerve to reach the left and right intact efferent limbs respectively.
  • Right direct and left consensual reflexes are intact as right optic, right oculomotor and left oculomotor nerves are intact.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is diagnosed with a heart condition which has gradually progressed over the last 10 months. On examination, painful nodular lesions are present on the pads of the fingers as shown below. He also gives a history of repeated tooth extraction procedures for dental caries in the last 3 years. Which of the following laboratory results accurately describes the organism involved?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of painful erythematous nodular lesions on the pads of the fingers(Osler nodes) in a patient with a heart condition that has gradually progressed over months is suggestive of subacute infective endocarditis (SABE).

Viridans streptocooci are most commonly associated with SABE in patients who have undergone tooth extraction procedures for dental caries. They are resistant to optochin, bile insoluble, show alpha hemolysis on blood agar and the inulin fermentation test is negative.

Viridans group of streptococci include:

  • Streptococci mitis 
  • Streptococci mutans
  • Streptococci salvarius
  • Streptococci sanguis (causes sub-acute bacterial endocarditis)

Viridans streptococci are normal commensals of the upper respiratory tract. Following tooth extraction or other dental procedures, they are introduced into the bloodstream and implanted on damaged or prosthetic valves causing sub-acute bacterial endocarditis (SABE).

Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the heart valves or the mural endocardium that leads to the formation of vegetations composed of thrombotic debris and organisms, often associated with the destruction of the underlying cardiac tissue. It is classified as

  • Acute - infection of a previously normal heart valve by a highly virulent organism that progresses rapidly.
  • Subacute - infection in previously deformed valves by organisms of lower virulence like  S.viridans, S. epidermidis, HACEK(Haemophilus, Actinobacillus, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, and Kingella) group that progresses gradually over weeks to months. 

Microscopically, the vegetations of subacute IE typically exhibit granulation tissue at their bases indicative of healing

Clinical features include subungual splinter haemorrhages, Osler nodes, Janeway lesions, and Roth spots. 

The image below shows Osler nodes which are painful raised violaceous lesions commonly affecting the fingers, toes, and feet. It is immunologically mediated.

The image below depicts Roth's spots which are exudative lesions in the retina. This is an immunological phenomenon.

The image given below shows Janeway lesions which are faint, red, painless macules on palms and soles. They occur as a result of septic embolization and are not immunologically mediated.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient was diagnosed with extensive AIDS-related Kaposi sarcoma and was started on an anticancer drug given intravenously. She had undergone radiotherapy for breast cancer two years back. She now presents with erythema, desquamation, and local skin reaction on the chest area. Identify the given anticancer drug that is responsible for this reaction.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of radiation recall syndrome and the given anticancer drug is doxorubicin.

In the given clinical scenario, there is the development of local reaction in a previously irradiated area, after 2 years is suggestive of radiation recall syndrome. Intravenous liposomal doxorubicin is used in the treatment of AIDS-related Kaposi sarcoma.

Radiation recall syndrome is an acute inflammatory response confined to the areas that are previously irradiated, which can be triggered by the administration of chemotherapeutic agents. Studies show that the common drugs causing this phenomenon are:

  • Doxorubicin
  • Dactinomycin
  • Docetaxel and paclitaxel
  • Gemcitabine and capecitabine

Radiation sensitization - This is more common than radiation recall. This is a period of enhanced sensitivity in the days after irradiation when the reaction to systemically administered drugs and the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is <7 days. Such reactions can be considered radiation enhancement or sensitization. 

Radiation recall - This is less common than radiation sensitization. When the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is >7 days, months, or even years.

The major side effects of doxorubicin are: 

  • The dose-limiting complication is myelosuppression with maximal leukopenia.
  • Stomatitis, mucositis and alopecia.
  • The long-term toxicity is cardiomyopathy.

Note: Cyclophosphamide when given as a combination with 5-Fluorouracil and epirubicin can cause radiation recall syndrome.

questions.text:
Match the following antiretroviral drugs with their important adverse effects.
Antiretroviral drug Adverse effect
1. Didanosine  a. Hypersensitivity syndrome
2. Abacavir b. Vivid dreams
3. Efavirenz c. Peripheral neuropathy
4. Enfuvirtide d. Injection-site reactions
questions.solution:
The correctly matched options are as follows:

Antiretroviral drug Adverse effect
1. Didanosine c. Peripheral neuropathy
2. Abacavir a. Hypersensitivity syndrome
3. Efavirenz b. Vivid dreams
4. Enfuvirtide d. Injection-site reactions

Didanosine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI). Peripheral neuropathy characterized by pain, numbness, and tingling in glove and stock pattern, and pancreatitis are the most adverse effects of this drug.

Abacavir is also an NRTI. The most serious adverse effect is a hypersensitivity syndrome characterized by fever, maculopapular rash, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal upset, malaise, and fatigue.

Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). Adverse effects are dizziness, impaired concentration, dysphoria, disturbing or vivid dreams, and insomnia.

Enfuvirtide is an entry (fusion) inhibitor. It is the only approved parenteral antiretroviral drug and therefore, injection-site reactions like pain, erythema, and induration are most frequently seen.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient visits the sleep clinic with a history of episodic gasping during sleep. In his evaluation for obstructive sleep apnea, he is asked to fill out a questionnaire to assess his day-time sleepiness. What is the scale used?
questions.solution:
The Epworth Sleepiness Scale (ESS) is used in the assessment of daytime sleepiness.

The Epworth Sleepiness Scale (ESS) a self-administered questionnaire with 8 questions, mentioning 8 activities that are part of the common routine. Respondents are asked to score from 0-3, their usual chances of falling asleep while engaged in these activities. The ESS score (the sum of 8 item scores, 0-3) can range from 0 to 24. A higher score indicates higher daytime sleepiness.

How likely are you to doze off or fall asleep during the following situations?

0 = would never dose

1 = slight chance of dozing

2 = moderate chance of dozing

3 = high chance of dozing

Watching TV 0 1 2 3
Sitting, inactive in a public place 0 1 2 3

Lying down in the afternoon to rest when circumstances permit 0 1 2 3
Sitting and talking to someone 0 1 2 3

The scores are interpreted as follows:

  • 0-5 Lower Normal Daytime Sleepiness
  • 6-10 Higher Normal Daytime Sleepiness
  • 11-12 Mild Excessive Daytime Sleepiness
  • 13-15 Moderate Excessive Daytime Sleepiness
  • 16-24 Severe Excessive Daytime Sleepiness

Other Options:

Option A) The Visual Analogue Scale is used for rating the severity of pain.

Option B) The Hunt and Hess Scale is used in rating the severity of subarachnoid hemorrhage based on the patient's clinical condition.

Option C) The Bristol Scale is to describe the consistency of stool in gastroenterology.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient with a BMI of 42 kg/m² with central obesity is scheduled to undergo bariatric surgery. As preparation for surgery, he is advised to follow a low-carbohydrate, low-fat, and moderate-protein meal, for two weeks. On follow-up, he is found to be non-compliant with the diet. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The next best step is psychological re-evaluation to address the underlying psychological blocks in a patient who is unable to comply with the diet.

Male individuals who are morbidly obese, especially those with central obesity, have large livers that make surgery impossible since the surgeon has to lift the liver to gain access to the stomach. A liver shrinkage diet helps to reduce the size of the liver. This allows mobility for the surgeon and increases the chances of a safer procedure.  

A liver shrinkage diet is one that has a low-carbohydrate, low-fat, and moderate-protein diet. It is started at least 2 weeks prior to the surgery and must be followed strictly by patients who had consented to the surgery. 

When there is no compliance, a psychological evaluation should be done.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with abdominal pain and vomiting. X-ray abdomen reveals characteristic sign as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows rows of several air-filled spaces between the valvulae conniventes of fluid-filled, dilated small bowel loops, giving a ‘string of pearls’ or ‘string of beads’ appearance, characteristic of small bowel obstruction.

Radiological features of small bowel obstruction:

X-ray:

  • On erect X-ray, there may be presence of more than 2 fluid levels within the dilated small bowel loops.
  • Supine X-ray shows a row of gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae conniventes, within fluid-filled dilated small bowels, resembling a string of beads.

Ultrasound:

It can detect fluid-filled loops of the small intestine.

CT:

  • The presence of angulated and tethering of the bowel loops on CT may indicate adhesions, most likely due to a neoplasm.
  • Small bowel ‘feces sign’ may be seen due to the presence of faeces-like material in the small bowel loops proximal to the obstruction. It can occur due to prolonged stasis, and water reabsorption.
  • In simple obstruction, a definite point of obstruction, called ‘transition point’ may be seen, with dilated small bowel loops proximally, and collapsed loops distally.
  • In closed-loop obstruction, a U- or V-shaped configuration of the dilated loops may be seen with a fixed radial distribution.
  • A strangulated bowel represents the incarceration of the proximal and distal limbs of mechanical small bowel obstruction, with subsequent ischemia.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with fever, weight loss, and diarrhea. Several investigations were done, including an intestinal biopsy, which appears as shown below. Which among the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows a non-caseating granuloma. Among the given options, Crohn’s disease is the most likely condition in the given case.

Non-caseating granulomas can be seen in

Granulomas are generally not seen in ulcerative colitis and irritable bowel syndrome. Tuberculous granuloma is an example of caseating granuloma, which has central necrosis with amorphous granular debris and a cheese-like macroscopic appearance. The given image does not show a necrotic center, making it unlikely to be tuberculosis.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with carcinoid syndrome excretes a large amount of a certain metabolite of serotonin in the urine. Which enzyme is involved in the production of this metabolite?
questions.solution:
In carcinoid syndrome, 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) is excreted in large amounts in the urine and the enzyme monoamine oxidase is responsible for its production.

A carcinoid tumor is a tumor of argentaffin cells that produces an excessive amount of serotonin and is characterized by cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. Serotonin is a specialized product of tryptophan metabolism (as shown below).

Urinary metabolites of serotonin in patients with carcinoid syndrome include N-acetylserotonin glucuronide and 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid. 

5-HIAA testing is a 24-hour urine test that is specific for carcinoid tumors. This test is the most common biochemical test for carcinoid tumors associated with carcinoid syndrome.

 Other options:

Option A: Aminotransferase is involved in the conversion of GABA to Succinate.

Option B: PLP-dependent amino acid decarboxylase is involved in the second step of the synthesis of serotonin, where 5-hydroxy tryptophan is decarboxylated to 5-hydroxy tryptamine/serotonin.

Option D: Tryptophan is first acted on by tryptophan hydroxylase in serotonin synthesis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman is being evaluated for post-menopausal bleeding. Her family history is significant for ovarian and colonic cancers. The pedigree chart plotted is shown below. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an endometrial thickness of 16 mm, and a provisional diagnosis of endometrial hyperplasia is established. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is defective in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a woman with endometrial hyperplasia and an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance of hereditary cancer syndromes (colonic and ovarian) narrows down the diagnosis to Lynch syndrome. It is characterized by defective mismatch repair.

Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is an autosomal dominant genetic condition that is associated with a high risk of colon cancer as well as other cancers, including endometrial cancer (second most common).

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

This syndrome is due to defects in DNA mismatch repair genes, with MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2.

HNPCC shows familial clustering of cancers at several sites, including the colorectum, endometrium, stomach, ovary, ureters, brain, small bowel, hepatobiliary tract, pancreas, and skin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about nicorandil is false?

choices.text: It reduces afterload but increases preload.
It is approved for use in patients with stable angina.
It acts as an agonist at ATP-sensitive potassium channel.
Its adverse effects include hypotension and GI ulcers.

questions.solution:
Nicorandil dilates both arterial and venous vascular beds, leading to a decrease in afterload and preload of the heart. 

Nicorandil causes activation of K+-ATP channels. This leads to the hyperpolarization of the smooth muscle cells, leading to vasodilatation. It also has nitrate-like cGMP-dependent action. Adverse effects of nicorandil include headache and hypotension, similar to nitrates. Apart from this, it is associated with GI ulcers and perforations.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with severe retrosternal chest pain, sweating, and breathlessness for the last 20 minutes. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following treatment options is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
The ECG with ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF is suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. The treatment option most appropriate for this patient is percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).

Myocardial infarction (MI) occurs when there is an occlusion of one or more arteries supplying the heart. This leads to an imbalance between myocardial oxygen demand and supply, leading to myocardial ischemia and death. 

Treatment of MI primarily involves control of discomfort, fibrinolysis, and reperfusion therapy. Reperfusion therapy includes both PCI and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). 

In PCI, a stent or balloon is inserted into the occluded artery to restore blood flow. It is done under local anesthesia and mild sedation. In CABG, a vessel is grafted from a different part of the body and is used to restore blood flow by bypassing the occlusion. It is a surgical procedure. CABG is generally preferred for severe left main and three-vessel disease. 

Reperfusion therapy should be done as soon as possible, within a few hours of the onset of symptoms. It has better short-term and long-term outcomes when compared to fibrinolysis alone. 

Other options: 

Option A - Aspirin and ibuprofen are given to patients with acute pericarditis. 

Option B - Cardioversion is done in patients with atrial fibrillation.

Option D - Coronary artery bypass grafting is preferred in patients with severe multivessel disease.

questions.text: In the process of gluconeogenesis, which of the following amino acids does not enter the Krebs cycle via succinyl CoA?
questions.solution:
In the process of gluconeogenesis, phenylalanine is the only amino acid that does not enter Krebs cycle via succinyl CoA. Phenylalanine enters this cycle as fumarate. 

Muscles constitute almost half of our body mass, and hence, amino acids derived from these muscles are a major source of substrate for gluconeogenesis during starvation.

The figure below shows the various points of entry of amino acids into Krebs cycle (tricarboxylic acid cycle). Valine, methionine, and isoleucine all enter in the form of succinyl CoA. 

All gluconeogenic substrates will ultimately form oxaloacetate, as shown below. Oxaloacetate will then undergo the reverse process of glycolysis, resulting in the formation of glucose.

questions.text: A patient was given 200 mg of a drug that follows first-order kinetics. If 75 mg is excreted in 90 minutes, how much drug will remain at the end of 6 hours?
questions.solution:
30.5 mg of the drug will remain after 6 hours.

In first order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. 

75 mg of 200 mg is excreted in 90 minutes

75/200 = 37.5/100 = 0.375 is eliminated 

After 90 minutes; 200 mg-75 mg = 125 mg remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 180 minutes) = 125 x 0.375 = 46.875 mg is eliminated, and 125-46.875 = 78.125 mg remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 270 minutes) = 78.125 x 0.375 = 29.297 mg is eliminated, and 78.125-29.297 = 48.828 remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 360 minutes) = 48.828 x 0.375 = 18.310 mg is eliminated, 48.828-18.310 = 30.518 mg remains after 6 hours. 

A simpler way to calculate 

3/8 fraction is excreted in 90 minutes → 5/8 remains after 90 minutes.

6 hours (360 min) is 4 times of 90 minutes.

So 200 x (5/8)(5/8)(5/8)(5/8) = 30.518 mg remains after 360 minutes

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He underwent immediate amputation surgery of the left lower limb. The postoperative day 2 image is given below. What is the most likely change in peripheral vascular resistance following this surgery?

choices.text: Peripheral vascular resistance is the same
Peripheral vascular resistance cannot be calculated

questions.solution:
The above-given image shows a post-lower limb amputation and the peripheral vascular resistance increases after amputation.

The brain, kidney, muscle, gastrointestinal, skin, and coronary circulations are arranged in parallel circuits. Each tissue contributes to the overall conductance of the systemic circulation. Blood flow through each tissue is a fraction of the cardiac output. It is determined by the resistance and the pressure gradient. Resistance is the reciprocal of conductance.

Amputation of a limb or surgical removal of an organ removes a parallel circuit. This reduces systemic conductance and therefore increases the total peripheral vascular resistance.

Vascular resistance refers to the hindrance to blood flow in vessels. It can be calculated from measurements of blood flow and the pressure difference between two points in a vessel. Blood vessels branch widely to form parallel circuits that supply blood to many organs and tissues of the body. This arrangement permits each tissue to regulate its own blood flow. The total resistance of blood flow is calculated as 1/Rtotal = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3

The total resistance of the parallel circuit will be much less than that of any individual blood vessel. An increase in the resistance of any blood vessel in the parallel circuit will increase the total vascular resistance.
