Necrotizing enterocolitis is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in the newborn period. It is characterized by various degrees of mucosal or transmural inflammation and necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. 

Three major risk factors are:

  • Prematurity is the greatest risk factor
  • Formula feeding
  • Bacterial colonization of the intestine

Incidence and mortality increase with decreasing birth weight and gestational age. It usually presents within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal X-ray. The important signs are :

  • Pneumatosis intestinalis- air in the bowel wall is diagnostic, and corresponds to stage IIA.
  • Portal vein gas is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIB.
  • Pneumoperitoneum indicates perforation and corresponds to stage IIIB.

Perforation is an absolute indication of surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk. questions.text: A father brings his child with a distended abdomen and poor feeding. He has been on a diet consisting mainly of rice water, after being exclusively breastfed till the age of 8 months. Laboratory investigations show markedly low serum albumin levels. Which of the following findings are not consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child with a distended abdomen and poor feeding with low serum protein and albumin is suggestive of kwashiorkor, where simian facies is not seen. Simian facies is consistent with marasmus.

Kwashiorkor is a clinical syndrome seen in severe acute malnutrition (SAM). It is associated with pitting edema and apathy and affects children aged 1-4 years.

Edema is most likely to appear first in the feet and then in the lower legs soon developing into generalized edema. Abdominal distension occurs with or without dilated bowel loops and hepatomegaly with fatty infiltrate.

Skin changes occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled peeling patches with pale skin underneath forming patches of hyper and hypopigmentation called flaky paint dermatosis or crazy paving. The skin gets easily infected.

The image given below shows flaky paint dermatosis seen in kwashiorkor.

The hair is dull, brittle, sparse, and can easily be pulled out. It may lose its curl. Alternating bands of light and normal color hair may be seen, known as the flag sign. Children are miserable, apathetic, and often refuse to eat. There is marked muscle atrophy and growth retardation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old girl enquires if there are any surgical options for the correction of her myopia. She does not wish to wear her glasses or switch to contact lenses. What is the minimum time frame for which her refractive error has to be stable before laser assisted in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK) can be considered?
questions.solution:
The patient's refractive error has to be stable for a minimum period of at least 1 year before undergoing laser-assisted in-situ keratomileusis. (LASIK).

Myopia also known as shortsightedness is a refractive error in which parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused in front of the retina with the accommodation at rest. 

Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is performed using excimer laser. It is the commonly done surgery for myopia. Excimer laser beam reshapes the cornea by ablating the superficial stroma to a predetermined extent after lifting a flap of the cornea with a sharp microkeratome. 

Patient selection criteria:

  • In individuals aged 21 years and above.
  • In individuals who have a stable refractive error for at least 1 year.
  • In individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment.
  • In individuals in whom corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus have been ruled out.

Complications:

  • Tear instability (dry eye)
  • Wrinkling, distortion, or dislocation of the flap
  • Subepithelial haze with resultant glare, especially at night.
  • Persistent epithelial defects.
  • Epithelial ingrowth under the flap.
  • Diffuse lamellar keratitis (sands of the Sahara)
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Keratoconus

questions.text: The image shown below represents which type of mechanical asphyxia?
questions.solution:
The type of strangulation shown in the image is Burking. 

Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim preventing chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands. 

Other options:

Option A: Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow.  Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In mugging, the attack is usually made from behind.

The below image show strangulation by mugging.

Option B: Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened by twisting it with a lever such as a rod or stick within the ligature. Earlier in Spain, garroting was an official method of judicial execution.

 

Option D: In bansdola, one strong bamboo or stick is placed across the back of the neck and another across the front. The victim is squeezed to death by tieing both ends of the stick with rope.

On examination, a bruise can be seen in the centre of the neck across the windpipe corresponding to the width of the stick or the substance used. A similar mark can be seen on the back of the neck if two sticks are used. 

Sometimes two sticks are used across the back and front of the upper part of the chest and squeezed forcibly. This causes laceration of the muscles, rib fractures and interferes with respiration.

questions.text: You are an intern in the OPD seeing a 3-year-old female child with severe disfigurement and photosensitivity. On examination, skin thickening and brownish teeth are seen. Urine examination reveals increased uroporphyrin 1.  What condition is she suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the increased levels of uroporphyrin 1 suggest that she is suffering from congenital erythropoietic porphyria, also known as Gunther's disease.

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria is an autosomal recessive porphyria due to the uroporphyrinogen III synthase defect. It presents with severe photosensitivity from birth, skin thickening, hypo and hyperpigmentation of the skin, and sun-exposed areas prone to infection and disfigurement. Hypertrichosis of the face and limbs may be seen. The skin over sun-exposed areas develops bullae and vesicles which can rupture and get infected. Brownish teeth may be seen due to the deposition of porphyrins. Hemolysis and splenomegaly may be seen.

Laboratory values show increased levels of urinary, fecal, and red cell uroporphyrin 1.

Treatment includes transfusions for treating the anemia, and splenectomy to reduce the hemolysis. Bacterial infections should be treated and protection from sunlight should be done.

Other options:

Option A: Erythropoietic protoporphyria is caused by the deficiency of Ferrochetalase and presents with photosensitivity.

Option B: Hereditary coproporphyria is due to deficient coproporphyrinogen oxidase (CPOX) and presents with abdominal pain, photosensitivity, and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Option C: X-linked sideroblastic anemia is caused by deficient δ-aminolevulinate synthase 2 (ALAS 2) and manifests as anemia.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: A patient posted for surgery suddenly develops shortness of breath, swelling of lips and tongue, and facial swelling in the operation theatre. She was diagnosed with anaphylaxis and was immediately administered adrenaline. Which of the following is the most common cause of anaphylaxis in the peri-operative setting?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of anaphylactic reactions during anesthesia is antibiotics (especially penicillin and cephalosporin).

A careful pre-operative assessment should be conducted to rule out prior allergic events in order to avoid precipitating factors. There should be careful documentation of the history of allergies and adverse drug reactions. 

A distinction should be made between a true anaphylactic reaction and adverse side effects. Past perioperative difficulties may also be reported as drug allergies by the patients. 

Other options: 

Option A - In the perioperative period, opioids are likely to cause nausea. This is an adverse drug reaction. 

Option B - Succinylcholine can lead to conditions like hyperkalemia, masseter spasm, and malignant hyperthermia. If administered to a patient with pseudocholinesterase deficiency, they might experience prolonged neuromuscular blockade.  

Option D - Sulfa drugs like sulfonamide antibiotics, furosemide, hydrochlorothiazide, and captopril also exhibit allergy in surgical patients.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing Doppler ultrasonographic assessment for varicose veins. When the probe was placed inferior to the inguinal crease, the sign shown in the below image was seen on the transverse view in the B-mode. What does it indicate?
questions.solution:
The sign in the image given above is the Mickey mouse sign, which represents the normal anatomy of the femoral vessels.

The Mickey mouse sign is seen on the transverse B-mode of USG.

It includes 

  • Great saphenous vein (GSV),
  • Common femoral vein (CFV), and
  • Common femoral artery (CFA)

Normally, the GSV and CFV lie medial to the common femoral artery, which gives rise to the sign.

Mickey mouse in medicine:

  • Mickey mouse appearance - seen on antenatal ultrasound, due to absent cranial bone/brain and bulging orbits in anencephaly
  • Mickey mouse appearance - seen on MRI in progressive supranuclear palsy
  • The Mickey Mouse sign also represents the configuration of the portal triad - the portal vein, common bile duct, and the hepatic artery on biliary ultrasound.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was admitted to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On examination, paradoxical respiration was seen. His chest X-ray is shown below. All of the following can be done to manage this patient except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of paradoxical respiration and the X-ray showing contiguous rib fractures on the right side are suggestive of a flail chest. All the above measures can be used to treat flail chests except strapping as it impairs chest wall movement leading to hypoxia.

A flail chest usually results from blunt trauma associated with 3 or more rib fractures in 2 or more places. It arises when these injuries cause a part of the chest wall to move independently of the rest of the chest wall. It is diagnosed clinically by observing paradoxical respiration. On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall gets displaced inwards, and on expiration, it moves outwards. They are at higher risk of developing pneumothorax/hemothorax. CT scan is the gold standard investigation.

Management includes oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia, and physiotherapy. Intermittent positive pressure ventilation (IPPV) is reserved for patients developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen

questions.text:
The image given below shows the mechanism of a component of the immune system's first line of defense against infection. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the release of these substances from the cell?

SLE- Systemic lupus erythematosus

choices.text: It results in the loss of nucleus.
It is effective only against bacteria.
It is implicated in the pathogenesis of  SLE.

questions.solution:
The gif shows fibrous neutrophilic extracellular traps (NETs) released from a neutrophil. NETs are mainly effective against bacteria and fungi.

Neutrophilic extracellular traps are networks of extracellular fibers that provide a high concentration of antimicrobial substances at the site of infection and prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils.

Neutrophilic extracellular traps (NET) are the meshwork of nuclear chromatin of neutrophils. The loss of nuclei leads to the death of the neutrophils. They concentrate on antimicrobial peptides and enzymes to fight against bacteria and fungi (not viruses). They are detected in the blood during sepsis. They are produced by neutrophils in response to

  • Infectious pathogens: mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators: chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

Note: The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, which includes histones and associated DNA, has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text:
During your labor room postings, you perform a cardiotocography (CTG) on a woman who is in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. The tracing that you obtain is as shown in the image below. Which among the following may cause this finding?
  1. Placental abruption
  2. Excessive use of oxytocin
  3. Epidural anesthesia
  4. Fetal head compression
  5. Umbilical cord compression
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows late decelerations. The fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Causes of late decelerations:

  • Placental pathologies like - post-maturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

The CTG given below shows early decelerations. The deceleration coincides with the uterine contractions. It seen in fetal head compression.

The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A 26-year-old lady with G2P1L1 at 34 weeks of gestation came for a regular check-up. On examination, her fundal height corresponds to 28 weeks of gestation. Doppler scan was done and showed the following flow pattern of umbilical arteries. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given flow pattern of umbilical arteries represents an absence of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical arteries, leading to a diagnosis of intrauterine growth restriction.

Other common flow patterns are shown below-

(a): Normal diastolic flow.

(b): Absence of end-diastolic flow seen in IUGR.

(c): Reversal of end-diastolic flow seen in impending IUD.

Umbilical artery vessels:

Characterised by forward, low resistance flow.
As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the resistance indices, so the amount of forward diastolic flow increases.
S/D ratio decreases as the period of gestation increases.

Abnormal flow patterns in umbilical artery:

Reduced End diastolic flow: Uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases)
Absent End diastolic flow: Fetal compromise (hence terminate the pregnancy by cesarean section if >34 weeks)
Reverse end diastolic flow: Impending doom of death (terminate pregnancy irrespective of gestational age)

Middle cerebral artery:

This will show increased diastolic velocity in fetus with hypoxemia.

questions.text:
A female patient diagnosed with parathyroid adenoma was posted for parathyroidectomy. After the removal of the gland, her intra-operative PTH level was measured and is shown in the graph below. What is the next step in management?

PTH- Parathyroid hormone

Normal Range of PTH - 10-65 pg/mL

choices.text: Autotransplant the parathyroid tissue in the forearm.
Check the level of PTH again.

questions.solution:
The graph shows the values of PTH before and after the excision of the gland. Here the values have dropped from 142 (Pre-incision) to 25 (10 minutes post-excision). The drop indicates a fall of the values into the normal range and to less than half the maximum preoperative PTH levels, indicating that it is likely to be a single-gland disease as per the Miami criteria. Hence, no further surgical intervention is required.

The Miami criteria were developed to ensure the adequacy of resection in parathyroid surgery. It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to the normal range and to less than half the maximum preoperative PTH at 10 minutes.

Most of the patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have a single adenoma and therefore undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy, where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed through an incision less than 3 cm. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure no other hyperactive gland remains by performing an intraoperative PTH assay which is interpreted based on the Miami criteria.

However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration. At times during bilateral neck exploration, all four glands are removed and a forearm autotransplant of parathyroid tissue in the brachioradialis muscle is done.

questions.text: A 57-year-old lady presented with complaints of dyspareunia and vaginal spotting, despite attaining menopause 3 years back. She has no other complaints, is not on any medications, and has no family history of carcinomas. On examination, the vagina appeared pale with small petechiae. Transvaginal ultrasound revealed a 3 mm thick endometrium with no abnormality. Which among the following would be an appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of atrophic vaginitis, which should be managed with topical estrogen, the estradiol-releasing vaginal ring being the best answer among the given options.

Atrophic vaginitis is a common cause of post-menopausal bleeding due to low estradiol levels resulting in friability. Patients may present with dry vagina; dyspareunia; and a purulent, often slightly blood-tinged, discharge. The vagina appears pale, dry, and may contain petechiae. These symptoms are part of a constellation of signs and symptoms described under genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM).

Treatment of atrophic vaginitis involves topical estrogens in the form of creams, tablets, or rings. Estrogen replacement restores vaginal mucosal elasticity, vaginal fluid secretion levels, blood flow, and sensorimotor responses.

Options include

  • Conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally 
  • A continuous low-dose estradiol-releasing vaginal ring containing 2 mg estradiol 
  • A 10 μg 17β-estradiol tablet intravaginally
  • An oral estrogen may be considered for maintenance therapy
  • Vaginal lubricants and moisturizers may also provide symptomatic relief.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

Other options:

Option A: Pipelle biopsy is done if the endometrial thickness is >4 mm on the transvaginal sonogram.

Option C: Mirena intrauterine device (IUD) or levonorgestrel IUD is effective if there is endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. It is also used to control abnormal uterine bleeding in the reproductive age group and is an effective method of contraception. 

Option D: Hysteroscopy is generally performed if pipelle biopsy does not yield an adequate result or cannot be passed.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient presents with amenorrhea and galactorrhea. She has been trying to conceive for the past two years. Her UPT is negative and she is not on any medications. Serum prolactin is found to be elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate next step for this patient is to measure serum TSH, T3, and T4, because hypothyroidism should be ruled out in any patient with hyperprolactinemia before starting an extensive diagnostic workup.

Amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and infertility are the characteristic features of hyperprolactinemia in females. In males, hyperprolactinemia presents with diminished libido, visual loss (due to compression of the optic tract), and infertility. 

In any patient presenting with hyperprolactinemia, the physician must always rule out physiological causes (pregnancy, lactation), hypothyroidism, and a history of use of drugs associated with hyperprolactinemia. Low thyroxine in patients with hypothyroidism causes increased TRH release from the hypothalamus. TRH induces prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary. 

Once these causes have been ruled out, the next step is to do an MRI of the brain to identify a functional pituitary tumor, that is, a prolactinoma. A microadenoma is a pituitary tumor of size < 10 mm. If the size is ≥ 10 mm, it is termed a macroadenoma. Macroadenomas are more likely to cause visual symptoms.

Initial management for both is dopamine agonists, such as cabergoline. It successfully reduces prolactin levels, improves fertility, and causes a shrinkage of the tumor. Bromocriptine is another dopamine agonist used in the management of prolactinoma, especially in pregnant patients. If there is no reduction in the size of the tumors, or there is persistent tumor growth or persistent hyperprolactinemia, surgery is considered.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presented with right-sided flank pain which radiates to the groin. She also reports nausea and one episode of vomiting. Her X-Ray abdomen is shown below. She has been on regular medication for a seizure disorder. Which of the following drugs can be implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing acute symptoms of right flank pain radiating to the groin along with bilateral stones in the abdominal x-ray makes renal calculi a likely diagnosis, which is commonly associated with the antiepileptic drug Topiramate.

Acute renal colic presents with sudden onset of severe pain originating in the flank and radiating inferiorly and anteriorly. At least half the patients will also present with nausea and vomiting. Patients with renal calculi may report infection or hematuria.

Topiramate is an anti-epileptic that can be used as initial mono-drug therapy for 

  • Focal seizures
  • GTCS
  • Lennox-Gastaut syndrome in patients ≥ 2 years 

Mechanism of action: Topiramate acts by

  • Reducing voltage-gated Na+ currents 
  • Activating a hyperpolarizing K+ current
  • Enhancing postsynaptic GABAA receptor currents
  • Limiting the activation of glutamate receptors. 

The drug is also a weak inhibitor of renal carbonic anhydrase and can lead to metabolic acidosis. Metabolic acidosis causes hypocitraturia and hypercalciuria that increase urinary saturation and predispose to the formation of renal calculi.

Other options :

Option A: Ezogabine causes urinary retention and blue pigmentation of the skin.

Option C: Vigabatrin causes bilateral vision loss and a contraction of the visual field.

Option D: Oxcarbazepine causes side effects similar to carbamazepine which include hyponatremia and Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presented with multiple swellings on the neck and a few discharging sinuses. The histopathological examination of the swellings was as shown below. Which of the following cells does not play a role in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the slide showing granulomatous inflammation with central caseous necrosis are suggestive of tuberculosis of cervical lymph nodes. Neutrophils are associated with acute inflammation and are not involved in the pathogenesis of tuberculosis.

Once Mycobacterium tuberculosis enters the macrophage, it inhibits the formation of the phagolysosome. This allows it to replicate unchecked. M. tuberculosis recruits a host protein coronin to block the fusion of phagosome and lysosome. Th1 response to M. tuberculosis is mounted about three weeks following the infection. The antigen-presenting cells (APCs) present mycobacterial antigens to the T-cells in the lymph nodes and release IL-12 and IL-18 to cause the differentiation of T-cells into Th1 cells (option B).

Th1 cells produce IFN-γ. IFN-γ is the critical step in the body's defense against M. tuberculosis. It acts by activating macrophages (option C), causing maturation of phagolysosome, and inducing nitric oxide synthase enzyme to form more reactive nitrogen species. It also mobilizes anti-bacterial compounds like defensins and stimulates autophagy.

Th1 response leads to the formation of a granuloma and caseous necrosis. Macrophages that are activated by the action of IFN-γ differentiate into epithelioid histiocytes (option D). These are the cells that actually aggregate to form a granuloma. Some epithelioid cells may also fuse to form a giant cell.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops acute pain abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. The pain is restricted to the site of the fibroid. This was associated with nausea and vomiting. She also developed a fever and her WBC count was 18000/μL. Which of the following is the appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of red degeneration of the fibroid. Red degeneration in pregnancy is managed with bed rest and analgesics.

Red degeneration is a complication of fibroids that often develops during pregnancy. It is due to the breakdown of fibroid resulting in ischemia and pain. It is an aseptic condition. Clinical features acute pain abdomen restricted to the site of the fibroid, fever, and vomiting. Investigations reveal an elevated WBC count and a raised ESR. Diagnosis can be made by ultrasound. It is usually self-limiting and can be managed with bed rest and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: A child is brought to the emergency room with an acute attack of asthma. Intravenous hydrocortisone had to be administered. Which of the following is true regarding the mechanism of this drug?

choices.text: They augment the effect of beta agonists on airway smooth muscles

questions.solution:
Hydrocortisone is a corticosteroid and it augments the effect of beta-agonists on airway smooth muscles.

Corticosteroids do not have any bronchodilatory properties. However, it is efficient in acute asthma exacerbation as they decrease inflammatory response (inhibit the formation of inflammatory cytokines). They also potentiate the beta-agonist effect on bronchial smooth muscles (increases the transcription of β-2 receptor genes), as well as help in decreasing mucus production.

Hydrocortisone acts primarily as a glucocorticoid but also has significant mineralocorticoid activity and is used for replacement therapy in the case of acute/chronic adrenal insufficiency.

Related Pearl: Activity of corticosteroids

Highest mineralocorticoid activity is seen with aldosterone.

Highest mineralocorticoid activity in a drug that is clinically used is seen with fludrocortisone (aldosterone cannot be used clinically).

Least mineralocorticoid activity is seen with betamethasone and dexamethasone.

 

Highest glucocorticoid activity is seen with dexamethasone and betamethasone.

questions.text: You are posted as an occupational health officer in an industry. You would perform a daily medical examination on the workers that are handling ________.
questions.solution:
Workers who handle irritant chemicals like dichromate require a daily medical examination.

A periodic medical examination is necessary when workers handle toxic or poisonous substances. This is done to recognize any early stages of diseases related to occupational origin. The frequency of the examination will depend on the type of occupational exposure. These periodical examinations may be supplemented with radiological and biological tests whenever necessary.

questions.text: A patient comes 9 months after a kidney transplant for routine evaluation. She receives tacrolimus with mycophenolate mofetil. The creatinine is found to be 3 mg/dl. Her previous value 2 months ago was 1.6mg/dl. Which of the following is the cause of her lab findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting 9 months after a kidney transplant with elevated creatinine has likely developed Tacrolimus-induced kidney injury. The mechanism of this is believed to be due to hypertension-induced in the renal tubules. 

Tacrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor that blocks FKBP 12. This is an immunophilin that ultimately inhibits calcineurin phosphatase and exerts its actions. 

Tacrolimus is administered orally for long-term maintenance. There are also IV formulations for patients unable to tolerate oral feeds. It is used in the management of solid organ transplant rejection including heart, kidney, and liver transplants. 

Tacrolimus has a very narrow therapeutic index and should be monitored intensively after initiating therapy till the patient stabilizes. It is associated with nephrotoxicity, neurotoxicity, hypertension, hyperglycemia. Nephrotoxicity is a significant risk when coadministered with cyclosporine, so most regimens of tacrolimus are now combined with mycofenolate which allows for dose reduction to a certain extent. However, it should still be monitored routinely.

Other Options:

Option A: Acute transplant reaction occurs within weeks to months after a transplant, usually within 6 months.

Option B: Mycophenolate causes leukopenia, pure red cell aplasia, and GI upset. It does not cause nephrotoxicity.

Option D: Ischemic injury can occur in chronic transplant rejection after years due to narrowed tubules. It does not cause creatinine to rise this soon.

questions.text: The life cycle of a parasite is given below. Which of the following is true regarding the eggs produced by this parasite?

choices.text: Non-bile stained, does not float in saturated salt solution
Bile stained, floats in saturated salt solution
Non-bile stained, floats in saturated salt solution
Bile stained, does not float in saturated salt solution

questions.solution:
The given image depicts the life cycle of Hymenolepis nana. The eggs of H.nana are non-bile stained and float in the saturated salt solution.

The eggs of Hymenolepis nana are about 30-40 μm in size and roughly spherical or ovoid in shape. It is covered by a thin colorless outer membrane with the hexacanth oncosphere enclosed inside the inner embryophore. Yolk granules and 4-8 thread-like polar filaments, arising from two knobs on the embryophore, are present in the space between the two membranes.

The eggs are non-bile stained and float in the saturated salt solution. The eggs cannot survive for more than 10 days in the external environment and are immediately infective after release. The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana.

Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the smallest tapeworm. Humans are the definitive host. It has no intermediate host. It occurs more commonly in children and the patient acquires this infection by ingesting food or water contaminated with its eggs. The egg attaches to the intestine and develops into the larva and adult worm. The adult worm resides in the small intestine.  

Patients are usually asymptomatic. But in heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. Pruritus may also be present due to an allergic response.

It can also cause autoinfection. Internal autoinfection occurs when the eggs are released in the intestine and hatch there. External autoinfection occurs through the ingestion of the eggs by the fecal-oral route. They hatch in the small intestine to release the hexacanth embryo which penetrates the intestinal villus resulting in autoinfection.

Praziquantel is the drug of choice for infection with H. nana.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques separates proteins on the basis of their stokes radii?
questions.solution:
Gel filtration chromatography, also known as size exclusion chromatography separates proteins on the basis of their stokes radii.

Stokes radius is a measure of the effective volume a protein occupies in a free solution. It accounts for both the mass and the shape of the protein. Proteins with large and small stokes radii are applied to the top of a gel filtration column. On entering the column, the small proteins enter pores in the stationary phase matrix (included proteins). During the mobile phase flowing down the column, the large molecules lag behind, which get excluded (excluded proteins). Proteins thus emerge from a gel filtration column in descending order of their stokes radii.

Ion exchange chromatography separates proteins in inverse order of the strength of their interactions with the stationary phase and is based on charge-charge interactions. Proteins with a net positive charge at a given pH will tightly adhere to negatively charged beads called cation exchangers. Proteins with a net negative charge will adhere to positively charged beads called anion exchangers. Nonadherent proteins flow through the matrix and are washed away. HbA1c (Glycated hemoglobin) is best measured using ion exchange chromatography.

Affinity chromatography is based on the high selectivity displayed by most proteins for their ligands. The high selectivity of affinity chromatography is caused by allowing the desired molecule to interact with the stationary phase and remain bound within the column in order to facilitate its separation from the undesired material, which will not interact and elute first.

Hydrophobic interaction Chromatography separates proteins based on their tendency to associate with a stationary phase matrix coated with hydrophobic groups. Proteins with exposed hydrophobic surfaces adhere to the matrix via hydrophobic bonds that are enhanced by employing a mobile phase of high ionic strength.

Related Pearl: Types of Chromatography

Chromatography types Property used for separation
Paper chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Thin layer chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Ion exchange chromatography Based on charge – charge interaction
Size exclusion chromatography Based on descending order of Stokes radius which is a function of molecular mass and shape
Affinity chromatography Based on specific ligand binding behaviour
Hydrophobic interaction chromatography Based on hydrophobic interaction

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man was posted for elective appendicectomy. During the pre-anesthetic workup, he gives a history of denervating injury over his left elbow due to an accident 2 years back. While administering muscle relaxants to this patient prior to surgery, which of the following responses would you most likely observe in the denervated area?

DMR - Depolarising muscle relaxant

NDMR - Non-Depolarising muscle relaxant

choices.text: Resistance to both DMR and NDMR
Exaggerated response to both DMR and NDMR
Exaggerated response to NDMR and resistance to DMR
Exaggerated response to DMR and resistance to NDMR

questions.solution:
The most likely observation is an exaggerated response to DMR and resistance to NDMR.

Neuromuscular blocking agents are subdivided into two classes

  1. Depolarizing muscle relaxants
  2. Non-Depolarizing muscle relaxants

To understand the response of administering muscle relaxants with a history of denervation injury, we must first know the mechanism of action of both types of muscle relaxants. All neuromuscular blocking agents are quaternary ammonium compounds with an affinity for nicotinic ACh receptors due to the positively charged nitrogen present in them. 

Depolarising muscle relaxants (DMRs), such as succinylcholine (SCh) closely resemble the neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh). When administered, they rapidly bind to the ACh receptors on the muscle end-plate and cause depolarization. Unlike ACh, DMRs are not metabolized by the acetylcholinesterase enzyme. This results in their prolonged presence in the synaptic cleft. As a result, there is continuous endplate depolarization.

This continuous endplate depolarization does not allow the endplate to repolarize. Hence, the time-limited perijunctional sodium channels that were inactivated during depolarization fail to re-open. This leads to muscle relaxation.

Non-Depolarising muscle relaxants (NDMRs) such as atracurium, pancuronium, etc compete with ACh and bind to its receptors, preventing the action of ACh on its receptors. However, the NDMRs are incapable of inducing the conformational change necessary for ion channel opening. Hence, their binding does not lead to the development of end-plate potential.

Thus, DMRs behave as ACh receptor agonists while NDMRs behave as competitive antagonists. 

In the given clinical scenario, where there is a history of a chronic denervation injury, the physiological response is that of overexpression of ACh receptors on the muscle membranes. These overexpressed receptors are low conductance receptors with a prolonged opening time, similar to fetal nicotinic ACh receptors.

The prolonged opening time of these receptors leads to an exaggerated response to DMRs. Whereas, the increased number of receptors leads to resistance to the action of NDMRs, as the NDMRs now cannot block all these receptors. The net effect is an exaggerated response to DMR and resistance to NDMR.

The opposite happens in conditions like myasthenia gravis, where the number of ACh receptors is greatly reduced. This leads to an exaggerated response to NDMRs due to complete antagonism of all receptors and resistance to DMRs due to an inadequate number of receptors being depolarized. (Option C)

Options A and B are not possible in this scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the oncogenic mechanism of human papilloma virus ?

choices.text: E6 binds to RB protein and displaces E2F
E7 binds to RB protein and displaces E2F
Tax protein leading to polyclonal expansion of T cells
L1 protein leading to clonal expansion of T cells

questions.solution:
The true statement is that E7 protein of human papilloma virus (HPV) binds to the hypophosphorylated RB protein and displaces the E2F transcription factors, thereby promoting G1/S transition.

RB gene is a key negative regulator of the cell cycle at the G1/S transition. RB gene exists in an active hypophosphorylated state in resting cells and in an inactive hyperphosphorylated state in cells undergoing G1/S transition.

E7 protein from the high-risk types of HPV (such as HPV 16) binds to the hypophosphorylated RB through the same pocket that RB uses to bind and sequester the E2F transcription factors, thereby displacing the E2F which leads to the progression of the cell cycle and thus the proliferation of tumor cells. E7 proteins also inactivate the CDK inhibitors p21 and p27. E7 proteins from high-risk HPVs (types 16,18 and 31) also bind and presumably activate cyclins  A and E.

Oncogenic activities of protein E6:

The E6 protein binds to and helps in the degradation of p53 and stimulates the expression of telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT), which is the catalytic subunit of telomerase, thereby helping in the longevity of the cells. E6 from high-risk HPV types has a higher affinity for p53 than E6 from low-risk types. 

Other options :

Option C: HTLV-1 encodes the viral protein Tax, which leads to polyclonal expansion of T cells. It exhibits tropism for CD4+ T cells.

Option D: L1 major capsid protein is useful in the formulation of HPV vaccines.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy came limping and sat down with his left knee flexed, complaining of pain, limitation of movement, stiffness, and swelling over the knee joint. His parents describe what is classical of 'night cries'. An X-ray taken is shown below.  A chest radiograph showed right upper lobe airspace disease with associated hilar adenopathy. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is tubercular arthritis.

The clinical vignette of a young patient between 10-25 years of age, presenting with pain, swelling, and stiffness, restriction of movement at the knee joint, typical 'night cries' along with right upper lobe airspace disease, hilar lymphadenopathy with the knee X-ray showing joint space destruction and marked periarticular rarefaction is suggestive of a case of tubercular arthritis.

The spread of infection of the bones and joints occurs through the bloodstream, referred to as tertiary spread, and begins locally as synovitis or osteomyelitis. As the synovial membrane and subchondral bone have a common blood supply, a simultaneous infection may be seen.

The patient presents with complaints of pain, swelling, fever and night sweats, loss of weight, and restricted joint movement. As articular erosion progresses, deformity of the joint becomes apparent. The patient begins limping and the knee is kept flexed. Discharging sinuses may be present.

During the night, subsequent to local muscle relaxation, there is stretching to compression of the affected tissues at night, leading to periods of intense pain called 'night cries'.

An X-ray shows the bone ends having a 'washed out' appearance with narrowing of joint space. Epiphyseal enlargement, soft-tissue swelling, and peri-articular osteoporosis are observed. In the later stages, there is subarticular bone erosion on both sides of the joint with an absence of periosteal reaction.

On further investigation, the Mantoux test or Heaf test will be positive and there is an elevated ESR. Synovial fluid appears cloudy on aspiration; a culture of this fluid or that of synovial biopsy specimen shows the growth of M.Tuberculosis.

Management involves both conservative and operative procedures. The affected knee is immobilized by below-knee skin traction and plaster of Paris cast above-knee. Antitubercular chemotherapy is started.

Operative procedures are:

  1. Synovectomy in cases of synovial tuberculosis
  2. Joint debridement when articular cartilage is preserved
  3. Arthrodesis

Other options:

Option A: Rheumatoid arthritis is the chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints. It occurs between the ages of 20 to 50 years and women are more commonly affected. The presence of four or more of the following is indicative of rheumatoid arthritis: Morning stiffness, swelling of three or more specified joints, swelling of joints in the hands and wrist, symmetrical swellings, rheumatoid nodule, rheumatoid factor positive, X-ray showing erosion or unequivocal peri-articular osteopenia.

Option B: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative disease primarily affecting the articular cartilage, which occurs in elderly people, mostly in weight-bearing joints of the lower limb such as the knee and hip when the disease is primary and is usually bilateral. Secondary osteoarthritis occurs due to an underlying disease of the joint such as avascular necrosis, coxa vara, and malunited fractures of the hip. It occurs at any age after adolescence and commonly affects the hip.

Option D: Psoriatic arthropathy presents as a polyarthritis, with the involvement of distal interphalangeal joints. It is also associated with the presence of psoriatic skin disease, nail disease characterized by onycholysis, pitting, splinter hemorrhages, and ocular disease in the form of uveitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with a painless swelling in front of the ear as given below. On examination, his left earlobe was lifted and the curtain sign was positive. What is the mainstay treatment of this condition where only the superficial lobe is involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of parotid pleomorphic adenoma and the mainstay treatment in this condition is superficial parotidectomy. 

Pleomorphic adenomas are benign mixed neoplasms presenting as a painless and slow-growing swelling that lifts the ear lobe. This swelling cannot be moved above the zygomatic bone and is known as the curtain sign. 

Sometimes it may undergo malignant transformation. The malignant form is known as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma. Signs of malignant transformation include:

  • A rapid increase in size
  • Pain and ulceration
  • Facial nerve involvement (LMN)
  • Lymph node involvement
  • Restricted jaw movements

Surgical intervention is done via parotidectomy. If only the superficial lobe is involved superficial parotidectomy (removal of the superficial lobe) is done. 

If both lobes are involved, total conservative parotidectomy (both lobes are removed but the facial nerve is preserved) or total radical parotidectomy (both lobes and facial nerve are removed - malignant cases) can be done.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about the anterior border of the structure marked?

1. It is a part of the lesser omentum.

2. It is a derivative of the ventral mesentery.

3. It is clamped to prevent bleeding from hepatic veins and inferior vena cava.

4. Its contents are the hepatic artery, hepatic vein, and common bile duct.
questions.solution:
Statements A and B are true about the hepatoduodenal ligament. 

The structure marked in the given image is the epiploic foramen. The hepatoduodenal ligament, which is formed by the thickened free right margin of the lesser omentum (Statement 1), forms the anterior boundary of the epiploic foramen. Lesser omentum develops from the ventral mesogastrium (Statement 2) and the part of it between the liver and the duodenum is called the hepatoduodenal ligament.

Within this free border lies the following structures (Statement 4):

  • Bile duct (anteriorly on the right)
  • Hepatic artery (anteriorly on the left)
  • Portal vein (posteriorly) 

The Pringle maneuver is performed when there is excessive bleeding from the liver. In this maneuver, the hepatoduodenal ligament is occluded with a vessel loop or vascular clamp. This helps to stop the blood flow from the hepatic artery and portal vein (Statement 3). Hence, if bleeding continues even after performing this maneuver, that means that the source of the bleeding must be the hepatic vein or inferior vena cava.

The epiploic foramen is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac. The pearl summarizes the various relations of the foramen.

questions.text: A couple presents to you with complaints of inability to conceive despite staying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse. You advise them to come to the hospital within 2 hours after having sexual intercourse for post-coital test. Which of the following is false regarding this test?

choices.text: Ability of sperms to penetrate cervical mucous can be studied
Cervical mucus viscosity and quantity can be studied
Can detect presence of anti-sperm antibodies

questions.solution:
The test being advised for the above couple is the post-coital test and normally, the sperms should show progressive, but not rotatory movements.

Post-coital test (Sims’ or Huhner’s test):

The couple is advised intercourse close to the ovulation time, preferably in the early hours of the morning. The woman presents herself at the clinic within 2 hours after the intercourse.

The mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and is spread over a glass slide. Another smear made from the posterior fornix serves as a control. Normally 10–50 motile sperms are seen per high-power field in cervical mucus.

The presence of antispermal antibodies in the cervical mucus imparts shaky or rotatory movements to the sperms or may totally immobilize them. The cervical mucus is simultaneously examined for its quantity, viscosity, and fern test.

The advantage of this test is that the cervical mucus can be simultaneously studied for oestrogenic effect and ovulation and its capability to allow sperm penetration and to look for the presence of any anti-sperm antibodies.

Note: The test is useless in the presence of cervical infection, which should be treated before performing the post-coital test.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presented with a 1-year history of worsening headaches and one episode of focal seizures recently. Imaging reveals a cortical calcified mass in the left cerebral hemisphere. The histopathological image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

IDH- Isocitrate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario presence of cortical calcified mass in the left cerebral hemisphere with histopathology revealing a chicken-wire pattern and fried egg appearance is suggestive of oligodendroglioma.

In the given histopathological image there are regular sheets of tumor cells with spherical nuclei surrounded by a perinuclear halo termed fried egg appearance. The network of thin branched capillary-sized vessels shows a "chicken-wire" pattern in appearance. The cells that infiltrate the brain may collect around the neurons. This is called perineural satellitosis.

Oligodendroglioma is an infiltrating glioma composed of cells resembling oligodendrocytes. It is associated with mutations in IDH and deletion of chromosomes 1p and 19q.

Most commonly oligodendrogliomas are detected in the fourth and fifth decades of life. Patients may have had several years of antecedent neurologic complaints, often including seizures. The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, with a pre­dilection for white matter. The imaging may show the presence of cortical mass with calcifications.

Management includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy.

Related Pearl: Most commons of Brain tumours

Most common tumor of the brain - Metastasis secondary to lungs > breast

Most common primary CNS tumor - glioma > meningioma

Most common primary CNS tumor in children - pilocytic astrocytoma

Most common primary CNS tumor in adults - astrocytoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in children - medulloblastoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in adults - glioblastoma

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A patient who is a known asthmatic on low-dose inhalational corticosteroids comes to the OPD with complaints of acute exacerbations. On this visit, theophylline is added to his treatment regimen and shows better symptom control. He returns after a few days with complaints of nausea, headache, gastric discomfort, and excessive micturition. Which of his side effects is not due to phosphodiesterase-4  inhibition?
questions.solution:
The diuretic effect of theophylline is due to the blockade of adenosine (A1) receptors. All the other symptoms are caused by the inhibition of PDE4.

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug that acts by:

  • Inhibition of phosphodiesterase enzyme (PDE). PDE3 inhibition causes relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle and PDE4 inhibition causes inhibition of the release of cytokines and chemokines which further leads to a decrease in immune cell migration and activation.
  • Blockade of adenosine receptors, which inhibits bronchoconstriction. However, blockade of A1 receptors in the glomerular afferent arteriole and PCT causes diuresis.
  • Activating enzyme histone deacetylase-2, which is responsible for its anti-inflammatory action

Adverse effects of theophylline are usually related to plasma concentration ( >15 mg/L). The most common side effects are headache, nausea, and vomiting, abdominal discomfort (due to inhibition of PDE4), and restlessness.

At high concentrations, cardiac arrhythmias may occur due to inhibition of cardiac PDE3 and antagonism of cardiac A1 receptors. At very high concentrations, seizures may occur due to central A1 receptor antagonism.

A targeted plasma concentration of 5-10mg/L is maintained to avoid adverse effects and drug interactions.

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text: A  male patient presented with a 6-month history of soft tissue swelling on the right jaw. On examination, a discharging sinus was found as seen below.  On microscopic examination of the pus, sulfur granules appearance was seen.  Which of the following is not true regarding the implicated pathogen?

choices.text: Stains positive by Kinyoun's modified acid fast staining
It is an anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria
It is a gram-positive filamentous bacteria
Culture of the organism shows a molar tooth appearance of the colonies

questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation, this is a case of cervicofacial actinomycosis caused by Actinomyces  species. Actinomyces are gram-positive, anaerobic, and filamentous bacteria that are non-acid-fast in contrast to Nocardia.

Actinomycosis typically presents as a painless nodule that indurates, with purulent discharge that contains sulfur granules. Sulfur granules are composed of a matrix of bacteria, calcium phosphate, and host tissue. It is an indolent, slowly progressive, suppurative, and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions, with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain sulfur granules. It presents as any of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- (most common site) fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas. (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonization of intrauterine contraceptive devices.
  • Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue, and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis:

  • Gram staining of sulfur granules shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures (Sunray appearance).
  • Culture shows a molar tooth appearance of the colonies.

The image below shows the molar tooth appearance of Actinomyces colonies.

 

Image below shows gram-positive filaments of Actinomyces. 

 

The given image shows a patient with multiple cutaneous lesions caused by actinomycosis:

Penicillin G is the drug of choice and requires prolonged administration where the duration of therapy is between 6-12 months. The other drugs that can be used include amoxicillin, erythromycin, tetracycline, doxycycline, clindamycin, and minocycline. Surgical excision and drainage may be required.

questions.text: The histopathological appearance of the renal arteriole of a patient with a BP of 230/120 mm Hg is as below. The fundoscopy showed bilateral retinal flame hemorrhages. The pathophysiology of her hypertension is likely due to:

choices.text: Hyaline deposition in the small capillaries
Basophilic calcification of the muscular arteries
Fatty  streaks and foamy macrophages in tunica intima

questions.solution:
The given scenario of severe hypertension (blood pressure ≥180/≥120 mmHg) with fundoscopic changes (flame hemorrhages and/or papilloedema) is suggestive of malignant hypertension (also known as hypertensive emergency/crisis). The histopathological image shows fibromuscular hyperplasia of the arterioles having a typical onion-skin appearance. This is seen in hyperplastic arteriosclerosis. 

Malignant hypertension is characterized by severe hypertension with ischemic complications of multi-organs. The commonly affected organs are eye (resulting in retinal hemorrages, hard exudates, cotton wool spots with or without papilledema) and kidney (causing malignant nephrosclerosis). 

The pathophysiology behind this condition is due to hyperplastic arteriosclerosis. It affects small arteries and arterioles causing thickening and hardening of the wall with loss of elasticity. 

Histopathological features of malignant hypertension are - 

  • Smooth muscle and collagen proliferation are seen resulting in reduced size of the lumen. This further leads to concentric, laminated arteriolar thickening of the vessel wall with duplication of the basement membrane giving rise to an onion-skin appearance. 
  • They are also accompanied by fibrinoid deposits and vessel wall necrosis (necrotizing arterioles), particularly in the kidney and can lead to acute renal failure. 
  • Small, pinpoint petechial hemorrhages may appear on the cortical surface from rupture of arterioles or glomerular capillaries, giving the kidney a peculiar flea-bitten appearance.
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, DIC, and encephalopathy may also be present. The prognosis is very poor if left untreated.
  • No changes are seen in the heart. 
 

Other options - 

Option A: Hyaline deposition in the vessel wall leads to benign hypertension. Here, the arteriolar wall is thickened with increased protein deposition (hyalinized), and the lumen is irregular and markedly narrowed. It can also cause bilaterally contracted kidneys with the renal surface showing diffuse, fine granularity that resembles grain leather. 

Option C: Basophilic dystrophic calcification in tunica media and internal elastic lamina is seen in Monckeberg's medial sclerosis. The vessels are hardened and can be felt like bone on palpation. They are usually asymptomatic and are seen in age groups more than 80 years. Lumen size is normal here. 

Option D: Fatty streaks and foamy macrophages in tunica intima are characteristic of atherosclerosis. 

The cells marked in the image below are the foam cells in atheromatous plaques. They refer to lipid-laden monocytes/ macrophages or smooth muscle cells within the plaques.

questions.text: Which of the following will cause the cell cycle to stop at the G1-S checkpoint?
questions.solution:
p53 accumulation in the cell causes transcription of CDKN1A gene, which produces p21 protein. p21 inhibits CDK4/cyclin D complexes, thereby maintaining RB in hypophosphorylated and active state. This blocks the cell cycle progression at G1-S checkpoint. 

G1-S checkpoint is predominantly regulated by retinoblastoma (RB) gene. During the normal progression of the cell cycle, there is an increase in the levels of CDK4/cyclin D, CDK6/cyclin D and CDK2/cyclin E. This leads to hyperphosphorylation and consequent inhibition of RB. This releases E2F transcription factors from RB, and they drive the expression of the genes which are required to progress to the S-phase of the cell cycle. While growth factors accelerate this entire process and upregulate the activity of CDK/cyclin complexes, growth inhibitors increase CDK inhibitors.

TP53, which is a tumor suppressor gene, also plays a role in cell cycle progression. Ionization radiation, carcinogens and other forms of oncogenic stressors activate TP53. p53 accumulation in the cell can bring about the following outcomes to prevent the neoplastic transformation of the cell:

  • Cell cycle arrest at G1-S can occur because of p21 protein, which blocks CDK4/cyclin D complex. This pause in the cell cycle is utilized for DNA repair.
  • Cellular senescence (permanent cell cycle arrest) can occur.
  • Apoptosis of cells with irreversible DNA damage can be induced by p53.

MDM2 protein stimulates the degradation of p53 and will thus move the cell cycle forward.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to the emergency department following several episodes of blood-stained vomitus. The patient reported that the symptoms started after attempts of forceful retching after a binge-eating episode. Her endoscopy finding is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Mallory-Weiss tears. The given clinical scenario describes bulimia, which is a disorder in which the patient first indulges in binge eating and then vomits out the food. Forceful vomiting in bulimia may lead to Mallory-Weiss tears.

Mallory-Weiss tears are longitudinal mucosal tears near the gastroesophageal junction.

It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or staining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

Management of Mallory-Weiss tear

  1. Conservative, as it is usually is self-limiting
  2. Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy
  3. Angiographic embolization - if endoscopy fails
  4. High gastrotomy - if all these maneuvers fail

Option A: Barrett's esophagus presents clinically with features similar to GERD. The patients complain of heartburn, dysphagia, and regurgitation of sour-tasting gastric contents, most often post-prandially.

Option B: Esophageal varices are tortuous dilated veins within the mucosa and submucosa of the distal esophagus and proximal stomach. Variceal hemorrhage is an emergency that can be treated medically by inducing splanchnic vasoconstriction or endoscopically by sclerotherapy, balloon tamponade, or variceal ligation.

Option C: Boerhaave syndrome is a much more serious disorder characterized by transmural tearing and rupture of the distal esophagus. This catastrophic event produces severe mediastinitis and generally requires surgical intervention. The patients initially present with severe chest pain, tachypnea, and shock.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency following an assault by his neighbour with a metal rod. The patient was diagnosed to have permanent loss of hearing. Which of the following BNS (IPC) section describes the punishment in this case?
questions.solution:
Permanent hearing loss is considered grievous hurt. BNS Sec 118 (2) (326 IPC) describes punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons.

Grievous hurt is inflicted voluntarily to another person and comprises any of the eight kinds (clauses) enumerated below:

  • Clause 1 — Emasculation.
  • Clause 2 — Permanent privation of the sight of either eye. 
  • Clause 3 — Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
  • Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
  • Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
  • Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
  • Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.
  • Clause 8 — Any hurt which endangers life or causes the sufferer to be, during the period of 15 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

Punishment for grievous hurt :

  • BNS Sec 117(2)- previously 325 IPC- Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt –imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
  • BNS Sec 118(2)- previously 326 IPC Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means—life imprisonment or imprisonment of a minimum of one year, extendable up to ten years, and fine.

Related IPC's

BNS Section 115(1)- previously 321 IPC: Voluntarily causing hurt.
BNS Section 117(1)- previously 322 IPC: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt.
BNS Section 115(2)- previously 323 IPC.: Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt: Imprisonment up to one year, or with fine up to one thousand rupees or both.
BNS Section 118(1)- previously 324 IPC.: Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means (3 years imprisonment) or with fine or both.

The above image represents the floor of the fourth ventricle. It is a shallow diamond-shaped depression on the dorsal surfaces of the pons and the rostral half of the medulla. It contains the nuclei of the cranial nerves (V-XII).

questions.text: Identify the type of isomerism shown by the 2 molecules represented in the below image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows glucose and fructose that differ in the functional groups. Hence they are functional isomers.

Fructose has the same molecular formula as glucose but differs in that there is a keto group in position 2 whereas in glucose there is an aldehyde group in position 1.

Other options

Option A: Anomerism

Anomers are characterized by the difference in spatial configuration of —H and —OH groups with reference to the first carbon atom in aldoses and the second carbon atom in ketoses. D-glucose has two anomers, alpha and beta varieties.

Option C: Enantiomerism/ D and L isomerism

The orientation of the —H and —OH groups around the penultimate carbon atom determines whether the sugar belongs to the D- or L- series.

  • When the —OH group on the penultimate carbon atom of the sugar is on the right side, then the sugar is designated as a D- isomer/enantiomer.
  • When the –OH group is on the left, it is an L-isomer/enantiomer.
  • Naturally occurring monosaccharides- D-sugars
  • Naturally occurring amino acids –L-isomers

Option D: Isomers that differ in configuration around only one specific carbon atom (with the exception of the carbonyl carbon) are defined as epimers of each other.

Examples of epimers of glucose:

  • Mannose (epimerized at carbon 2)
  • Galactose (epimerized at carbon 4)

questions.text: A 64-year-old diabetic and hypertensive patient with an average BP of 150/90 mmHg had a transient ischemic attack that lasted for 30 minutes. His speech was slurred, but there was no motor weakness in his limbs. Calculate the ABCD2 score for this patient to determine the risk of developing a stroke in the future.
questions.solution:
The ABCD2 score for this patient is 5. The risk factors contributing to the score are as follows.

  • Age >60 years - 1 point
  • Systolic blood pressure >140 mmHg - 1 point
  • Slurred speech without motor weakness - 1 point
  • Duration of 30 min - 1 point
  • Diabetes - 1 point

The total score adds up to 5 points which suggests a 12% risk of developing a stroke in the next 3 months.

The ABCD2 score is used to calculate the risk of stroke after transient ischemic attack (TIA). TIA is defined as episodes of stroke symptoms that last for only a brief period of time (<24 hours) and most often <1 hour.

questions.text: A research assistant with chemical burns was rushed to the emergency. On examination, he has 2nd-degree burns involving 40% of his total body surface area. He is stabilized and fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to assess adequate fluid correction?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most appropriate way to assess adequate fluid correction is by measuring urine output. 

The urine output should be maintained between 0.5 to 1mL/kg body weight/hour. If the urine output is low and the patient presents with signs of hypoperfusion (restlessness with tachycardia, cool peripheries, high hematocrit). A bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be administered.  Urine output in excess of 2 mL/kg body weight per hour indicates that the patient is being over-resuscitated and thus the infusion should be decreased.

Monitoring lactate levels is useful in larger burns. A persistent raised lactate/metabolic acidosis can indicate a missed systemic toxicity from cyanide or carbon monoxide.

Other options: 

Option A: The parkland formula is a tool to estimate fluid requirement, and not assess the adequacy of fluid correction.

Option B: Central venous pressure monitoring is required in patients with cardiac/renal dysfunction.

Option D: Hematocrit is not measured during resuscitation of burns.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A 58-year-old chronic alcoholic woman presented to the dermatology outpatient department with the following lesion over the extensor aspect of the arm. All the following are the histopathological features seen in this condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical image is indicative of psoriasis. All the following histopathological features are seen in this condition except suprapapillary thickening, instead suprapapillary thinning is seen.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. The sustained inflammation leads to uncontrolled proliferation of the epidermal keratinocytes.

In a normal individual, it takes approximately 30 days for basal epidermal keratinocytes to proliferate, differentiate, and ascend through the layers of the epidermis. However, this process takes only 4-5 days in a patient with psoriasis. 

It can be caused due to drugs (lithium, antimalarials, interferon-α), seasons (winter), infections (streptococcal), alcohol abuse, and smoking. 

Histopathological features of psoriasis include:

  • Acanthosis- Irregular epidermal thickening 
  • Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis
  • Suprapapillary thinning
  • Clubbing or elongation of rete ridges at the base
  • Kogoj spongiform pustules- collection of neutrophils in the malpighian layer (stratum basale and stratum spinosum referred together)
  • Munro microabscesses- collection of neutrophils in stratum corneum
  • Dilated, tortuous blood vessels in the dermis

Psoriasis patient presents with skin involved in the form of red/ salmon pink, scaly, and well-demarcated lesions. A peripheral clearing (ring of Woronoff) may be present. It is usually seen on the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

The appearance of a smooth, glossy red membrane with small bleeding points on the removal of the scales by gentle scraping is known as Auspitz sign, which is characteristic. It is associated with Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon.

Topical application of steroids, retinoids, vitamin D, and emollients is the mainstay of management

The following is an image of psoriasis. Its epidermis shows markedly elongated rete ridges, with bulbous thickening. Also, it shows thin suprapapillary epidermal plates, edema, and dilated vessels in the dermal papillae.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.
