questions.text: A 40-year-old man was incidentally diagnosed with a non-functional adrenal tumor of size 3 cm during his routine check-up. Subsequently, in about 3 months, the size of the tumor in MRI increases by about 40%. The next ideal step in the treatment of this patient would be:

choices.text: CT-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the tumor

questions.solution:
From the given description, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is the ideal and definitive management in non-functional adrenal tumors, i.e, incidentalomas more than 4 cm in size. An increase in the size of the tumor by 40% indicates an increase in size by 1.2 cm. Thus, the total size of the tumor here is 4.2 cm. 

An adrenal incidentaloma is defined as a clinically unapparent adrenal lesion that is incidentally detected in imaging studies. The majority of these lesions are non-functional.  Secondary metastasis from breast, lung, and kidneys are seen in 2% of the patients. Functional tumors may present with Cushing's syndrome, phaeochromocytoma, Conn's syndrome, etc. These tumors can become malignant and the incidence increases 4-fold if the size of the lesion crosses 4 cm. 

Management of non-functional incidentalomas < 4cm is conservative with routine MRI surveillance every 3-6 months. If > 4cm, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is done.

 Other options - 

A. Hormonal assay studies are done in suspected functional tumours or patients presenting with symptoms. If positive, it should be managed accordingly. Observation is not a followed protocol unless they're not functional or benign. 

B. Fine-needle aspiration and biopsy is avoided as it is inconclusive to distinguish adrenal adenomas from carcinomas. It can be considered in suspected extra-adrenal secondary metastasis. Tests for pheochromocytoma should always be done before the procedure to avoid precipitating a hypertensive crisis.

C. Follow-up MRI with 3-6 months surveillance is done for non-functional tumors <4cm size.

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby is brought to the OPD with complaints of noisy breathing. On examination, there was bluish discoloration of the lips and the mucosa. The respiratory rate was 65 cpm. On performing direct laryngoscopy, you notice the following findings.  What is the definitive management of this condition?

choices.text: Endotracheal intubation followed by delayed tracheostomy
Proton pump inhibitors to prevent reflux

questions.solution:
In the given scenario the baby presents with noisy breathing, respiratory distress(RR-65cpm) and bluish discoloration of the lips and mucosa(Cyanosis) and direct laryngoscopy showing omega-shaped epiglottis is suggestive of severe laryngomalacia. Supraglottoplasty is performed in a case of severe laryngomalacia.

In 15–20% of patients with laryngomalacia, symptoms are severe enough to cause progressive respiratory distress, cyanosis, failure to thrive, or cor pulmonale. In such cases, supraglottoplasty is performed.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital laryngeal anomaly and the most common cause of stridor in infants and children. Stridor is exacerbated by any exertion: crying, agitation, or feeding. In the prone position, the stridor disappears.

Direct laryngoscopy shows elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself (omega-shaped Ω), floppy aryepiglottic folds, and prominent arytenoids. 

In most children, only expectant observation is required as the condition resolves secondary to nervous system maturation, within 18 to 24 months of birth(Option A). However, neonates with severe laryngomalacia may develop marked upper airway obstruction resulting in cor pulmonale, life-threatening apneic episodes, feeding difficulties, obstructive sleep apnea, and failure to thrive. In such cases, surgical resection of supraglottic tissues and supraglottoplasty has been the favored approach.

questions.text: A young woman complains of excessive thirst, polyuria, and nocturia following a head injury. There is no glucosuria. Her urine osmolarity is found to be 290 mOsm/L, and her 24-hour urine output is 2.75 L. The patient was asked not to consume any fluids. After 4 hours, the urine osmolality was measured to be 600 mOsm/L. MRI showed a bright spot in the posterior pituitary.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is primary polydipsia.

In the given clinical scenario, the patient has polyuria, nocturia, and polydipsia without glucosuria. Her urine osmolality is initially low (<300 mosm/L) but increases after the fluid restriction (400–800 mosmol/L). The MRI showed a bright spot in the posterior pituitary. These findings favor the diagnosis.

Primary polydipsia means excessive intake of fluids. It can occur as a result of

  • inappropriate thirst mechanism - dipsogenic diabetes insipidus
  • as a part of psychosis - psychogenic polydipsia
  • due to increased water intake owing to its health benefits - iatrogenic polydipsia

Excessive water intake results in decreased plasma osmolality and sodium levels, decreasing the antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion. There is a compensatory increase in urine volume and a decrease in urine osmolality.

In patients with primary polydipsia, fluid restriction increases and brings back the plasma osmolality and sodium to normal. This increases the levels of ADH, which results in increased urinary osmolality.

In most healthy adults, the posterior pituitary emits a hyperintense signal visible in the MRI as a bright spot. This is visualized in patients with primary polydipsia and is abnormal or absent in patients with central diabetes insipidus.

Other options:

Option A: Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is caused due to deficiency of ADH secretion. In this condition, the levels of ADH do not increase even after fluid restriction and therefore the urine osmolality will not increase. 

Option B: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus occurs due to decreased action of ADH. Mutations occur in the V2 receptor or the aquaporin channels and ADH cannot act on them. Therefore, in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, even if the ADH levels are normal, it cannot act on the receptors, and the urine osmolality does not increase after fluid restriction. A simpler way to differentiate between central DI and nephrogenic DI is to measure basal ADH levels and urine osmolality under unrestricted fluid intake conditions. A low urine osmolality with a concurrent elevated ADH level (>1 ng/mL) indicates nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. A low ADH level is suggestive of central DI or primary polydipsia, which can be differentiated on MRI brain.

Option C: Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion results in increased secretions of ADH. Therefore, the patients will have decreased urine output and increased urine concentration. If the water intake is not restricted, patients also develop hyponatremia.

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

    • Pituitary adenomas (most common)

questions.text: A newborn child presents with the following finding in the right eye as shown in the image below. The left eye is normal. What is the ideal age to take this patient up for elective surgery?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dense unilateral congenital cataract. Ideally, unilateral dense cataract merits urgent surgery and it is at 6 weeks when elective surgery should be performed.

Generally, it is not advisable to operate on lamellar cataracts until the child is 1 or preferably 2 years old. But when the lens is completely opaque, or the pupil will not dilate, and when squint or nystagmus is developing, it is wise to operate at an earlier age. Moreover, the results of surgery in unilateral cataracts in children are universally poor, unless the operation is carried out within the first 6 weeks of birth.

This is because the critical period for developing the fixation reflex in both unilateral and bilateral visual deprivation disorders is between 2 and 4 months of age. Thus, any cataract dense enough to impair vision must be dealt with before this age and the earliest possible time is preferred. 

Surgery involves anterior capsulorhexis, aspiration of lens matter, capsulorhexis of the posterior capsule, limited anterior vitrectomy, and IOL implantation, if appropriate. It is important to correct associated refractive errors.

Related Pearl: Types of Congenital Cataract

Punctate cataract: Blue-dot cataract, most common congenital cataract

 

Zonular/Lamellar cataract: Most common congenital cataract with diminished vision; Spokes of a wheel appearance (Rider’s Cataract) A, B, and C

 

Fusiform/coralliform cataract: Anteroposterior spindle shaped appearance. 

 

Nuclear cataract: Most common type of cataract seen in congenital rubella syndrome

 

Coronary cataract: Appears as a corona of club-shaped opacities near the periphery of the lens.

 

Anterior polar cataract: May arise either due to delayed development of anterior chamber or due to corneal perforation

 

Posterior polar cataract: Progressive form of posterior polar cataract, which typically shows an "onion whorl appearance"

questions.text: What is the most common complication of the procedure shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the procedure of endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). Pancreatitis is the most common complication of ERCP. 

Here in this question image, a side-viewing endoscope is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla. It is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree.

The pancreatitis is usually mild and resolves in a few days. CT scan is indicated in a patient complaining of pain, tachycardia, or hypotension post-ERCP. The risk factors for the development of post-ERCP pancreatitis include sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, young age, normal bilirubin, past history of pancreatitis, contrast injecting into pancreatic ducts, pancreatic sphincterotomy and balloon dilatation of biliary sphincter.

It is now recommended to administer per-rectal indomethacin or diclofenac before or after the procedure to reduce the risk of post-ERCP pancreatitis.

The other complications of ERCP include duodenal perforation, hemorrhage, and sepsis.

 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: A newborn is being evaluated after a difficult birth. A deformity is present in the left arm as shown in the image below. Which of the following nerve root is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing a claw hand with a supinated forearm and the flexed elbow is likely suggestive of Klumpke's palsy. The C8-T1 nerve roots are affected in this condition. 

Klumpke's palsy occurs following an injury to the 8th cervical nerve and the 1st thoracic nerve. It is commonly seen after deliveries involving excessive traction on the brachial plexus. It results in a paralyzed hand where the intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) and the ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8) are mainly affected.

Clinically, the baby lies with the forearm supinated and the elbow flexed. There is a loss of intrinsic muscle power and reflexes in the hand. There may be a unilateral Horner’s syndrome, characterized by ipsilateral ptosis and miosis if the sympathetic fibers of the 1st thoracic root are also injured.

Immobilization and prevention of contractures form the mainstay of treatment in Klumpke's palsy.

The image given below shows clinical features seen in Klumpke's palsy.

Narakas classification for babies delivered via cephalic presentation with brachial plexus injury is as follows: 

  • Group 1: C5/C6
  • Group 2: C5/C6/C7
  • Group 3: Entire plexus involved
  • Group 4: Entire plexus with Horner's sign

Other options: 

Option A: Median nerve palsy (C6 -T1) presentation depends on the level of the lesion. Low lesions present as impaired abduction of the thumb and loss of sensation over the radial 3 1/2 digits. High lesions will have the features of low lesions, but will also have paralysis of the radial wrist flexors and forearm pronator muscles. The hand will be held with the ulnar fingers flexed and the index straight (pointing index sign). 

Option B: In a total plexus injury, C5 - T1 are injured. Here, the baby's arm is flail and pale. There is paralysis of all the fingers and unilateral Horner's syndrome. 

Option D: C5 - C6 injury is seen in Erb's palsy. It is typically seen in overweight babies with shoulder dystocia at delivery. There is paralysis of the abductors, external rotators of the shoulder, and the supinators. The arm will be held to the side in internal rotation and pronation with loss of finger extension.

The following image shows the clinical presentation of Erb's palsy.

Related Pearl: Erb's and Klumpke's Palsies.

Causes

Undue separtion of head and shoulder. Upper plexus root involved. 

Eg.Shoulder dystocia at delivery, motor vehicle accidents

Hyperabduction of shoulder. Lower plexus root involved.

Eg. Difficult breech delivery, Holding on to something (e.g. a branch) during a fall, Cervical rib syndrome, Scalene syndrome

Deltoid, Supraspinatus - loss of abduction

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with fever, joint pain, and a lesion over his hand, as seen in the image below. Histopathological examination would most likely reveal?

choices.text: Perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates, perivascular infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy
Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates  and perivascular infiltrates
Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles
Perimysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has arthritis and skin lesions pointing to Gottron's papules and highly suggestive of dermatomyositis. Perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates, perivascular infiltrates, and perifascicular atrophy are characteristic histopathological findings that would be seen in this condition.

Dermatomyositis (DM) is an autoimmune disorder predominantly affecting the skin and skeletal muscle. The following are various manifestations of dermatomyositis:

  • Gottron's papules: Violaceous, erythematous papules overlying the dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal, elbow, or knee joints, as shown in the image below
  • Gottron's sign: Symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques, often atrophic, in the same distribution as Gottron's papules.
  • Shawl sign/V-sign: Fixed macular erythema across the shoulders and outer arms(Shawl distribution)
  • Periungual telangiectasias: Dilated capillaries of the nail folds
  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the skin of the tips and sides of the fingers, resulting in irregular, dirty-appearing lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual labourer
  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.
  • Less common manifestations include: Facial swelling, malignancy, erythroderma, lichen planus

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies. Electromyography will reveal features of myopathy. Histology will show perifascicular atrophy. Immunohistochemical staining will reveal myxovirus resistance protein A, a sensitive and specific marker. 

Treatment of dermatomyositis includes:

  • Immunotherapy with high-dose glucocorticoids - first-line drug
  • Methotrexate - second-line drug. Indications include -
    • When a patient presents with severe weakness or other organ system involvement
    • Patients with a risk of steroid complications, like patients with diabetes, osteoporosis, or postmenopausal women
    • Patients who do not show improvement after 2-4 months of treatment with prednisone or those who cannot be maintained on a low dose 
  • Triple therapy with intravenous immunoglobulin or rituximab may be required

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: In the following flowchart representing the natural history of disease, the duration between points A to B is called?
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the final critical point of diagnosis (point B) is called Screening time.

Screening is the search for unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applicable tests or procedures. It must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis (point C in the image).

This ensures the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. The final critical point (point B in the image) is the stage beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful or there would be permanent damage.

The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C) is called lead time.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments is/are used in tubal patency testing?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct. All the above instruments are used in tubal patency testing. 

Image 1 shows Rubins Insufflation Cannula.

It requires a ‘Y’ rubber tube. One end is attached to a bulb and the other end to a manometer.

Uses: To know the patency of the tube (Rubin’s test) in infertility investigation or following tuboplasty.

 

Image 2 shows Cervical occlusion clamp.

  • The blades are guarded with rubber tubes to avoid trauma to tissues.
  • Cervix is occluded with the instrument and methylene blue dye is injected into the uterine cavity through the fundus using a syringe and a needle.

Uses: Evaluation of tubal patency during laparotomy (following tuboplasty).

 

Image 3 shows Hysterosalpingographic cannula.

It is required to push the iodine containing radio-opaque dye (urograffin) into the uterus during hysterosalpingography.

Uses:

  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) to evaluate tubal patency.
  • Hydrotubation.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old Rh-negative multigravida presents to the OPD at 33 weeks of gestation. An indirect Coombs test which was performed at 12 weeks of gestation revealed critical antibody titers. She was advised to undergo a middle cerebral artery doppler study at weekly intervals. A middle cerebral artery PSV was performed and the value was > 1.5 MoM. What is the next best step in the management?

PSV- Peak systolic velocity

MoM - Multiples of the Median

choices.text: Repeat Middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity after 1 week
Emergency Intrauterine transfusion of blood to the fetus
Perform cordocentesis to determine fetal hematocrit
Immediate termination of pregnancy after steroid administration

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the peak systolic velocity of the Middle cerebral artery is >1.5 MoM and the next best step in the management is to perform cordocentesis to determine fetal hematocrit.

The critical value of PSV of the Middle cerebral artery is 1.5 MoM 

PSV of the Middle cerebral artery Management
< 1.5 MoM Deliver at 37 or 38 weeks of gestation
> 1.5 MoM

>34 weeks of gestation: Deliver

<34 weeks of gestation: Cordocentesis

The protocol for RH isoimmunisation is as follows:(Options A and D)

The first step is to determine the blood group of the husband.

  • If the husband's blood group is Rh-negative: Routine antenatal care is given 
  • If the husband's blood group is Rh-positive: an Indirect Coomb's Test is performed 

Indirect Coomb's test (ICT):

If ICT is negative:

  • In a primigravida with no history of blood transfusion repeat ICT at 36 weeks.
  • In a multigravida or previous history of transfusion repeat ICT at monthly intervals till 24 weeks and every 2 weeks thereafter.

If ICT is positive:- Determine the antibody titer. 1:16 is considered a critical titer.

Titer less than 1:16 Titer more than 1:16
Repeat antibody titration at weekly intervals and deliver at term

Monitor fetal anemia with serial middle cerebral artery Doppler study(peak systolic velocity) every 1-2 weeks

Cordocentesis:

  • Haematocrit (HCT) <30%: Intrauterine transfusion is performed and labor is induced approximately three weeks after the last transfusion, typically at 37 or 38 weeks of gestation (Option B)
  • Haematocrit (HCT) >30%: Repeat weekly cordocentesis based on middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity. Deliver at 37 or 38 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic due to pneumonia. She has had repeated episodes of pneumonia due to Staphylococcus aureus in the past. She also has a history of easy bruising. On examination, she has light skin, silvery hair, and light blue eyes. Multiple bruises are seen on her legs and arms in different stages of healing. On peripheral blood film, the following image is seen. Which of the following defects is present in this patient?

choices.text: Loss of function of LYST gene

questions.solution:
The given clinical features of immunodeficiency fit the description of Chediak Higashi syndrome. A defect in the LYST gene is implicated in the development of Chediak Higashi syndrome.

Chediak Higashi syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to loss of function of the LYST gene (Lysosomal trafficking regulator gene)- a protein required for the normal packaging and distribution of granules. This defect results in defective chemotaxis, phagolysosome fusion, degranulation of T-cells and NK cells, and ADP granule function in platelets. Due to the defective fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes, giant granules in the neutrophils are seen. Other features include albinism (due to abnormalities of melanocytes), nerve defects (nerve cell dysfunction), and bleeding (due to platelet dysfunction).

Other Options:

Option A: Defective CD40 ligand is seen in hyper IgM syndrome. In this, there are low levels of IgG, IgA, and IgE. Clinically, patients present with recurrent pyogenic infections, because the level of opsonizing IgG antibodies is low. No giant granules are seen on peripheral blood film along with no signs of albinism. 

Option B: WAS gene mutation is seen in Wiscott-Aldrich syndrome, an X-linked disease characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection. This patient has no history of eczema.

Option D: Defective NADPH oxidase is seen in Chronic granulomatous disease, which is characterized by defects in bacterial killing and renders patients susceptible to recurrent bacterial infection especially by catalase-positive organisms. It is not associated with albinism and platelet dysfunction.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman underwent hysterectomy 3 weeks back. She now presents with constant dribbling of urine. The tampon test was positive. A genitourinary fistula was suspected and cystourethroscopy showed that the fistulous opening was 1.7 cm away from the external urinary meatus. What type of fistula is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of a fistulous opening 1.7 cm away from the external urinary meatus is classified as a Type III genitourinary fistula.

A genitourinary fistula (GUF) is defined as an abnormal communication between the urinary (ureters, bladder, urethra) and the genital (uterus, cervix, vagina) systems. Obstetric trauma such as prolonged or obstructed labor accounts for the majority of cases of GUF in developing countries, whereas iatrogenic injury during surgeries such as hysterectomy is the most common cause of GUFs in developed countries.

Although GUFs can be classified in many ways, a comprehensive and standardized classification system has been developed as follows:

Based on fistula distance from the external urethral meatus:

  • Type 1: Distal edge of fistula > 3.5 cm from the external urinary meatus
  • Type 2: Distal edge of fistula 2.5–3.5 cm from the external urinary meatus
  • Type 3: Distal edge of fistula 1.5 to < 2.5 cm from the external urinary meatus
  • Type 4: Distal edge of fistula < 1.5 cm from the external urinary meatus

Based on the size/largest diameter:

  1. Size < 1.5 cm
  2. Size 1.5-3 cm
  3. Size > 3 cm 

Based on degree of fibrosis:

  1. None or only mild fibrosis (around fistula and/or vagina) and/or vaginal length > 6 cm
  2. Moderate or severe fibrosis (around fistula and/or vagina) and/or reduced vaginal length 
  3. Special consideration, e.g., post-radiation, ureteric involvement, circumferential fistula, or previous repair.

Clinical presentation:

  • Unexplained continuous urinary leakage from the vagina after a recent operation.
  • A vesicovaginal fistula may present days to weeks after the initial inciting surgery, and those following hysterectomy typically present after 1 to 3 weeks.
  • Unusual symptoms are fever, pain, ileus, and bladder irritability.

Diagnosis:

  • History and physical examination are suggestive of the diagnosis in most of the cases.
  • Tampon test / 3-swab test - In this test a solution of methylene blue is instilled into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After routine activity for about 20 minutes, the tampon is removed and inspected. Blue discoloration at the top suggests a high lying fistula whereas blue discoloration at the bottom suggests a low-lying fistula.
  • Cystourethroscopy - This is very useful to localize fistulas, determine proximity to the urethral meatus, number and sites of fistulae, and visualize bladder mucosa.
  • Urine culture is mandatory before surgery
  • USG - Kidney ureter and bladder
  • Intravenous pyelography (IVP)
  • Voiding cystourethrography (VCUG) can help confirm the presence, location, and the number of fistulous tracts.

The image given below shows the 3-swab test:

Management:

  • Conservative management using an indwelling catheter
  • Surgical management if indicated should be carried out in the first 24-48 hours following inciting surgery. In cases of extensive inflammation, surgery should be carried out after 6 weeks. The various surgical approaches used are:
    • Lazko's vaginal approach
    • Abdominal approach
    • Chassar Moir technique for vescicovaginal fistula.
    • Interpositional flaps - Omental J-flap in abdominal approach and Martius bulbocavernosus fat pad flap in vaginal approach
    • Ureteric reimplantation to the sigmoid colon, creating an ileal loop bladder or a rectal bladder
    • For ureteric fistulae, anastomosis with a stent, implantation of the ureter into the bladder, psoas muscle hitch, Boari's operation, and an ileal bladder are considered.
    • If one attempt fails to heal the fistula, a second vaginal repair can be undertaken after a period of 3 months.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

questions.text: Which of the following tests recent memory?

choices.text: Asking the patient to name the months in reverse order
Asking the patient what they had for dinner yesterday
Asking the patient to repeat a set of numbers after some time
Asking the patient when they got married

questions.solution:
Asking the patient what they had for dinner the previous day would be a suitable test to gauge their recent memory.

Other Options:

Option A: Asking the patient to recite the months in reverse order tests their concentration. 

Option C: Asking the patient to repeat a set of numbers after some time tests their immediate memory.

Option D: Asking the patient when they got married checks their remote memory. 

Related Pearl: Tests for evaluating attention, concentration and memory

Memory:

Memory is of 3 types:

  • Immediate memory and recall are usually tested by digit span/ digit repetition test.
    • Digit span test: Digits spelled at the rate of 1 digit per second. It is of two types: Digit forward and Digit backward.
    • Digit forward: Reproduction of increasingly longer digits. E.g., Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat in the same order 2 – 4 – 8 –1 –5 –7 –9.
    • Digit backward: Reproduction of longer digits in the backward direction. Eg: Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat it backward. 9 -7 -5 -1 -8- 4- 2.
    • The above tests should be stopped when there are 2 successive failures. Hence 2 skips are not allowed.
  • Recent memory: Ask them how they reached the hospital or what they ate for breakfast.
  • Remote memory: Relevant questions from the past like close relative's birth dates. 

Attention:

  • Is the patient's attention easily aroused and sustained?
  • Digit span test.

Concentration:

  • Is the patient easily distractable or can they concentrate?
  • Serial subtraction test: Minimum of five subtractions done serially is taken into account
  • Count backward from 20.
  • Enumerate the months in reverse order.

questions.text: A cardiologist wants to study the effect of an anti-hypertensive drug. He notes down the initial systolic blood pressure of 50 patients and then administers the drug to them. After a week of treatment, he measures the blood pressure again. What is the most appropriate statistical test to be chosen to compare the change in blood pressure?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, a paired t-test (before and after) would be used. As the effect of a drug to change the blood pressure is measured on the same sample, making it a dependent sample.

T tests are performed when experimental subjects are divided into two different groups. One group is treated with one intervention and the other group with a different intervention. 

Other options:

Option B: Unpaired t-test or a student t-test or independent t-test is used when the two groups under comparison are independent of each other.

Option C: ANOVA or analysis of variance is a test used to compare and analyse the difference between the means of more than two groups.

Option D: Chi-square Test is a method of testing the significance of the difference between two proportions. 

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is being evaluated for intellectual disability. On examination, the child had large ears, a long, prominent square jaw, and enlarged testes. Genetic analysis reveals trinucleotide repeats. Which of the following is not true about this particular syndrome?

choices.text: It is caused due to mutations in the FMR1 gene
The nucleotide repeats involve the CGG sequence
The larger the triplet repeat expansion, the lesser the intellectual disability
Females can also be affected by this syndrome.

questions.solution:
The patient’s clinical features are strongly suggestive of Fragile X syndrome. The larger the triplet repeat expansion in fragile X syndrome, the more significant the intellectual disability.

It is caused due to trinucleotide repeat expansion (CGG) of DNA in the long arm of chromosome X involving the FMR1 gene. The main clinical features in affected males include intellectual disability, autistic features,post-pubertal macroorchidism, and characteristic facial features including large ears, a long face, and a  square jaw. Affected females also show varying degrees of intellectual disability. 

Diagnosis is made by DNA testing which shows more than 200 trinucleotide (CGG) repeats. Premutation repeats(55-200 repeats) are associated with fragile X–associated tremor/ataxia syndrome, and premature ovarian failure. Unaffected individuals show fewer than 50 trinucleotide repeats.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with infertility, and a cervical mucus study was performed on the 24th day of her menstrual cycle (she has a regular 28 days cycle). Which of the following is not true regarding the interpretation of the findings shown in this test?

choices.text: This finding is due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus.
This phenomenon occurs under the influence of estrogen.
This test indicates that ovulation has occurred in this patient.
Corpus luteum is absent during this time of her cycle.

questions.solution:
The image shows a specimen of dried cervical mucus with ferning. It occurs under the influence of estrogen. The persistence of ferning beyond day 22 indicates anovulation. In this patient, ferning is present on the 24th day, which indicates that her cycles are anovulatory.

Fern test:

A drop of cervical mucus is spread and dried on a glass slide and observed under the low-power microscope. 

In the preovulatory (estrogenic) phase, a characteristic pattern of fern formation is observed due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus secreted under the estrogenic effect.

Following ovulation, ferning disappears due to progesterone activity. The disappearance of ferning is presumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity.

Insler devised a scoring system by just taking into account various properties of cervical mucus such as amount, ferning, and viscosity as an inexpensive test of ovulation.

questions.text: You enter the ENT operation theatre when a procedure is underway for a patient with fungal sinusitis with a fungal ball.  You notice the following instruments on the instruments tray. Which of the following is not an indication for the procedure performed with these instruments?
questions.solution:
The given image is of instruments commonly used in Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) operation. Lateral frontal sinus disease is a contraindication for endoscopic sinus surgery as the disease is inaccessible by endoscopic procedures.

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis (diffuse nasal polyposis).
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball or nasal polyp.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Control of epistaxis by endoscopic cautery.
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.

Contraindications to FESS:

  • Inexperience and lack of proper instrumentation.
  • Disease inaccessible by endoscopic procedures, e.g. lateral frontal sinus disease and stenosis of internal opening of frontal sinus.
  • Osteomyelitis.
  • Threatened intracranial or intraorbital complication.

questions.text: During oogenesis,  when will the arrest of the secondary oocyte occur?
questions.solution:
The secondary oocyte gets arrested during meiosis-2 in the metaphase of the cell cycle.

Oogenesis is the process wherein oogonia differentiate into mature oocytes. It begins before birth. At birth, there are approximately 2 million primordial follicles. Primordial germ cells divide by mitosis to form oogonia.

The majority of the oogonia divide by mitosis, however, some enter meiosis I and get arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase and are now called primary oocytes. These primary oocytes remain arrested in this manner until puberty. Primary oocytes haven't completed meiosis, hence they're diploid. The primary oocyte along with surrounding epithelial cells forms the primordial follicle.

Meiosis I is completed after LH surge during puberty to form the secondary oocyte. The cell then enters meiosis II but arrests in metaphase approximately 3 hours before ovulation.

If fertilization does not occur, the secondary oocyte fails to complete the second meiotic division and degenerates about 24 hours after ovulation. If fertilization occurs, penetration by the sperm signals the secondary oocyte to complete meiosis II. This results in one mature oocyte (ovum) and another smaller cell called the second polar body that is shed off.

questions.text: In the clinical ward rounds, the professor tests the vibratory sensations of a patient by placing a 128Hz tuning fork on his great toe. He explains the receptors involved rapidly adapt to ongoing stimuli. Which receptor is he referring to?
questions.solution:
Rapidly adapting receptors that sense 128 Hz (fast vibration) are Pacinian corpuscles.

Pacinian corpuscles are cutaneous mechanoreceptors, which consist of unmyelinated dendritic endings of a sensory nerve fiber, encapsulated by concentric lamellae of connective tissue. It gives them an onion peel-like appearance. They respond to deep pressure and fast vibration of frequencies ranging between 60 - 300 Hz. Pacinian corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors, adapting in a few hundredths of a second.

The below image shows the histology of the Pacinian corpuscle.

Other options : 

Option A - Merkel's discs are expanded dendritic endings, which respond to sustained pressure and touch. They are slow-adapting receptors, allowing one to determine the continuous touch of objects against the skin.

Option B - Ruffini's end organs are enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules. These adapt very slowly and therefore, are important for signaling continuous states of deformation of the tissues, such as heavy prolonged touch and pressure signals. They are also found in joint capsules and help to signal the degree of joint rotation.

Option D - Meissner’s corpuscles are elongated encapsulated nerve endings of a large myelinated sensory nerve fiber. They are abundant in the nonhairy parts of the skin (lips, fingertips). Meissner's corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors, particularly sensitive to the movement of objects over the surface of the skin, as well as to low-frequency vibration (5-40 Hz).
